law.shorttitle: VOL. 1, SEC. 98.TAX COLLECTORS, DUTIES AND LIABILITIES OF.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend section 98 of the Code of 1895 (volume 1), which fixes the terms of office of county officers, so as to add a proviso to said section requiring tax collectors to complete the collection of State and county taxes for the years for which they have been elected and for which they have given
bond, and to fix and determine the duties and liabilities of the outgoing and incoming tax collectors, and for other purposes.
law.p: SECTION 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That from and after the passage of this Act section 98 of the Code of 1895 (volume 1), which fixes the terms of office of county officers be, and the same is, hereby amended by adding at the end of said section the following proviso: Provided, that where the tax collector of any county is succeeded by another, that the outgoing collector shall make final settlement with the State and county for the taxes levied and chargeable for the year for which he was elected and for the collection of which he has given bond; the incoming collector being charged and responsible only with the collection of the taxes due for the years for which he is chosen and bonded. Code 98 amended. Tax collector.
SEC. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 1, SEC. 101.JUSTICES OF THE PEACE, ELECTION OF
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend Section 101 of the Code of the State of Georgia, relating to the time and place of election of justices of the peace, by striking out the words and figures January, 1873, in the second and third lines of said section, and inserting in lieu thereof the words and figures December, 1900.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same,

Section I. That Section 101 of the Code of Georgia, relating to the time and place of elections of justices of the peace, be amended by striking from the second and third lines of said Section, the words and figures January, 1873 and inserting in lieu thereof the words and figures December, 1900, so that said Section when amended shall read as follows: Justices of the Peace
shall be elected on the first Saturday in December, 1900, and every fourth year thereafter, by the voters of their respective districts; provided, they have resided in the district as much as thirty days immediately preceding the election, and are otherwise qualified. The election must be held at the place of holding Justices' court for the district; if none, then at the election precinct; if no election precinct, then at some place in the district named by the ordinary, of which ten days' written notice must be given in the district. Code 101 amended. Justices of Peace, time and place of election.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 1, SEC. 105.CONSTABLES, ELECTION OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend Section 105 of the Code of the State of Georgia, relating to the time and place of elections for constables in this State, by substituting for said Section the following, to wit: Constables shall be elected at the same place that Justices of the Peace are elected, and by the same class of voters, once every two years, the first election to be held on the first Saturday in December, 1900, and thereafter on the first Saturday of December, every two years; provided, that this Act shall not effect or change the time of the election of constables in January, 1899.
law.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same,

Section I. That Section 105 of the Code of Georgia, relating to the time and place of holding elections for constables in said State, be, and the same is, hereby amended by substituting for said Section the following words, to wit: Constables in this State shall be elected at the same place and by the same class of voters that Justices of the Peace are elected, which elections for constables shall be held on the first Saturday in December, 1900, and on the first Saturday of December every two years thereafter; provided, that this Act shall not effect or change the time of the election of constables in January, 1899. Code 105 amended. Constables, time and place of election.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 1, SEC. 107.CONTESTED ELECTIONS, COMMISSIONS WHEN ISSUED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend Section 107 of volume 1 of the Code of 1895, relating to proceedings in contested elections by adding thereto an additional sub-section to be known as sub-section 8, limiting the time and defining the circumstances under which commissions shall be withheld by the Governor after notice of contest has been sent to him, and providing for the issuing of commissions after certain time.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, Section 107 of volume 1 of the Code of 1895, relating to proceedings in contested elections, be and the same is, hereby amended by adding thereto an additional sub-section, to be known as sub-section 8, and to read as follows, viz.: 8. That the contestant shall send to the Governor a copy of the notice, in writing, required by sub-section 2 of this Section to be served on the contestee, stating the grounds of contest and the time and place of taking testimony, and the name of the officer before whom testimony is to be taken; if no such copy is sent to the Governor within twenty days after the holding of the election, he shall proceed to issue commission as though no notice of contest had been received. That should the copy of notice above specified be received within the twenty days, but nothing more, and the time for taking testimony have passed, the party whose election was proposed to be contested may procure from the officer named in the notice as the one before whom the testimony was to be taken, a certificate showing that the contestant has taken no steps to prosecute his claim, and that the delay is not due to any fault on the part of said officer nor to the selection of any other officer to preside, nor to continuances granted by said officer to either party to be signed by said officer before the clerk of Superior Court or Ordinary of the county, who shall certify that the signature is genuine and the officer signing the same is known to him to be the identical officer who was selected to take testimony in the case, and upon the receipt of such certificate the Governor shall proceed to issue the commission just as though no notice of contest had ever been sent to him Code 107 amended. Contested election, notice of. Failure to prosecute claim.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 1, SEC. 107.CONTESTED ELECTIONS, BY WHOM DETERMINED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend paragraph VII. of section 107 of the Code of 1895, by adding after the word hearing in the last line of said section, the following: And in the event the Judge of the Superior Courts of said circuit is disqualified from hearing said contest, or for any legal cause refuses to hear the same, he shall certify this fact and shall transmit said papers and proceedings to a Judge of the Superior Court of an adjoining circuit, qualified to hear said contest, who shall hear and determine the same, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That paragraph VII. of section 107 of the Code of 1895 be and is hereby amended by adding after the word hearing in last line of said section, the following: And in the event the Judge of the Superior Court of said circuit is disqualified from hearing said contest, or for any legal cause refuses to hear the same, he shall certify this fact and transmit said papers and proceedings to a Judge of the Superior Courts of an adjoining circuit qualified to hear said contest, who shall hear and determine the same; so that said section as amended, shall read as follows, to wit: All papers and proceedings or copies of them duly certified by the presiding officer, or agreed to by the parties in writing, must be transmitted within five days after the closing of the testimony to the Judge of the Superior Court of the circuit wherein the contest may arise, who shall hear and determine the same, either in term time or in chambers, after giving reasonable notice to the parties concerned or their counsel of the time and place of hearing, and in the event the Judge of the Superior Court of said circuit is disqualified from hearing said contest, or for any legal cause refuses to hear the same, he shall certify this fact and transmit said papers and proceedings to a
Judge of the Superior Court of an adjoining circuit, qualified to hear said contest, who shall hear and determine the same. Code 107 amended. Contested election, disqualified judge.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 1, SEC. 982.STATE DEPOSITORIES, BANKS IN DUBLIN.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend section 982 of the Code of Georgia of 1895, providing for the selection by the Governor of banks in certain cities therein named as State depositories, and the several Acts of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia amendatory thereof, so as to add the city of Dublin in Laurens county, Georgia, to the list of such cities.
law.p: Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That section 982 of the Code of Georgia of 1895, providing for the selection by the Governor of banks in certain cities therein named as State depositories, and the several Acts of the General Assembly of Georgia, amendatory thereof, be, and the same are, hereby so amended as to add the city of Dublin in Laurens county, Georgia, to the list of such cities. Code 982 amended. State depositories.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 1, SEC. 1642.DISABLED OR INDIGENT SOLDIERS, LICENSE TAX OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend section 1642 of volume 1 of the Code which relates to exemptions to certain Confederate and other soldiers, by adding to the first proviso the following words: or running a billiard, pool, or other table of like character, or dealing in futures, or peddling stoves or clocks, or carrying on the business of a pawnbroker or auctioneer; or dealing in lightning rods.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of same, That section 1642
of volume 1 of the Code be, and the same is, hereby amended by adding to the first proviso to same, the following words, to wit: or running a billiard, pool or other table of like character, or dealing in futures, or peddling stoves, or clocks, or carrying on the business of a pawnbroker or auctioneer, or dealing in lightning rods, so that said section, when amended, shall read as follows: Any disabled or indigent Confederate soldier or soldiers of the Seminole, Creek or Cherokee Indian war, or Mexican war, who are residents of this State, may peddle or conduct business in any town, city, county or counties thereof without paying license for the privilege of so doing; and a certificate from the ordinary of any county, stating the fact of his being such disabled or indigent Confederate soldier or soldiers of the Seminole, Creek or Cherokee Indian war or Mexican war, who are residents of the State, shall be sufficient proof; provided, that this section shall not authorize peddling or dealing in ardent and intoxicating drinks, or running a billiard, pool, or other table of like character, or dealing in futures, or peddling stoves or clocks, or carrying on the business of a pawnbroker or auctioneer, or dealing in lightning rods; and provided further, that the privilege hereby granted shall not be transferred to or used by any other person. Code, Vol. I, 1642 amended. Indigent soldiers peddlers
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 1, SEC. 1700.OYSTER BEDS, LOCATION OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend Section 1700 of the Code of 1895 which provides that the natural oyster-beds of the State shall forever remain the property of this State, open to all her citizens for the procuring of oysters, and for the better securing of this purpose, the charts made and published in consequence of the resolution passed by the Legislature of this State, by the United States Geodetic Survey, known as Bulletin No. 19, shall be conclusive evidence of the location of such natural oyster-beds and of vacant ground, by striking out from the seventh line of said section the word conclusive.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That Section 1700 of the Code of 1895 be amended by striking out the word conclusive from the seventh line thereof, so that the said section as amended, shall read as follows: Code 1700 amended.

blockquote.p: 1700.Natural Beds. The natural oyster-beds of this State shall forever remain the property of this State, open to all her citizens for the procuring of oysters for consumption, sale, seed, or propagating; and for the better securing of this purpose, the charts made and published in consequence of a resolution passed by the Legislature of this State, by the United States Geodetic Survey, known as `Bulletin No. 19,' shall be evidence of the location of such natural oyster-beds and of vacant ground; provided, that wherever beds shown by said `Bulletin No. 19' to be natural oyster-beds shall, as a matter of fact, not extend below low-water mark, then the territory below low-water mark shall nevertheless be open to lease. Except as herein stated it shall not be lawful for the county commissioners or ordinary to grant leases to any grounds shown on said `Bulletin No. 19' to contain a natural bed, and it shall be lawful for them to grant leases on any or all territory indicated on said `Bulletin No. 19,' as vacant. Oyster beds.

law.p: Sec. II. All laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 2, SEC. 1916BANKS, LOANS BY.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend Section 1916, volume II of the Code of 1895 by striking from the third line thereof the word collateral, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That section 1916, volume II of the Code of 1895 be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking from the third line of said section the word collateral, so that thus amended, said section shall read as follows: No bank, or corporation, doing a banking business, shall be allowed to loan to any one person, unless such loan is amply secured
by good security, more than ten per cent. of its capital stock and surplus. Code, Vol. 2, 1916 amended. Loans by banks.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws, in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 2, SEC. 2250STOCK KILLED BY RAILROADS, LIABILITY FOR.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend Section 2250 of the Code of 1895, as to the manner of collecting claims, and penalties for failure of overseers and trackmenders to file weekly lists of the stock killed on their respective roads, so as to make such claims recoverable as other claims.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That the law as contained in Section 2250 of the Code of 1895, be amended by inserting the word other between the word of and the word `claim in the sixth line of said section, and by striking out the words during such failure, as contained in the fourth and fifth lines, and by striking out the words for stock killed on railroads, as contained in the sixth and seventh lines, so that said section, when so amended, shall read as follows: Upon failure of any overseer or trackmender to comply with the provisions of Section 2248, he shall be liable to pay the owners of said stock double the value of all stock killed on his particular section, and not reported; the same to be recovered in the manner as now provided by law for the collection of other claims in this State. Code, Vol. 2, 2250 amended. Liability for stock killed by railroads.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 2, SEC. 2253 TO 2260 INCLUSIVE.RELATIVE TO SUITS FOR STOCK KILLED BY RAILROADS, REPEALED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal Sections 2253, 2254, 2255, 2256, 2257, 2258, 2259 and 2260 of the Code of 1895, as to notice to railroad companies of claims for killing or damaging of stock or other property, and the form thereof, the trial, judgment and execution under said notice, and appeal therefrom, and levy, advertisement and sale under said execution, disposition of the proceeds of said sale, the tender of a reasonable amount for said stock or damages, and the effect of a rejection thereof, and the right of joint owners or agents to bring said suits, and their bar to future actions.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That Sections 2253, 2254, 2255, 2256, 2257, 2258, 2259 and 2260 of the Code of Georgia of 1895, as to notice to railroad companies of claims for killing or damaging livestock, or other property, and the form of said notice, and the trial, judgment and execution under said notice, the appeal from said judgment, the levy, advertisement and sale under said execution, the disposition of the proceeds of said sale, the tender of a reasonable amount for said stock as damages, and the effect of a rejection thereof, and the right of joint owners or agents to bring said suits, and thereby barring future actions, be and the same are, hereby repealed. Code, Vol. 2. 2253 to 2200, inclusive, repealed. Suits for stock killed by railroads.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 2, SEC. 2334.RAILROADS, VENUE OF SUITS AGAINST.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend Section 2334 of the Civil Code of 1895, which fixes the venue of suits against railroad companies in this State.
law.p:
Section 1. The General Assembly of Georgia do enact, That Section 2334 of the Civil Code of Georgia of 1895, which fixes
the venue of suits against railroad companies in this State, be and the same is, hereby amended, by adding to the end of said Section the following words: Whenever a railroad company incorporated under the laws of this State shall have, in violation of the provisions of paragraph four (4) of Section two (2) of article four (4) of the Constitution of this State, acquired by purchase, lease or otherwise the ownership or control of the line of railroad of a competing railroad company in this State, the venue of a suit brought against said first described railroad company for the purpose of setting aside and having annulled such unlawful act of acquisition, shall be in any county through which may run the line of railroad so unlawfully acquired. Code, Vol. 2, 2334 amended. Venue of suits vs. railroads.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That all laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 2, SEC. 2835.HOMESTEADS, RECORD OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend Section 2835 of the Code of 1895, relating to the approval and record of homesteads, so as to provide for the record of homesteads in each county in which exempted land is situated, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That Section 2835 of the Code of 1895, relating to approval and record of homesteads, be amended by inserting after the word county and before the word who in the seventh line, the words and when land out of his county is exempted, the ordinary shall transmit a certified copy of the homestead to the Clerk of the Superior Court of each county in which exempted land is situated. And by striking out the word who in the seventh line of said section, and inserting in lieu thereof the words each of whom. So that said Section, when so amended, shall read as follows: Application for homestead, how approved, etc. If, at the time and place appointed for passing upon said application, no objection shall be urged by any creditor of the applicant, the ordinary shall indorse upon said schedule and upon said plat: `Approved this the day of , 18,' filling the blanks, and shall sign the same
officially, and hand the same to the Clerk of the Superior Court of his county, and when land out of his county is exempted, the ordinary shall transmit a certified copy of the homestead to the Clerk of the Superior Court of each county in which exempted land is situated, each of whom shall record the same in a book to be kept for that purpose in his office, which record or a certified transcript of same shall be competent evidence in all the courts of this State. Code, Vol 2, 2835 amended Homesteads, record of.
Section II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 2, SEC. 2867.EXEMPTIONS, RECORD OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend Section 2867 of the Code of 1895, relative to the record of schedules of exempted property, so as to provide for the record in the county in which the real estate is situated of schedules exempting land from levy and sale.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That Section 2867 of the Code of 1895, relative to record of schedules of exempted property, be amended by inserting after the word purpose and before the word and in the eighth line thereof, the words and when land out of his county is exempted, he shall transmit the schedule to the ordinary of the county in which the land is situated for record in like manner, so that said Section, when so amended, shall read as follows: Mode of obtaining exemption. Every debtor seeking the benefit of the preceding Section, or if he refuses, his wife, or any person acting as her next friend, shall make out a schedule of the property claimed to be exempt, and return the same to the ordinary of the county, without making any application for homestead, and it shall not be necessary to publish the same in a gazette. The ordinary shall record the schedule in a book to be kept by him for that purpose, and when land out of his county is exempted, he shall transmit the schedule to the ordinary of the county in which the land is situated, for record in like manner, and he shall receive for each schedule filed, approved and recorded, the sum of two dollars, and for each and every plat returned by the county surveyor under the
following section, to be recorded by him in a book kept for that purpose, the further sum of one dollar. Code, Vol. 2, 2867 amended. Exemptions, record of
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 2, SEC. 3950.ANSWER OF DEFENDANT, WHEN DISCOVERY IS PRAYED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend Section 3950 of the Civil Code of 1895, by adding immediately after the word circumstances in the fourth line of said Section, the following proviso, to wit: provided, discovery is expressly prayed for in plaintiffs' petition.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly, That Section 3950 of the Civil Code of 1895 be, and the same is, hereby amended by inserting immediately after the word circumstance in the fourth line of said Section the following words, to wit: Provided, discovery is expressly prayed for in plaintiffs' petition, so that said section when so amended will read as follows: The answer of a defendant, as to facts within his own knowledge, responsive to the discovery sought, is evidence in his favor and can be rebutted only by two witnesses, or one witness and corroborating circumstances; provided, discovery is expressly prayed for in the plaintiffs' petition. Code, Vol. 2, 3950 amended. Answer where discovery is prayed.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 2, SEC. 4685.CONDEMNATION OF RAILROAD RIGHT OF WAY BY TELEGRAPH COMPANY.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled An Act to provide a uniform method of exercising the right of condemning, taking, or damaging private property, approved December 18, 1894, and codified in sections 4657 to 4686, inclusive, of the Code of 1895, and amended by an Act approved December 21, 1897, so as to provide for the contents, direction and service of the notice contemplated by section thirteen of said Act, and by section 4669 of said Code, when a telegraph company undertakes to condemn a portion of the right of way of a railroad for the purposes of constructing, maintaining and operating its telegraph lines along and upon such right of way, and providing that such condemnation proceedings may be had in one county for the entire length of the railroad within this State, and for the assessment of damages therefor, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That from and after the passage of this Act, the Act entitled An Act to provide a uniform method of exercising the right of condemning, taking or damaging private property, approved December 18, 1894, and codified in sections 4657 to 4686, inclusive, of the Code of 1895, and amended by an Act approved December 21, 1897, be amended by adding at the end of the twenty-ninth section of said Act, and at the end of section 4685 of said Code, as amended, the following words, to wit: provided, however, that when a telegraph company undertakes to condemn so much of the right of way of a railroad company as may be necessary for its use, for the purpose of constructing, maintaining and operating its telegraph lines along and upon such right of way, the notice provided for in section 4669 of said Code shall be directed to said railroad company, and shall set out the manner in which the telegraph company proposes to construct its lines on said right of way of said railroad company; fix the time when the hearing shall be had; give the name of the assessor selected by said telegraph company, and request the railroad company to select an assessor, which said notice shall be served upon said railroad company as is provided for the service of other suits upon railroad companies in this State; there need be but one condemnation proceeding against the same railroad company, which may be had in any
county where service can be made upon said company, as herein provided. But if the said railroad company has a main or principal office in this State, then said proceeding shall be had in the county in which said main or principal office is located, and the assessors shall make their finding for the damages to which said railroad company may be entitled by reason of the construction, maintenance and operation of said telegraph lines in the manner set out in said notice. The hearing may be had in the office of the ordinary of the county in which said condemnation proceedings are held, or at such place as the assessors may fix; and it shall not be necessary for said assessors to go upon or inspect the premises sought to be condemned,

but they shall make their findings upon the testimony heard by them as to the damages that will be done said railroad company in the premises; it shall not be necessary to serve such notice upon any person or corporation other than the railroad company in possession of and operating said railroad whose right of way is sought to be condemned by the telegraph company for its use, and only the interest of such railroad company so served shall be affected by said proceedings; so that said section when amended shall read as follows, to wit: The method of condemnation of property and assessment of damages hereinbefore provided shall apply to condemnation by cities, counties, railroads, telegraph, canal, mining, and waterworks companies, drainage by counties, tram-roads, light-houses and beacon constructions, and to all persons or corporations having the privilege of exercising the right of eminent domain; provided, however, that when a telegraph company undertakes to condemn so much of the right of way of a railroad company as may be necessary for its use for the purpose of constructing, maintaining and operating its telegraph lines along and upon such right

of way, the notice provided for in section 4669 of said Code shall be directed to said railroad company, and shall set out the manner in which the telegraph company proposes to construct its lines on said right of way of said railroad company; fix the time when the hearing shall be had; give the name of the assessor selected by said telegraph company, and request the railroad company to select an assessor, which said notice shall be served upon said railroad company as is provided for the service of other suits upon railroad companies in this State; there need be but one condemnation proceeding against the same railroad company, which may be had in any county where service can be made upon said company, as herein provided; but if the said railroad company has a main or principal office located in this State, then said proceeding shall be had in the county in which said main or principal office is located,
and the assessors shall make their findings for the damage, to which said railroad company may be entitled by reason of the construction, maintenance and operation of the telegraph lines in the manner set out in said notice. The hearing may be had in the office of the Ordinary of the county in which said condemnation proceedings are had or at such place as these assessors may fix; and shall not be necessary for said assessors to go upon or inspect the premises sought to be condemned, but they shall make their findings upon the testimony heard by them as to the damages that will be done said railroad company in the premises; it shall not be necessary to serve such notice upon any person or corporation other than the railroad company in possession of and operating said railroad whose right of way is sought to be condemned by the telegraph company for its use, and only the interest of such railroad company so served shall be affected by said proceedings. Condemnation of R. R. right of way by telegraph companies. 4685 of Code amended.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 2, SEC. 5315.DEPOSITIONS, CONTEMPT TO COMMISSIONER.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend Section 5315 of the Code of Georgia in reference to the taking of depositions so as to authorize the production of documents before the commissioner, and to provide for the punishment of contempts to such commissioner, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That Section 5315 of the Code of Georgia be amended by adding to said section after the word witnesses in the seventh line of said section, the words: Provided further, that the commissioner before whom evidence under this section is to be taken shall have power on notice being given to the opposite party or his attorney, or an subp[oelig]na duces tecum being served, five days previous to the hearing, to require any witness or party to produce at the hearing, books, writings, and other documents in his possession, power, custody or control. That any witness or party refusing to produce, appear or answer without legal excuse shall be guilty of contempt, and upon certification of said Act by the commissioner to the judge
in whose court the case is pending, the judge shall punish the same as though committed before him, so that said section, when so amended, shall read as follows: Section I. In all counties of this State of twenty thousand (20,000) inhabitants, and upwards, either party litigant in any court of record in any such county may, without any order or commission, take the deposition of any witness or witnesses in said case, whether resident in the county or not, upon giving the opposite party five days' notice of the time and place, with the names of the witnesses; provided further, that commissioner before whom the evidence under this section is to be taken shall have power, on notice being given to the opposite party or his attorney, or an subp[oelig]na duces tecum being served five days previous to the hearing, to require any witness or party to produce at the hearing, books, writings, and other documents in his possession, power, custody, or control. That any witness or party refusing to produce, appear, or answer without legal excuse, shall be guilty of contempt, and upon certification of said act by the commissioner to the judge in whose court the case is pending, the judge shall punish the same as though committed before him. Code, Vol. 2, 5315 [Illegible Text] amended. Production of books before Commissioners.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 2, SECS. 5315 AND 5316.DEPOSITIONS, WHEN AND BY WHOM TAKEN.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend Sections 5315 and 5316 of the Code of 1895, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That Section 5315 of the Code of 1895 be and the same is, hereby amended by striking from the said section the following words appearing in the second line of the same, to wit: of twenty thousand inhabitants and upwards, so that said section when amended shall read as follows: In all counties of this State, either party litigant in any court of record in any such county may, without any order or commission, take the depositions of any witness or witnesses in said case whether resident in the county or not, upon
giving the opposite party five days' notice of the time and place, with the names of the witnesses. Code, Vol. 2, 5315 amended. Depositions.

Section II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That Section 5316 of the Code of 1895 be amended by adding to the end of said Section the following words, to wit: or in case of failure to appoint, or there is a vacancy in the office of commission, the Clerk of the Superior Court is hereby authorized as an ex officio commissioner to take such depositions, and by further adding to said section immediately following the above words, the following words, to wit: All witnesses to be examined in the county of their residence, and before the commissioner or ex officio commissioner of such county, so that said section when amended shall read as follows: Such depositions to be taken before any commissioner appointed by the Judge of the Superior Court of said county for the purpose of taking such depositions and the appointment entered on the minutes, or in case of failure to appoint or there is a vacancy in the office of commissioner, the Clerk of the Superior Court is hereby authorized as an ex officio commissioner to take such depositions. All witnesses to be examined in the county of their residence, and before the commissioner or ex officio commissioner of such county. 5316 amended. Depositions, how taken.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 2, SEC. 5401.SHERIFFS' FEES, COST OF REVENUE STAMPS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend Section 5401 of volume II of the Code of 1895 relative to the fees of sheriffs by adding to the costs allowed to be charged for making out and executing titles to land the amount required to be paid for internal revenue stamps by the laws of the United States.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That Section 5401 of the 2d volume of the Code of 1895, which prescribes the fees of the sheriffs of this State, which they are entitled to collect as costs in civil cases, be amended by adding after the words and figures, For making out and executing titles to land $3.50, the
words and the amount paid for U. S. internal revenue stamps required by law to be affixed to such deed, and by adding after the words and figures If presented by the purchaser $1.00, the words and the amount paid for U. S. internal revenue stamps required by law to be affixed to such deed, so that said portions of said Section 5401 will read as follows: For making out and executing titles to land, $3.50, and the amount paid for U. S. internal revenue stamps required by law to be affixed to such deed. If presented by purchaser, $1.00, and the amount paid for U. S. internal revenue stamps required by law to be affixed to such deed. Code, Vol. 2, 5401 amended. Sheriffs' fees.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 2, SEC. 5541.EXCEPTIONS PENDENTE LITE.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend Section 5541 of the Civil Code, which relates to bills of exceptions pendente lite, by adding at the end of said Section the following words: but, if the court shall adjourn within less than thirty days from the date of the ruling complained of, such bill of exceptions, pendente lite, must be tendered within sixty days from the date of the order, decision or ruling complained of.
law.p:
Section 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, Section 5541 of the Civil Code be and the same is, hereby amended by adding at the end of said Section the following words: But, if the court shall adjourn within less than thirty days from the date of the ruling complained of, such bill of exceptions, pendente lite, must be tendered within sixty days from the date of the order, decision or ruling complained of, so that said Section, when amended, shall read as follows: Exceptions Pendente Lite. Exceptions tendered before the final judgment, for the mere purpose of being made a part of the record, shall be certified to be true by the judge, and ordered to be placed on the record. Such exceptions must be tendered during the term. But, if the court shall adjourn within less than thirty days from
the date of the ruling complained of, such bills of exceptions, pendente lite, must be tendered within sixty days from the date of the order, decision or ruling complained of. Code, Vol. 2, 5541 amended. Exceptions pendente lite.
Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, that all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 3, SEC. 341.METAL KNUCKS, CARRYING CONCEALED PROHIBITED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend section 341 of the Penal Code of Georgia, by inserting immediately after the word any in the third line and before the word pistol the following words: kind of metal knucks.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, section 341 of the Penal Code of this State be, and the same is, hereby altered and amended by inserting after the word any in the third line, and before the word pistol the following words: kind of metal knucks, so that said section when amended, shall read as follows: Any person having or carrying about his person, unless in an open manner and fully exposed to view, any kind of metal knucks, pistol, dirk, sword in a cane, spear, bowie knife, or any other kind of knives, manufactured and sold for the purpose of offense and defense, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Penal Code, 341 amended. Concealed weapons.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 3, SEC. 698.FIRING WOODS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend Section 698, volume 3 of the Code of 1895, which relates to setting on fire woods, etc., by striking from the second line thereof the words and maliciously and substituting in lieu thereof the words, carelessly or negligently, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That Section 698, volume 3 of the Code of 1895 be and the same is, hereby
amended by striking from the second line thereof the words and maliciously and substituting in lieu thereof the words carelessly or negligently, so that said section, thus amended, shall read as follows: If any person shall willfully, carelessly or negligently set on fire, or cause to be set on fire, any woods, lands or marshes, so as to cause loss or injury to another, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Penal Code, 698 amended. Firing woods.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 3, SEC. 765SUPERSEDEAS IN CASES OF CERTIORARI
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend Section 765 of the third volume of the Code of 1895, referring to certioraries from the county courts, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, Section 765 of the third volume of the Code of 1895 be, and the same is, hereby amended by adding at the end of said section the following words, to wit: And the filing of said bond shall operate as a supersedeas of the judgment rendered in said court for the space of ten days, so that when amended, said section shall read as follows: The writ shall not be granted unless the accused shall file his affidavit, stating that he has not had a fair trial, and has been wrongfully and illegally convicted, and shall also give bond and security, or make affidavit as is required of persons when carrying criminal cases to the Supreme Court; and the execution and filing of said bond shall operate as a supersedeas of the judgment rendered in said court for the space of ten days. Penal Code, 765 amended. Supersedeas,
Sec. II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: VOL. 3, SEC. 1107.SHERIFFS' FEES FOR SUMMONING WITNESSES.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend Section 1107 of volume 3 of the Code of Georgia, providing for the payment of sheriffs' fees, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That Section 1107 of volume 3 of the Code of Georgia be and the same is, hereby amended by adding to the fees of sheriffs in criminal cases, for summoning each witness (50) fifty cents. Penal Code, 1107 amended Sheriffs.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted by authority of the same, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: SUPERIOR COURTS, TERMS OF IN DODGE COUNTY.
law.fulltitle: An Act to change and fix the time of holding the superior court of Dodge county, in the Oconee Circuit, and for other purposes.
law.p: SECTION I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, the time of holding the superior court of Dodge county, in the Oconee Circuit, shall be changed from the second Mondays in March and September to the fourth Mondays in May and November of each year, and that each regular term of said court shall continue for two weeks, or so much thereof as may be necessary for the transaction of the business. Dodge county, Superior Court of.

SEC. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid. That all petitions, processes, rules, writs, bonds, subp[oelig]nas, and all other processes and papers of every kind, which have been or may be made returnable to the terms of said court as now provided by law, shall be held to relate and be returnable to the corresponding terms of said court as changed and fixed by this Act, and that all jurors and witnesses drawn or summoned to attend any term of
said court as now fixed by law, shall be required to attend the corresponding term as fixed and provided by this Act. Returns, etc.
SEC. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: SUPERIOR COURTS, TERMS OF IN CHEROKEE CIRCUIT.
law.fulltitle: An Act to fix the time for holding the superior courts in the Cherokee Circuit.
law.p: Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same,

SECTION I. That the superior courts of the Cherokee Circuit shall be hereafter held as follows: For the county of Bartow, on the second Mondays in January and July. For the county of Catoosa, on the first Mondays in February and August. For the county of Murray, on the third Monday in February and second Monday in August. For the county of Gordon, on the fourth Mondays in February and August. For the county of Dade, on the third Mondays in March and September. For the county of Whitfield, on the first Mondays in April and October. Cherokee Circuit, Superior Courts of.

SEC. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all processes heretofore issued from the superior courts of said counties as now held are hereby amended and made returnable to the terms of said court as herein fixed. Returns.
SEC. III. That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: SUPERIOR COURTS, TERMS OF IN COUNTIES OF DOUGHERTY, MITCHELL, WORTH, DECATUR, BAKER, CALHOUN AND MILLER.
law.fulltitle: An Act to change the time of holding the superior courts of Dougherty, Mitchell, Worth, Decatur, Baker, Calhoun, and Miller counties, and for other purposes.
law.p: SECTION I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the first day of January, 1899, the time of holding the superior courts in the counties of Dougherty, Mitchell, Worth, Decatur, Baker, Calhoun, and Miller shall be changed as follows: In Dougherty county from the first, second, and third Mondays in April and October to the Tuesdays after the first Mondays in April and October, continuing for two weeks; in Mitchell county from the third and fourth Mondays in March and the fourth Monday in November to the Tuesdays after the third Mondays in April and October; in Worth county from the fourth Mondays in April and October to the Tuesdays after the fourth Mondays in April and October, continuing each term for two weeks; in Decatur county from the second and third Mondays in May and November to the Tuesdays after the second Mondays in May and November, continuing each term for two weeks; in Baker county from the first Mondays in May and November to the Tuesdays after the fourth Mondays in May and November; in Calhoun county from the second Mondays in June and December to the Tuesdays after the second Mondays in June and December; in Miller county from the third Mondays in April and October to the fourth Mondays in April and October; so that after said January the first, 1899, said courts shall be held as follows: In Dougherty county on the Tuesdays after the first Mondays in April and October, in Mitchell county on the Tuesdays after the third Mondays in April and October, in Worth county on the Tuesdays after fourth Mondays in April and October, in Decatur county on the Tuesdays after the second Mondays in May and November, in Baker county on the Tuesdays after the fourth Mondays in May and November, in Calhoun county on the Tuesdays after the second Mondays in June and December, and in Miller county on the fourth Mondays in April and October. Superior Courts, terms of in Dougherty, Mitchell, Worth, Decatur, Baker, Calhoun and Miller.

SEC. II. Be it likewise enacted, That all petitions, bills, bonds, writs, summons, mesne and final processes issued from, returnable
to, or pending in said court, respectively, as the terms are now provided for, shall hold good and relate to the terms of said court, respectively, as changed, fixed, and provided for by this Act, and that all grand and traverse jurors who may be drawn and summoned to attend said court respectively as the terms are now provided by law, shall be required to attend the terms of said court, respectively, as charged, fixed, and provided for by this Act. Returns.
SEC. III. Be it likewise enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: SUPERIOR COURTS, TERMS OF IN COUNTIES OF DOOLY AND LEE.
law.fulltitle: An Act to fix a time of holding certain courts in the Southwestern judicial circuit, and for other purposes.
law.p: SECTION I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this act the superior court of the county of Dooly shall be held on the Fourth Monday in February and the first Monday in September of each year. The terms of said court to continue four weeks if in the judgment of the judge it should be necessary for the disposition of the business. Superior Courts, terms of in Dooly and Lee.

SEC. II. Be it further enacted, That from and after the passage of this act the time for holding the spring term of Lee's superior court be changed from the first Monday in March to the first Monday in May.

SEC. III. Be it further enacted, That all writs, processes, orders, summons, petitions, and all other proceedings returnable to said courts prior to the passage of this act, as well as subsequent to the passage of this act, shall be held and considered as returnable to the terms herein fixed and prescribed. Returns.
SEC. IV. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: SUPERIOR COURTS, TERMS OF IN COUNTY OF IRWIN.
law.fulltitle: An Act to change the time of holding the fall session of the superior court of Irwin county, to provide for a two-weeks term in the fall, and for other purposes.
law.p: SECTION I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this act the time of holding the fall term of the superior court of Irwin county shall be, and is hereby changed from the first Monday in November to the fourth Monday in October and the following Monday, so that said court shall be held on the fourth Monday in October and the following Monday, the fall terms to be for two weeks instead of one week. Irwin county, Superior Courts of.

SEC. II. Be it further enacted, That all business which is now pending in said court and is returnable to the November term, 1899, shall be returned by the clerk of said superior court to the October term, 1899, and business that shall hereafter originate in said court and that would have been returnable to the November term, 1899, shall be returnable to the October term, 1899, the said October term to stand in lieu of the said November term. Returns.
SEC. III. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA, INTEREST ON BONDS HELD BY.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to make permanent the income of the University of Georgia, and for other purposes, approved September 30th, 1881, by striking from the twelfth line of Section 1 the word seven and inserting in lieu thereof, the words three and one-half, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the Act entitled an Act to make permanent the income of the University of Georgia, and for other purposes, approved September 30th, 1881, be and the same is hereby amended by striking from the twelfth line of Section 1 the word seven and inserting in lieu thereof the words three and one-half, so that said Act, when so amended, shall read as follows: That from and after the passage of this Act, whenever the trustees of the University of Georgia shall, through their duly authorized agent or officer, present at the State Treasury for redemption any valid matured bond of this State as the property of such University, it shall be the duty
of the Governor to issue such trustees, in lieu of said matured bond so presented for payment, an obligation in writing in the nature of a bond, in amount equal to the principal of matured bond, and falling due fifty years from the date of such issue, the same to bear interest at the rate of three and one-half per cent. per annum, and not subject to be called in for redemption by the State before that time, nor to be negotiated or transferred by said trustees, said new bonds or obligations to be payable to the said trustees alone, and to be issued under the great seal of the State, and signed by the Governor and countersigned by the Secretary of State. The interest thereon to be paid semi-annually on the first days of January and July of each year, the terms prescribed by this Act for the issue of such obligations to be fully expressed in the body thereof, the amount of money necessary to pay the interest on such obligations being herein annually appropriated. University of Georgia. Redemption of bonds for.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA, SUMMER SESSIONS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the trustees of the State University to operate summer sessions, in graduate and post-graduate courses, for the benefit of white teachers of the State without regard to sex, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That the Board of Trustees of the Univesity of the State are hereby authorized to operate regular summer sessions of the University of Georgia, in graduate courses and work closely related thereto, including Psychology and the History and Philosophy of Education, for the special benefit of the white teachers of the State without regard to sex or age. University of Georgia, summer sessions.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: GEORGIA NORMAL COLLEGE, GRADUATES OF LICENSED TEACHERS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the graduates of the Normal Department of the Georgia Normal and Industrial College at Milledgeville, upon whom degrees may be conferred or diplomas have been or may be granted by the legally constituted authority of said College, to teach in the public schools of this State, without further examination, and that the diploma or such evidence of graduation, as aforesaid, shall entitle the holder thereof to a first grade license to teach in the public schools, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act all graduates of the Normal department of the Georgia Normal and Industrial College at Milledgeville, Georgia, and all those who may hereafter graduate therefrom, and upon whom degrees may be conferred by the Board of Directors of said institution, shall be, and are hereby authorized to teach in the public schools of this State without further examination. The diploma, or such other evidence of graduation as may be granted by said Board of Directors, shall entitle the holder thereof to a first grade license to teach in the public schools of this State, and said diploma shall be taken and held to be a first grade license to teach in the public schools of this State. Graduates of Normal schools licensed to teach.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, that all laws in conflict herewith be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: PUBLIC SCHOOLS, TEACHERS IN PAID MONTHLY.
law.fulltitle: An Act to provide for the payment of teachers in the public schools monthly, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the first day of January, 1899, the transfer of public schools funds to
the credit of each county, on the State Treasurer's books, shall be made on the first day of each month instead of on the 31st day of March, the 30th day of June, the 30th day of September, and the 31st day of December, as now provided; and the payment of said funds over to the several County School Commissioners (and the disbursement thereof by said County School Commissioners) shall be made monthly instead of quarterly, as is now provided by law; and the County Boards of Education shall be authorized to make their contracts in such a manner that the amounts payable to teachers for services rendered shall be due and payable monthly instead of quarterly. Payments to teachers in public schools.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the provisions of this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: PUBLIC SCHOOLS, TERMS OF HOW FIXED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to give the County Boards of Education of the several counties of this State full power and authority to define and regulate the length of the public school terms for their respective counties, and for other purposes.
law.p: SECTION I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, the several County Boards of Education of this State shall have full power and authority to define and regulate the length of the public school terms of their respective counties. School terms.
SEC. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.
