The Senate and House of Representatives of Georgia in General Assembly met, do enact, That the 2d clause of the caption of the Act approved August 22d, 1879, in the following langauge: To require the mayor and general council of said city, during the year eighteen hundred and ninty-six, and each year thereafter, until the whole of the public debt of the city is paid off, to set apart and appropriate for that purpose the sum of fifty thousand dollars; and section 2d of said Act, approved August 22d, 1879, in the following language: Be it further enacted, That during the year eighteen hundred and ninety-six, and each succeeding year, the mayor and general council of the city shall set apart and appropriate from the revenue of the city for each year, fifty thousand dollars, to be used wholly and exclusively for the purchase of and retirement of any bonds of the city that may be outstanding, until the whole of the public debt of the city is paid off, be, and the same are, hereby expressly repealed, such repeal to take effect on the 13th day of November, 1889, when the mayor and general council of the city of Atlanta were authorized to refund the whole bonded debt of said city by said Act of November 13th, 1889. Atlanta, bonded indebtedness refunded,

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That section 27 of said Act, establishing a new charter for the city of Atlanta, approved on the
28th day of February, 1874, be amended by adding at the close of said section the following words: and they shall have full power and authority to pass and enforce ordinances, providing for the punishment of persons selling spirituous, malt or other intoxicating liquors at wholesale or retail, within the corporate limits of said city, without having obtained licenses from said mayor and general council, or for selling such liquors after the expiration or revocation of such licenses, so that section, thus amended, will read as follows: Section 27. The said mayor and general council shall have power and authority to regulate the retail of ardent spirits within the corporate limits of said city, and at their discretion, to issue license to retail or to withhold the same, and to fix the price to be paid for license at any sum they may think proper, not exceeding two thousand dollars, and they shall have power and authority to pass and enforce ordinances providing for the punishment of persons selling spirituous, malt or other intoxicating liquors at wholesale or retail within the corporate limits of said city, without having obtained licenses from said mayor and general council, or for selling such liquors after the expiration or revocation of such licenses. Liquor, sale of in Atlanta.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That from and after the passage of this Act, deeds by the city of Atlanta, or its mayor, or its marshal, pursuant to tax sales or sales under execution, issued for the collection of local assessments, shall be admissible in evidence on the same terms as deeds made pursuant to sales for taxes due the State and county; provided, that it shall be competent for parties denying the validity of such tax deeds or assessment deeds to put in evidence the proceedings preliminary to the execution of such deeds. The purpose of this Act being to give city tax deeds, and city assessment deeds the same prima facie force and validity which is accorded to tax deeds made by the officers of the State and county. Deeds by city, force of.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and general council of the city of Atlanta shall have power and authority to provide by ordinance for the collection of assessments for the construction of sewers in installments, running through a series of years to be fixed by such ordinances in all cases where the construction of said sewers is performed by a contractor or contractors; provided, that said mayor and general council shall not have power and authority to incur indebtedness to be paid by the city from the treasury on account of the construction of such sewers, which indebtedness is not to be paid in the year in which it is contracted. Assessments for sewers, collection of.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and general council of the city of Atlanta shall have power and authority to fill, by election, any and all vacancies occurring in the ministerial offices of said city, required to be elected in the first instance by the qualified voters of said city. Vacancies in ministerial offices, how filled.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the first day of January, 1899, the members of the several administrative boards of the city of Atlanta, such as the board of police commissioners, the board of water commissioners, the board of health, the board of firemasters, the board of education, the Grant park commission, the trustees of the Grady hospital, and all similar administrative boards of the city government, shall serve without salaries, whether such members of any of said boards were elected before or after the passage of this Act. Members of administrative boards, no salaries for.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That from and after the passage of this Act, the books kept by the comptroller of the city of Atlanta shall be kept in such manner as to show in detail the receipts and expenditures of each department of the city government. Comptroller, books of, how kept.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and general council of the city of Atlanta are hereby authorized to issue and sell bonds of said city of Atlanta to the amount of $200,000.00, to run 30 years, and bearing interest at the rate of 4 per cent. per annum; the principal and interest of these bonds shall be payable in gold coin of the United States of America of the present standard of weight and fineness, or its equivalent, the interest to be evidenced by coupons, and paid semi-annually, the proceeds of which bonds shall be devoted exclusively to the laying of water mains within the city of Atlanta; provided, the qualified voters of said city assent by the requisite two-thirds majority to the issue of such bonds at an election to be held at any time in the year 1899 or 1900, when called by the mayor and general council of the city of Atlanta, in accordance with the general laws of the State regulating the holding of elections for the issue of county and municipal bonds; provided further, that a special registration of the qualified voters of said city shall be made for the bond election herein provided for, but no qualified voter of said city already registered as such voter for the same year in which the election is held, shall be left off the list of qualified voters for such bond election, except that the list of qualified voters for such bond election may be purged of the names of those who have died or have removed from the limits of the city after registering, and before the holding of such bond election. Bonds for $200,000 may be issued. Proviso.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in case of the issue of such bonds a special tax shall be levied for each year such bonds are to run sufficient in amount to raise the interest accruing on such bonds and one-thirteenth of the principal of such bonds, and the interest shall be paid semi-annually as aforesaid, and the money raised on account of the principal of such bonds shall be kept in a sinking-fund under the charge of the commissioners of the sinking-fund of the city of Atlanta, if a sinking-fund shall have been provided for by ordinance, until it can be applied to the payment of the bonds in whole or in part, at or before their maturity, and if no sinking-fund commission is provided, said sinking-fund shall be invested by the mayor and general council in their discretion. Tax for interest and sinking fund.

Sec. X. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no person, firm or corporation having a claim for money damages against the city of Atlanta, on account of injuries to person or property, shall bring any suit at law or in equity against the said city of Atlanta on such account without first presenting such claim to the mayor and general council of the city of Atlanta for adjustment, and no such suit shall be entertained by the courts against the city of Atlanta unless the cause of action therein has been first presented to the mayor and general council for adjustment; provided, that upon the presentation of such claim in any case to the mayor and general council, said mayor and general council shall consider and act upon the same, favorably or unfavorably to the petitioner within three months from the presentation thereof; provided further, that the action of the mayor and general council upon such claim, unless it results in the settlement thereof, shall, in no sense be a bar to the plaintiff's rights in such cases in the courts. Claims against city must be presented to Mayor and Council before sued.
Sec. XI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: AUGUSTA, PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO PAY DUES TO.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the city council of Augusta to impose a penalty for failure to pay taxes, assessments, fines, license fees, and any sums due for the use of water through the water pipes of said city within a fixed time.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the city council of Augusta shall be, and is hereby authorized to impose a penalty in the way of an additional per centum upon all taxes, assessments, fines, license fees, and any sums due for the use of water through the water pipes of said city, which may not be paid within the time fixed by the said city council. Augusta, penalty for failure to pay dues to
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts thereof in conflict with this be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: AUGUSTA, NORTHERN BOUNDARY OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to make the boundary line between the States of Georgia and South Carolina, along the entire river front of the city of Augusta, the northern boundary of said city.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the boundary line between the States of Georgia and South Carolina along the entire river front of the city of Augusta, shall be, and is hereby made the northern boundary of the said city of Augusta. Augusta, northern boundary of.
Sec. II. Be it further anacted, That all laws and parts thereof in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: AUGUSTA MAY ENFORCE COLLECTION OF DUES.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the city council of Augusta to enforce the collection of all taxes, assessments, fines, license fees, and any sums due for the use of water through the water pipes of said city, and all penalties and other sums that may be due the said city council, by execution.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That the city council of Augusta shall be, and is, hereby authorized to provide by ordinance for the enforcement of the collection of all taxes, assessments, fines, license fees, and any sums due for the use of water through the water pipes of said city, and all penalties, and other sums that may be due the said city council, by execution to be issued by such officer and under such terms and conditions, and with such provisions as have been or may be enacted by the said city council. Augusta, may enforce collection of dues.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That such executions shall be enforced and sale shall be made thereunder at such time, place and manner as now or hereafter may be provided by law for sheriffs' sales for State and county taxes. Sales for.
Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That all laws or parts thereof in conflict with this be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: AUGUSTA, COMMON SEAL, USE OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to provide that the city council of Augusta shall not be required to use its common seal in making and establishing by-laws, rules and ordinances, and to confirm all by-laws, rules and ordinances hitherto made and established without the use of such common seal, that are otherwise valid.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That it shall not be necessary hereafter for the city council of Augusta
to use its common seal in making and establishing any by-laws, rules, and ordinances. Augusta, common seal of.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all by-laws, rules and ordinances hitherto made and established by said the city council of Augusta without the use of its common seal, and that are otherwise valid, are hereby confirmed and validated. Former acts without seal validated.
Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts thereof, in conflict with this be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: AUGUSTA, QUORUM OF CITY COUNCIL.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the city council of Augusta to fix the number of its members necessary to constitute a quorum.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the city council of Augusta shall be, and is, hereby authorized to fix the number of its members necessary to constitute a quorum. Augusta, quorum of City Council.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts thereof in conflict with this be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: AUGUSTA MAY CHANGE DAM ACROSS SAVANNAH RIVER.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the city council of Augusta to change in whole or part, the location of the dam now extending across the Savannah river at the head of the Augusta canal; to construct a dam from any point on the Georgia side of said river or from any point of the present dam up the stream of said river; to raise the height of said dam; to condemn any property necessary for said purposes; and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted, by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the city council of Augusta is authorized and empowered to change in whole or in part the location of the dam now extending across the Savannah river at the head of the Augusta canal, in such manner
as will, in the discretion of said city council, best improve the condition and power of said canal; to construct a new dam or to alter the present dam; to construct a dam from any point on the Georgia side of said river, at or within one thousand yards of the point of beginning of the present dam or from any point of the present dam up the stream of said river along such lines, and extending to such limits, not exceeding four thousand yards from point of beginning of said dam, as to it seems best; to raise the height of said dam to such extent as is deemed necessary; to excavate and remove stone, dirt, or other materials; build such banks, tow-paths, sluices, waste-ways, gates, bridges, and any and all structures and appurtenances that may be necessary, and to do such other acts as may be necessary for the successful execution of the authority herein granted. Augusta may alter dam across Savannah river or build new dam.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That said city council is authorized to condemn all property necessary for the proper execution of the powers herein granted, the condemnation proceedings to be had under the provisions of the Code of Georgia of 1895, from sections 4657 to 4686, inclusive. May condemn property.
Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts thereof in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: AUGUSTA MAY CONVEY LAND FOR PASSENGER DEPOT.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the city council of Augusta to grant and convey so much of the south side of Walker street between Jackson (Eighth) and Campbell (Ninth), as may be necessary to construct a passenger depot.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That the city council of Augusta is hereby authorized to grant and convey so much of the south side of Walker street between Jackson (Eighth) and Campbell (Ninth) streets, as may be necessary to construct a passenger depot, such grant and conveyance to be made to such person or corporation on such terms and conditions, and for such time as the said city council may agree to; provided, that nothing
in this Act shall be construed into giving to any person or corporation the right to condemn any of said street. Augusta, land for passenger depot.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws or parts thereof in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: AUGUSTA, LAWS OF, PENALTIES FOR VIOLATING.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the city council of Augusta exclusively to fix within prescribed limits all fines and punishments for violation of any rules, by-laws, and ordinances established by said city council.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the city council of Augusta is authorized exclusively to fix all fines and punishments for violation of any rules, by-laws and ordinances established by said city council. Augusta, penalty for violating laws of.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted that said punishments may be by fines and imprisonment and labor on the public works of said city, or by fines or imprisonment or labor on the public works of said city, any or all; but such fines shall not exceed three hundred ($300.00) dollars and such improvement or labor on the public works shall not exceed ninety (90) days. Limits of fines.
Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts thereof in conflict with this be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: AUGUSTA, CHARTER AMENDED, STREET GRADES, ENCROACHMENTS, ETC.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the city of Augusta.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, the charter of the city of Augusta, originally granted in and by the Act entitled An Act to incorporate Augusta, and to improve the public roads in the neighborhood thereof, approved January 1st, 1798, be, and said charter of the city of Augusta is hereby amended by adding thereto the following powers, which are hereby granted to the city council of Augusta, to wit: The city council of Augusta may fix and determine the grade at, above and below, level, at which persons, firms, companies, corporations or railroads using the streets longitudinally or otherwise must use or cross said streets with their track or tracks, and may likewise fix the grade, stipulations and conditions on which spur-tracks leading to warehouses, industries and places of business, shall be laid. The city council of Augusta may widen the whole or any part of any street, or in its discretion, may order the same to be narrowed; and, in its discretion the said city council may require any street, or any part thereof, to be narrowed, or encroached upon, or closed up for passenger depot purposes, and may permit the part so closed or encroached upon to be occupied by buildings, offices, tracks, hack stands or otherwise in connection with said purposes, and upon such grades, terms, stipulations and agreements, and for such considerations as the city council may determine. When, in the opinion of the city council of Augusta, the whole, or any part of a street, has ceased to be of general utility or use as a street, the city council in its discretion, may permit platforms, gang-ways, tracks or other structures to be constructed upon such level, and with such width, height, length, and of such material as it may prescribe and approve, and on such terms and conditions as it may designate; or the city council of Augusta, in its discretion, may declare the same vacant and abandoned as a street, and donate the same to a use which, in their opinion, will be of advantage or utility to the commercial or business interests of the city, on such terms as the city council
may prescribe; provided, that in all the cases and circumstances mentioned in this Act, where, within the meaning of the constitution, private property is thereby taken, or damaged, the amount to be paid shall be assessed, collected and paid for as provided in sections 4657 to 4686 of the Civil Code. Augusta, charter amended. Grades of streets. Land for passenger depot. Encroachments on streets. Proviso.

Sec. II. Whereas, The suits of J. F. McGowan vs. Augusta Terminal Railway Company, and the church wardens of St. Paul's Church vs. Augusta Terminal Railway Company, are pending, involving the right to condemn a lot of land, build embankment, lay tracks, and operate cars and trains, at and around Bay and Washington streets, at a point opposite and abutting the property of St. Paul's Church in the city of Augusta; and Rights of J. F. McGowan and of St. Paul's Church not affected by this act.
Whereas, Neither the property nor the rights of them should be affected by this Act; and
Whereas; Said suits, and the rights of the parties to the land, street or easement, among themselves or as to others, should not in any way be lessened, increased, modified or changed by this Act;

Be it therefore enacted, That without the consent of the owner of said property, easement, franchises or rights, on terms respectively to be agreed upon, nothing in this Act shall be held to diminish or affect the rights of said J. F. McGowan, St. Paul's Church, or Augusta Terminal Railway Company, or to authorize condemnation of land, change of grade, building of embankments, and making of connection at Washington street; but the rights of each and all of said persons shall not in any way, or to any extent, or to any person, be affected by this Act, but said suits shall be determined by the law of force at the time the same were instituted, and the rights of each of said persons and corporations shall not be affected by the passage of this Act without their consent.
Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: AUGUSTA, CHARTER AMENDED, SEWERS, HOW CONSTRUCTED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to incorporate Augusta and to improve the public roads in the neighborhood thereof, approved January 31st, 1798, and the several Acts amendatory thereof, so as to authorize the city council of Augusta to construct drains and sewers, to provide a better system of drain and sewer assessments, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the city council of Augusta shall have full power and authority to construct or lay down drains and sewers along the streets, lanes and alleys of the city of Augusta, and through and over private property. All work of constructing or laying down drains or sewers shall be done under the direction and supervision of the board of health of Augusta. The commissioner of public works of said city shall furnish to said board estimates of the cost of the same, and shall furnish plans and profiles and such other like work as may be necessary and proper. In all cases where drains or sewers shall be constructed or laid down by or under the authority of said city council in any street, lane, or alley the sum of twenty-five (25) cents per lineal foot shall be assessed upon the property and estates respectively abutting on such drains or sewers on each side of said street, lane or alley in which said drains or sewers may be constructed or laid down; and in case any such drains or sewers are constructed or laid down; through or over any private property a like sum of twenty-five cents shall be assessed upon such property abutting upon each side of said drains or sewers for every lineal foot, making in all, fifty (50) cents for every lineal foot to be assessed upon such property through which said drains or sewers are constructed as aforesaid. In consideration of the payment of such assessments the owners of said properties or estates on each side of said drains or sewers, whether constructed or laid down in streets, lanes or alleys or through or over private property, shall have the right to connect their drains from said abutting property for the purpose of discharging sewerage into the said sewers, under such terms and conditions as the board of health of said city may provide, the extent and character, material used, and expense of such drains
and sewers constrcted and laid down, as well as the time and manner of constructing and laying down the same, shall be wholly in the discretion of the board of health and said city council. Such assessments shall be a lien upon the real estate against which they are assessed, from the passage of the ordinance providing for the construction and laying down of such drains and sewers; the city council shall have the authority to enforce the collection of the amount of such assessments in the same way as assessments for sidewalks are now authorized to be collected; provided, that the defendant shall have the right to file an affidavit denying that the whole or any part of the amount for which the execution issued is due, and stating what amount he admits to be due, which amount so admitted to be due shall be paid or collected before the affidavit is received, and the affidavit received for the balance; all such affidavits so received shall be returned to the superior court of Richmond county and there tried, and the issue determined as in cases of illegality, subject to all the pains and penalties provided in cases of illegality or delay. The remaining cost of all drains and sewers not thus assessed shall be paid by said city council out of the proper appropriation for the year. Augusta sewers, how laid. Assessments for. How collected.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That for the preservation and protection of all drains and sewers in the said city, the said board of health shall have the right to direct and control the time and manner in which the connections shall be made with such sewers and by whom the work is to be done, and upon what terms and conditions, and at what points, and to what extent surface water or drainage shall be permitted to flow into sewers, and generally relating to the use and control and repair of sewers and sewer connections. Said city council shall have full control over the replacing and paving of sidewalks and other structures in good condition. Connections, how nade.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That in the event it shall be necessary to construct and lay down any drain or sewer through private property, said city council shall have the right to condemn said private property for such use. Such condemnation proceedings to be had under sections 4657 to 4686, inclusive of the Civil Code of 1895 of the State of Georgia and the Acts amendatory thereof.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, That in case of real estate situated on a street corner and having frontage on two streets, the owner and real estate thus situated shall be assessed by this Act provided for the frontage on the street on which a sewer drain is
first laid, and when a sewer or drain is laid on the other street one hundred feet of frontage shall be exempt from assessment on the owner and real estate for the last named sewer. orner lots, ow ssessed.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That the construction of all sewers under this Act shall be provided for by ordinance, it being permissible to provide by a general ordinance for the terms, time and manner of construction and payment, and by special ordinances for each street the character, length, dimensions, material, and other details of the drains and sewers to be laid. No sewer shall be constructed until said board of health has recommended it and said city council has provided for its construction by ordinance. Construction of sewers, how provided for.
Sec. VI. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts thereof in conflict with this be, and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: AUGUSTA, TAX RETURNS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the city council of Augusta to affix a penalty for failure to make tax returns, and to provide for the enforcement of such penalty.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That the city council of Augusta shall be, and is, hereby authorized to compel any person or persons, natural or artificial, liable thereto under the ordinances of said city council to make tax returns. Said city council is authorized to affix a penalty for not making such returns, and to provide for the collection of the same by execution, or to provide a punishment for failure to make such tax returns in the recorder's court of Augusta. Augusta may require tax returns.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws or parts thereof in conflict with this be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: BREMEN, NEW CHARTER.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act entitled an Act to incorporate the town of Bremen, adopted September 5th, 1883, and to repeal all Acts amendatory of said Act, so as to repeal the charter of the town of Bremen, and to enact in lieu thereof a new charter for said town, defining the limits of said town, prescribing the powers and duties of the mayor and councilmen thereof; authorizing the levying and collecting the taxes and other dues to said town; providing penalties for illegal sale or furnishing intoxicants therein; and the manner of working and paving the streets and sidewalks of the same, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the Act entitled an Act to incorporate the town of Bremen, adopted September 5th, 1883, and all Acts amendatory thereof be, and the same are, hereby repealed, so that the charter of the town of Bremen, in the county of Haralson, be, and the same is, hereby repealed, and the following charter enacted in lieu thereof. Bremen, charter of 1883 repealed.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the municipal government of the town of Bremen, in the county of Haralson, shall consist of a mayor and four councilmen, who are hereby constituted a body corporate, under the name and style of the Town of Bremen, and by that name and style shall have perpetual succession, shall have a common seal, and be capable in law and equity of having, purchasing, holding, receiving, enjoying, possessing and retaining to them and their successors in office, for the use of the town of Bremen, any estate, or estates, real or personal, any and all kinds of property, whether real or personal, of whatever kind or nature, within or without the jurisdictional limits of said town for corporate; and shall by said name be capable of suing and being sued in any court of law or equity in this State, and shall succeed to all rights and liabilities of the corporation of the town of Bremen. New charter. Mayor and Councilmen, corporate name. Powers of.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the corporate limits of said town of Bremen shall extend seven hundred yards in every direction from where Buchanan street crosses the Southern railroad, in said town of Bremen, so as to make said corporate limits form a circle. Corporate limits.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That an election shall be held in the town of Bremen, Saturday after the first Monday in January, 1900, and on Saturday after the first Monday in January in each and every year thereafter, for the election of a mayor and four councilmen for said town of Bremen. Each of said officers shall serve for one year and until their successors are elected and qualified, at the first meeting of the mayor and councilmen of the town of Bremen, or so soon thereafter as practicable; one of said councilmen shall be chosen as mayor pro tem. Election of officers. Terms of.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesad, That in case of vacancy in any of the offices mentioned in the preceding section, by death, resignation, failure to elect, removal from office, removal from the town, or otherwise, a special election shall be ordered by the mayor and councilmen within thirty days, giving ten days' notice by publication to fill such vacancy. Vacancies, how filled.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all elections held under the provisions of this charter shall be superintended and managed by a justice of the peace, or some other judicial officer, and two freeholders, or three freeholders, all of whom shall be citizens of said town; and each of said managers, before entering on his duties, shall take, before some justice of the peace, or some other officer duly qualified to administer an oath, the following oath, to wit: I do solemnly swear that I will faithfully and impartially conduct this day's election, held for mayor and councilmen for the town of Bremen, and that I will not knowingly prevent any person from voting who is qualified to vote in this election, nor will I knowingly allow any person to vote who is disqualified. And said managers shall cause to be kept two lists of voters, and two tally-sheets of said election, and the polls at every such election shall be opened at nine o'clock a. m. and closed at four o'clock p. m. Elections, how held. Oath of managers.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That after the votes at any election shall have been counted by the managers, they shall certify two lists of voters and two tally-sheets, and shall place said lists of voters and said tally-sheets with the ballots, in the ballot-box, and shall seal said ballot-box and deposit the same with the ordinary of said county; the managers shall also certify to the person receiving the highest number of votes in said election for mayor, and to the four persons receiving the highest number of votes for councilmen, that they were duly elected to such offices, which certificates shall authorize the persons hereinafter mentioned to administer the oath of office to said mayor and councilmen. List of voters. Certificate of election.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That as soon as the mayor and board of councilmen of said town of Bremen shall have been elected, or as soon thereafter as practicable, the persons elected shall meet and take and subscribe the following oath before any justice of the peace of this State, any ordinary, clerk of the superior court, notary public, or the former mayor of the town, and shall forthwith enter upon the duties of their offices, to wit: I (A B) do solemnly swear that I will well and truly perform the duties of mayor (or councilman, as the case may be) of the town of Bremen, to the best of my skill and ability, without favor or affection, so help me God. Oath of officers.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no person shall be eligible to the position of mayor or councilman unless he is over the age of twenty-one years, a citizen of the United States and of Georgia, and shall have resided in the town of Bremen at least one year before his election. Qualifications of.

Sec. X. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor shall be the chief executive officer of the town of Bremen. He shall see that all laws, ordinances, resolutions and rules of the town are faithfully executed and enforced, and that all officers of the town shall faithfully discharge the duties required of them. He shall have general jurisdiction of the officers of the town. He shall preside at all meetings of the mayor and board of councilmen of the town of Bremen, and shall have the right to vote in all elections and on all questions coming before said board whenever there is a tie in such elections or question, but shall not have the right to vote on any question unless there is a tie on such question; and the said mayor shall have the right to veto any law or ordinance, resolution or other Act done by said board of councilmen, but his veto may be overruled whenever three members of said board vote to overrule the same; provided, that whenever the mayor is absent from any meeting the mayor pro tem. or some councilman may preside. Mayor, duties and powers of.

Sec. XI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That there shall be a mayor's court for the trial of offenses and offenders against the laws and ordinances of the town, which court shall be held by the mayor, and in his absence, or disqualification, by the mayor pro tem. Said court shall have the power to preserve order, to compel the attendance of witnesses, to punish for contempt by imprisonment not exceeding two days, or by fine not exceeding ten ($10.00) dollars, or both; and said mayor shall also have the power, on conviction of any person of the violation of any of the ordinances or laws of the town of Bremen, to sentence
such persons to labor upon the streets or public works of said town not to exceed sixty days, or to impose a fine not to exceed one hundred ($100.00) dollars, either or all of said sentence, in his discretion. Mayor's court. Powers of.

Sec. XII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor shall have authority and power to issue warrants against any person violating any of the laws of this state within the corporate limits of the town of Bremen, and shall have full power and authority to commit the offenders to jail, or to bail them (if the offense is bailable) to appear before the court having jurisdiction, and if, while trying any person charged with the violation of any ordinance or law of the town of Bremen, it shall be made to appear that such person has violated the criminal laws of this state, said mayor shall have the power to commit such person to jail, or to bail him, if the offense is bailable, to appear before the court having jurisdiction thereof. May commit.

Sec. XIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and councilmen of the town of Bremen shall have the right to elect the clerk of said board, and also a treasurer for the town of Bremen, which clerk and treasurer may or may not be selected from the board of councilmen, at the discretion of said board, and the said board shall also elect a marshal or marshals for said town, and to fix the compensation for the same; to require bond and security for the faithful discharge of their duties; provided, that the compensation of the clerk shall in no case exceed the sum of thirty ($30.00) dollars per annum, nor shall the compensation of the treasurer exceed the sum of twenty ($20.00) dollars per annum, and the compensation of the marshal shall in no case exceed the sum of three hundred ($300.00) dollars per annum, unless it becomes necessary to have more than one marshal, and in that event the compensation for all the marshals of the town shall not in the aggregate exceed six hundred ($600.00) dollars per annum. Clerk. Treasurer. Marshal.

Sec. XIV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that for the purposes of raising revenue for the support and maintenance of the town of Bremen, the mayor and councilmen of said town are hereby authorized to prescribe by ordinance for the assessment, levy and collection of an ad valorem tax on all real and personal property within the corporate limits of said town, to defray the ordinary annual expenses of said town, said tax not to exceed one-half of one per cent. Ad valorem tax.

Sec. XV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and councilmen of the town of Bremen shall
have power and authority to license, regulate and control all taverns, restaurants, livery-stables, hacks, drays and other vehicles, auctioneers, venders, masters, itinerant traders, theatrical performances, circuses and exhibitions of all kinds; itinerant lightning-rod peddlers, immigrant agents, clock peddlers, peddlers of all kinds, itinerant dealers in jewelry, and all other traveling or itinerant venders of articles, goods, wares and merchandise of every nature whatsoever; every keeper of billiard, pool, or bagatelle tables for public use; every keeper of shooting-gallery, tenpin alley, and upon the keeper of any table, stand or place; all game or games, whether played with stills, or balls, rings or other contrivances; upon the keeper of flying-horses, bicycles or velocipedes, or skating-rinks; keepers of slaughter-houses, beefmarkets, green-groceries; dealers in fish, or oysters, vegetables, fruits, bread, or other articles of food; and all other establishments, business or calling, or avocation; and to impose such license and special tax on any and all of said trades, professions, games, shows, agents, peddlers, or avocations, as in their discretion, they may see proper; except such professions, trades, and avocations as are specially exempt from taxation by municipal authorities under the general law of this State. Special taxes.

Sec. XVI. Be it further enacted by the authority [Illegible Text] That said mayor and councilmen of the town of Bremen shall have the power to compel all persons who are subject to road duty under the general laws of this State, to work on the public streets of the town of Bremen not exceeding fifteen days, or to pay in lieu thereof a commutation tax not to exceed ten ($10.00) dollars; and shall have power to summon such persons to perform such work under such rules and regulations as they may adopt; and on failure of any person to appear and work, as required by the ordinances, to impose such fines as may be reasonable and just, for contempt, or may, for such contempt, imprison such persons or work them on the streets of the town of Bremen not exceeding sixty days; or impose a fine, not exceeding one hundred ($100.00) dollars, or either, at the discretion of the said mayor and councilmen. Street tax.

Sec. XVII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said mayor and councilmen of the town of Bremen shall have power and authority to appoint three freeholders, residents of said town, as a board of assessors of tax returns, whose duty it shall be to scrutinize carefully each return of property, real and personal, made by every taxpayer of said town, and if, in their judgment, they shall find the property embraced in said return, or any portion thereof, returned below its value, they shall assess its
true value; and said board of tax assessors may also assess the value of all property in said town not returned for taxation. Tax assessors

Sec. XVIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and councilmen of the town of Bremen shall have full and complete control of the streets, alleys, sidewalks, parks and squares in said town, and shall have power and authority to open, lay out, widen, straighten, or otherwise change all streets, sidewalks, alleys, parks and squares of said town of Bremen; and also the right to condemn private property for the public uses aforesaid, and to prescribe such rules and regulations for the assessment of damages as they may see proper, which are not in conflict with the laws of this State. Streets, etc.

Sec. XIX. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That the mayor and councilmen of the town of Bremen have power to remove any forge, or smith-shop, where, in its operation, it may be necessary to insure safety against fire; it shall have power to remove stove-pipes, or other things which shall endanger the town as to fire; and shall also have power and anthority to abate all nuisances within the corporate limits of said town; and in case any nuisances are erected in said town they may abate the same at the expense of the owner or person erecting said nuisance, and shall have power to issue instanter execution against such person erecting the same. Protection against fire. Nuisances.

Sec. XX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said mayor and councilmen of the town of Bremen shall have power to establish and regulate markets; to prescribe the time of holding the same; to prevent injury or annoyance to the public, or individuals, of anything dangerous, offensive, or unwholesome; to prevent hogs, cattle, horses and sheep, dogs or other animals and fowls of every kind going at large in said town; to protect places of divine worship in and about the premises where held; to abate, or cause to be abated, anything that shall become a nuisance; to provide in and near said town places for the burial of the dead, and to regulate interments therein; to provide for the proper drainage of lots by proper drains and ditches; to provide for the paving and macadamizing of the streets and sidewalks of said town; and to assess a tax upon adjoining property holders for the payment of all macadamizing and paving, under such rules and regulations as they may prescribe; to protect the property and persons of the citizens of said town; preserve peace and good order therein, and, for this purpose, to appoint, when necessary, a police force to assist the marshal in the discharge of his duties; to prescribe the duties and powers of the officers appointed by the
mayor and councilmen of the town of Bremen; to fix their term of service and compensation; require and take from them bonds, when deemed necessary, payable to the mayor and councilmen of the town of Bremen, or their successors in office, with such sureties and in such penalties as said mayor and councilmen may see fit, for the faithful discharge of their duties; and provide a revenue for said town, and to appropriate the same to the expenses; to organize a chain-gang, or work-gang, to work upon the streets of said town, and for sanitary purposes. Markets. Stock. Places of divine worship. Cemetery. Drainage. Pavements Police. Chaingang.

Sec. XXI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and councilmen of the town of Bremen shall have power and authority to enforce by execution the collection of any amount due, or to become due, to it for taxes, license, fees and tax assessments of every kind; for fines and forfeitures; for any other debt or demand due the town, such execution to be issued by the clerk, to be issued in the name of the mayor of the town of Bremen against the person, or corporation, or firm, owing said sum, and which execution may be levied by the marshal on the property of the owner against whom such execution shall issue; and all property levied on by virtue of any execution, whether real or personal, shall be sold before the justices court-house door in said town of Bremen, by the marshal of said town; all real estate so levied shall be advertised in a newspaper published in the town of Bremen, if there be one, and if not, in the paper in which the sheriff's advertisements in said county are published, once a week for four consecutive weeks prior to said sale, and after having given the property owners the same notice of levy as is required of the sheriff when he makes a levy upon real estate, and to authorize the marshal, as aforesaid, to execute deeds to the purchaser of said real estate at his sales as aforesaid; provided, that all sales of personal property levied on by the marshal shall take place at the court-house door of said town, after advertising the same for ten days at three or more places in the town of Bremen; and all such sales, of both real and personal property, shall take place on the first Tuesday in each month, within the present legal hours of sale. Collection of dues.

Sec. XXII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no person who may be convicted before the Mayor's Court shall have the right to appeal to the board of councilmen, but such person, by giving notice of intention to certiorari, may suspend the judgment and may be released from custody upon giving bond, with security, in such sum as may be fixed by the mayor, for his appearance; and provided, that certiorari proceedings from the
said court shall be sued out within thirty days from the date of the judgement; and provided, that no certiorari shall issue until all costs have been paid, or an affidavit made by the defendant, showing his inability to pay cost. Certiorari from Mayor's Court.

Sec. XXIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and councilmen of the town of Bremen shall have full power and authority to establish police rules and regulations, to pass all laws and ordinances, not in conflict with the constitution and laws of the State of Georgia, which tend to promote the safety, health, good order, morality and general welfare of the inhabitants of said town. Police regulations

Sec. XXIV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and councilmen of the town of Bremen shall be paid such compensation for their services as may be fixed by the ordinance of said town, not exceeding fifty ($50.00) dollars per annum for the mayor, and not exceeding twenty-five ($25.00) dollars each per annum for councilmen; and that the fees provided for in this section shall not be changed or altered but one time in each year; and that each succeeding mayor and council fix by ordinance their own fees. Salaries of mayor and councilmen.

Sec. XXV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the sale of malt or spirituous liquors be, and the same are, hereby prohibited within the corporate limits of the town of Bremen, and the corporate authorities shall have the right to inflict punishment on all persons keeping such liquors within the corporate limits of said town for the purpose of illegal sale or furnishing. Liquor, sale of prohibited.

Sec. XXVI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the present mayor and councilmen of the town of Bremen shall have all the power and authority of mayor and councilmen of the town of Bremen until the election of mayor and councilmen to be held on Saturday after the first Monday in January, 1900.

Sec. XXVII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That this charter take effect January the 31st, 1899, and that act repealing the old charter of Bremen be not effective until this charter is of force and effect. Old and new charter

Sec. XXVIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and councilmen of said town shall have authority to require all owners of real estate to provide, repair, and keep in proper condition all sidewalks on, running by, or abutting said real estate, and on failure of said owner of such real estate to provide and keep in repair such sidewalks so required, the mayor and councilmen may have said sidewalks provided and improved, and shall
have the authority to collect the expenses thereof from said owner as provided in section twenty-one of this charter; provided, however, before the mayor and councilmen shall proceed to do said work they shall give the property owners ten days' notice to do said work themselves. Owners of real estate.

Sec. XXIX. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and councilmen shall have power to prevent the riding or driving of horses or other animals at an improper speed; prevent the flying of kites, throwing of stones, balls or other objects and things, or engaging in any employment or sport in the town of Bremen dangerous or annoying to citizens or other persons, or their property, and to prohibit the abuses of animals or breaking or training the same in the streets of said town. They shall further have the power to regulate the use of firearms and fireworks within the limits of said town, and to prevent the discharging or firing of the same, as they may deem best. Police powers.
Sec. XXX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: BRUNSWICK, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the city of Brunswick, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That subdivision D of section fourteen of an Act amending the charter of the city of Brunswick, approved November 12, 1889, be amended by striking the words and a fee of one dollar for levy, one dollar for selling, and five per cent. commission on the amount realized at the same, and one dollar for signing the deed, shall be paid the marshal for his costs in that behalf; and the clerk shall receive fifty cents for each execution issued, and inserting in lieu thereof the following, and a fee of fifty cents for levy, five per cent. commission on the amount realized at the sale, fifty cents for signing the deed, and fifty cents for each execution issued shall be paid as
costs, and all such costs shall be turned into the treasury of said city, so that when amended said subdivision D of said section fourteen shall read as follows: D. That all sales herein provided for in this Act shall take place on a regular sheriff's sale day, between the regular hours of sheriff's sales provided for in this State; and on the day of sales herein provided for, it shall be the duty of the marshal to offer the property levied, the same being realty, first for rent for one year; and if any amount is not offered sufficient to pay the taxes and costs, then for rent for five years, then for ten years, then for twenty years; and if he receives no such sufficient bid, then to offer for sale one-fourth undivided interest; and if he then receives no bid sufficient, as aforesaid, he shall then offer one-half; and if still no bid, then three-fourths; and if still no bid, then the whole for sale, and shall knock it off to the highest bidder, after crying the same according to the laws of the land; and that the amount to be charged for advertising the sale of such property shall be the same as now prescribed by the general laws of this State, and a fee of fifty cents for levy, five per cent. commission on the amount realized at the sale, fifty cents for signing the deed and fifty cents for each execution issued, shall be paid as costs; and all such costs shall be turned into the treasury of said city. Brunswick. sales for taxes.

Sec. II. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of same, That subdivision A of the fourteenth section of an Act amending the charter of the city of Brunswick, Georgia, be amended as follows:
1st. By inserting between the words real and property in the 5th line, the words and personal.
2d. By inserting the words and personal property between the words estate, and in in the 19th line.
3d. By inserting the word real between the words the and property in the 24th line.

4th. By inserting after the word thereof in the 26th line, the following, and they may describe and assess the personal property therein in a solid lump as personal property of such and such value; or by items or by classification with reference to the general character of the specifics in which the property may consist, or otherwise in their discretion.

5th. By striking out all of said paragraph or subdivision A of said section fourteen of the said word thereof in the said twenty-sixth line; so that said subdivision or paragraph A of said section, when so amended, shall read as follows:

A. That there shall be three assessors appointed as hereinafter,
whose duty it shall be to assess all real and personal property in said city, at a true and fair valuation; and they shall be appointed by said mayor and aldermen as follows: At the first appointment of assessors, which shall take place under this Act, at the first regular meeting of said mayor and council after the organization of the next board, in January next, they shall be appointed, one for one year, one for two years and one for three years, and ever there-after one assessor shall be elected and qualified annually, and shall hold his office for the term of three years, and until his successor is elected and qualified, except when an appointment is made to fill a vacancy, and shall take the following oath: I, , do solemnly swear that I will faithfully perform the duties of assessor for the city of Brunswick, and will make a true and just valuation of all property assessed. And it shall be the duty of the assessor to assess and value annually all real estate and personal property in said city liable for taxation, at a true and just valuation, and to enter their assessment of the same in a book to be kept for that purpose, and return the same to the mayor and aldermen of said city, and file it with the clerk of council of said city on or before the first day of March of each and every year; in which return they shall describe the real property assessed by number, notes and bounds, or other sufficient description, so as to give a sufficient identification thereof, and they may describe and assess the personal property therein in a solid lump, as personal property of such and such value, or by items, or by classification, with reference to the general character of the specifics in which the property may consist, or otherwise, in their discretion. Tax assessors. Oath of. Duties of.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said subdivision or paragraph F of the said section fourteen of the said Act be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking out the words shall be made within ten days and between the words matter and shall near the end of said subdivision F.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That paragraph or subdivision G of said section fourteen be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking out the word personal between the words owning and property in the second line of said subdivision G, and by adding to said subdivision the following proviso: provided, that any person making return of real property, at any time in the future, may at the time of making such return, with the consent of said mayor and council, direct in writing that his return, as to the parcels of real estate included therein, shall stand and be his return of the same for every year thereafter, and until he shall alter such, his return, by
adding other parcels thereto, or striking therefrom some of the parcels included in same. And it shall be the duty of persons transferring or acquiring real property, after the same has been so returned, to notify the clerk of council, in writing, of the fact of such transfer and the names of the transferrer and transferee, before the first day of April following such transfer, and in case a transfer of real property shall not be so notified to the clerk, then the same may be taxed as the property of the person last returning the same and shall be subject in like manner as if no transfer had been made, so that said subdivision G of said section, when so amended, will read as follows:

G. That all persons claiming or owning property of every or any nature and sort, in the limits of said city, or who is engaged in any sort of business, shall, on or before the first day of May of each and every year, make such a return of the same to the clerk of said council for taxation, together with the value of the same, under oath, as may be prescribed by ordinance of said mayor and council; provided, that any person making return of real property, at any time in the future, may at the time of making such return, with the consent of said mayor and council, direct, in writing, that his return, as to the parcels of real estate included therein, shall stand and be his return of the same for every year thereafter, and until he shall alter such, his return, by adding other parcels thereto, or striking therefrom some of the parcels included in the same. And it shall be the duty of persons transferring or acquiring real property, after the same has been so returned, to notify the clerk of council, in writing, of the fact of such transfer and the names of the transferrer and the transferee, before the first day of April following such transfer, and in case transfer of real property shall not be so notified to the clerk, then the same may be taxed as the property of the person last returning the same and shall be subject in like manner as if no transfer had been made. Tax returns. On property transferred.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said assessors shall have the same power to hear evidence and subp[oelig]na witnesses, and compel the witnesses when subp[oelig]naed to appear and testify and to punish for contempt, as is given by law to the police court of said city. Assessors, authority of

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no person shall be eligible to hold more than one office of emolument or trust under said city of Brunswick at the same time; provided, that the mayor of said city shall be, by virtue of his office as mayor, a member of the Board of Education. Office, same person can hold only one.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That
all persons liable to street or road work duty in the said city, who shall not present themselves with proper tools and implements to the superintendent of public works of said city by the first day of July of every year to work and serve out such duty, shall, without any notice or summons therefor, become and be liable to said mayor and council for the commutation tax now or hereafter to be allowed by law, to be collected as other taxes due said city; provided, that the foregoing provision shall not take away from the police of said city jurisdiction of cases against persons who fail or refuse when summoned so to do, to appear and work the streets and roads of said city. Road work. Commutation tax.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and council of said city shall have, and it is hereby given, full and ample authority by and under appropriate resolutions, ordinances, penalties, rules and regulations, to carry out and enforce the purposes of this enactment and punish violations of the same. Powers of mayor and council.
Sec. IX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: CAMAK INCORPORATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to incorporate the town of Camak in the county of Warren, in the State of Georgia, to define the corporate limits of said town, to provide for the election of a mayor and aldermen, and other town officers for the government thereof, to enact all necessary ordinances, and to provide penalties for the violation of the same; to regulate the sale of merchandise, and other commodities; to construct and maintain a system of sewerage; to regulate fire, sanitary and police protection; to raise revenue by taxation and specific license or otherwise, to defray expenses of the town government, to grant franchises as may be deemed necessary to provide for the laying out of streets, alleys, sidewalks, drives and other public grounds and maintaining the same, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That the town of Camak in the county of Warren be, and the same is, hereby incorporated as a town under the name of the town of Camak. The corporate powers of said town shall be vested in a mayor and five aldermen, and by the name of mayor and council of the town of Camak they may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and exercise all the corporate powers that may be necessary in performing their duties. Camak, town of incorporated. Mayor and council.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority of the same, That the corporate limits of said town shall extend one-half of a mile in each and every direction from the Georgia Railroad depot at Camak. Corporate limits.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That A. W. Mershon be, and he is, hereby appointed mayor, and J. C. Johnson, J. A. Chapman, S. W. Ivey, J. B. Rogers, R. D. Mayes, be, and they are, hereby appointed aldermen of said town of Camak, to hold their office until the first annual election as hereinafter provided. First mayor and council.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That on the second Monday in January, 1899, and each year thereafter on the same day, an election shall be held in the council chamber in said town for a mayor and five aldermen, who shall hold their office for one year, and until their successors are elected and qualified; but none shall vote or be eligible to the office of mayor or aldermen thereof, and who is not qualified to vote for members of the General Assembly of this State and have not resided in the town for six months. Said election shall be held and conducted in the same manner as elections for officers in the State, and the certificate of the managers shall be sufficient authority to the persons elected to enter in the discharge of the duties of the office to which they have been elected. In the event that the office of mayor or any member of the board of aldermen shall become vacant by death, resignation, removal or other cause, the mayor, or, in case his seat is vacant, the majority of the aldermen, shall order a new election, notice of which shall be given at least twenty days before said election is held, the same to be conducted as provided in this Act. Mayor and council, elections for.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That before entering on the discharge of their duties, the mayor and alderman shall subscribe to the following oath, which may be administered by any person authorized by the laws of this State to administer oaths: I do solemnly swear that I will faithfully discharge all the duties devolving on me as mayor or aldermen as the
case may be, of the town of Camak, Warren county, according to the best of my ability and understanding, so help me God. Oath of mayor and aldermen.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and aldermen shall have power and authority to pass all laws and ordinances that they may deem necessary for the government of said town and the protection of property from loss by fire or damage therein; provided, that they be not repugnant to the constitution and laws of the State and the United States. Powers of.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted, That the said mayor and aldermen shall have the power to levy and collect a tax not exceeding one half of one per cent. upon all property, both real and personal, within the corporate limits of said town, and the same may be enforced by execution issued by the clerk in the name of the mayor and by sale of property, as in sales of property liable to state and county taxes; all levies of tax executions to be made by the marshal or his deputy, and to be conducted as sales by the sheriffs of this State in case of levy of tax executions. They shall also have power to require all persons within said corporation who are subject to road duty under the laws of this State to work on the streets of said town, or they may prescribe a commutation tax which may be paid in lieu of work upon the streets, and they shall have the power to lay out streets, build sidewalks and regulate the drainage of the town so as to insure good sanitary conditions. Tax. Streets, how worked.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted, That the mayor of said town, and in his absence the mayor pro tem. (who shall be elected by the aldermen from their own number), shall be the chief executive officer of said town; he shall see that the ordinances, by-laws, rules and orders of the aldermen are faithfully executed; he shall have control of the police of said town, and may appoint special police whenever he may deem it necessary, and it shall be his duty especially to see that the peace and good order of the town are preserved, and that persons and property therein are protected, and to this end he may cause the arrest and detention of all riotous and disorderly persons in said town; he shall have power to issue executions for all fines, penalties and costs imposed by him, or he may require the immediate payment thereof, and in default of immediate payment he may imprison the offender in the guard house of said town, or by work on the streets of said town, not to exceed thirty days. Mayor, duty and authority of. Police.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council, at the first meeting after their election (or at the meeting after the first, if they deem proper and best), shall elect a clerk, treasurer and marshal, who may be one of their own numbers or any citizen
of said town. From all of these officers a bond shall be taken in such sums as the council may require, to be approved by the mayor, conditioned for the faithful performance of their duties. They shall also take and subscribe an oath before said mayor that they, and each of them, will well and faithfully discharge their several duties as clerk, treasurer and marshal, as the case may be, to the best of their ability. Clerk. Treasurer. Marshal. Bonds of. Oath of.

Sec. X. Be it further enacted, That the clerk, treasurer and marshal receive such annual salaries as the council may deem just and proper; the mayor and aldermen shall not receive any salaries, but shall be exempt from street tax during the continuance of their official term. Salaries of.

Sec. XI. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and aldermen shall have power and authority to tax all shows, auctioneers, sleight of hand performances, gift enterprises, pool and billiard tables, wheels of fortune and other like enterprises as they may deem most to the interest of said town. Specific taxes.

Sec. XII. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council shall have the power to regulate and control the sale of fresh meat and fresh fish within the limits of said town, and to impose a tax upon any person dealing in the same. Markets.
Sec. XIII. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: CEDARTOWN, CORPORATE NAME AND POWERS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend, consolidate and supersede the several Acts incorporating the city of Cedartown in the county of Polk, to confer additional powers upon the corporate authorities thereof and otherwise to amend the charter of said city; to provide a new charter for the same, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the municipal government of the city of Cedartown, in the county of Polk, shall consist of a mayor, clerk and
five aldermen who are hereby constituted a body corporate under the name and style of the City of Cedartown, the corporate powers of which shall be exercised by the mayor, clerk and aldermen hereinafter provided for. Cedartown, governm'nt and corporate name.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That an election shall be held in the city of Cedartown on the third Wednesday in December, annually. In December, 1898, a mayor, clerk and five aldermen shall be elected; the term of the mayor and two aldermen to expire on the first Tuesday in January, 1900, the term of the clerk and three aldermen to expire the first Tuesday in January, 1901; the aldermen to determine by lot who will fill long and who short terms. In December, 1899, and every two years thereafter, a mayor and two aldermen shall be elected, and in December, 1900, and every two years thereafter, a clerk and three aldermen shall be elected. Each of said officers shall serve until their successors are elected and qualified. No mayor, alderman or clerk hereafter elected shall be eligible to succeed himself. That J. H. Sanders be, and he is, hereby appointed mayor; J. C. Knight be, and he is, hereby appointed clerk; and J. B. Lacy, B. F. Lowther, J. O. Crabb, T. H. Adams and C. C. Bunn be, and are, hereby appointed aldermen of said city of Cedartown, to hold their office until the first Tuesday night in February, 1899, or until their successors are elected and qualified, as hereinbefore provided. At the first meeting of the mayor and council of Cedartown, or as soon thereafter as practicable, one of said aldermen shall be chosen mayor pro tem. and one to be chosen treasurer. Elections for mayor, clerk and aldermen. One term. Appointments.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That in case of a vacancy in any of the offices mentioned in the preceding section, by death, resignation, failure to elect, removal from office, removal from the city, or otherwise, a special election shall be ordered by the mayor and council of Cedartown, within thirty days, giving ten days' notice by publication, to fill such vacancy; provided, if such vacancy shall occur within three months of the expiration of the term of office of such officer, it shall be the duty of the mayor and council of Cedartown, or, in case of a vacancy in the office of mayor, the council to fill said vacancy by selecting a qualified citizen or citizens of said city to fill said vacancy for the unexpired term. That a vacancy in the council shall be filled from that ward in which it occurs. Vacancies, how filled.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, That all elections held under the provisions of this charter shall be superintended and managed by five freeholders, one from each ward, citizens of said city, and there shall be five clerks, one from each ward, and five boxes, one
for each ward, and the votes of each ward shall be put in said ward's box, and the voters of each ward shall vote for the mayor and clerk from the city at large, and for the aldermen from their respective wards only, said managers and clerks to be appointed by the mayor and council; said managers shall cause to be kept five tally-sheets and five lists of voters, keeping the votes for aldermen of each ward separate. Before entering upon his duties, each manager shall take oath before some officer qualified to administer an oath, that he will impartially conduct said election and prevent all illegal voting to the best of his skill and power. Election managers. Oath of.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That all elections held under this charter shall be held at the court-house in said city or at such other place or places as the mayor and council may direct, and the polls at every such election shall be opened at 8 o'clock a. m., and closed at 5 o'clock p. m. The person or persons receiving the highest number of votes cast at such election for alderman, mayor or clerk respectively shall be declared elected. Elections, where held.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted, That after the votes at any election shall have been counted by the managers, they shall certify the lists of voters and the tally-sheets and shall place one of said tally-sheets with the ballots in the ballot box or boxes and shall seal said ballot box or boxes and deposit the same with the clerk of the Superior Court and the other list of voters and tally-sheets shall be filed by the managers with the city clerk. The said clerk of the Superior Court, after the expiration of sixty days, shall destroy the contents of said ballot box or boxes without examining said ballots or allowing the same to be done; provided, no notice of contest shall be filed or pending. That all contests shall be heard and determined by the mayor and council. Notice must be served and filed within five days from the date of the election and determined in twenty days from said date. List of voters certified. Contested elections.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted, That on the first Tuesday in February after the first election, and on the first Tuesday in January after each other election, or as soon thereafter as practicable, persons elected shall appear at the council chamber and take and subscribe the following oath, before any judicial officer of this state, and shall forthwith enter upon the duties of his office, to wit: I, A B, do solemnly swear that I will well and truly perform the duties of mayor (alderman or clerk, as the case may be) of the city of Cedartown, to the best of my skill and ability, without favor or affection; so help me God. Oath.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted, That all persons qualified to vote for members of the Legislature, and who shall have paid all
taxes legally imposed and demanded by the authorities of the city, and shall have resided three months within the city prior to the opening of the registration list and registers as hereinafter provided for, shall be qualified to vote at said election for mayor and clerk and for alderman when he has resided in his ward three days preceding the election. Qualified voters.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted, That the clerk shall open a list for the registration of voters on the first Saturday in November in each year, which list shall be kept open from 9 o'clock a. m. until 12 m., and from 2 o'clock until 6 o'clock p. m., each and every day, Sundays excepted, until the first Saturday in December, when it shall be finally and absolutely closed, on which book shall be kept a separate list of each ward and also a separate list of white and colored voters, in which book shall be subscribed the names of the persons entitled to vote in said city, his age, place of residence and occupation. Said clerk must not permit any one to register who is not entitled to do so, and if he does so knowingly, he shall be discharged from office. No person who is not registered shall be allowed to vote at any regular election in said city. The mayor and council may prescribe such rules and regulations with reference to registering, as they may see fit and proper, not in conflict herewith. Registratration of voters.

Sec. X. Be it further enacted, That it shall be the duty of the clerk to furnish to the managers presiding at any such election at the opening of the polls on the day of such election, a complete list of all names, arranged alphabetically, which shall be registered according to the foregoing provisions, certified under the hand of said clerk, and the corporate seal of the city, which list shall be kept before the presiding managers during such election, and when such election is over it shall be deposited in the office of said city clerk to be by him safely kept. List of registered voters.

Sec. XI. Be it further enacted, That any person voting or attempting to vote, at any such election, or registering prior to said election, not qualified to register, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction before the Superior Court of Polk county, shall be punished as prescribed in Code of Georgia 1895, section 1039. Illegal voting.

Sec. XII.
