Be it further enacted, That no person shall be eligible to the office of mayor, alderman or clerk of the city of Cedartown, unless he be a freeholder, of the age of 21, a citizen of the United States of America, and shall have resided in the city one year immediately preceding his election, and shll have paid all taxes due and demanded by said city. Mayor, clerk and aldermen, qualifications of.

Sec. XIII. Be it further enacted, That the mayor, aldermen and clerk shall have an adequate salary to be fixed by annual ordinance at the first regular meeting in November for the next succeeding year, beginning the 1st Tuesday in January, except for the year 1899, which shall be fixed by the present mayor and council at its first regular meeting, after the adoption of this charter, and provided, that for the year 1899, 1900 and 1901, the salary of the mayor shall not exceed $150, of the alderman $25, each, of the clerk $200; the treasurer's shall not exceed $75, in addition to the amount allowed him as alderman. Salaries of.

Sec XIV. Be it further enacted, That the corporate limits of the city of Cedartown, in the county of Polk, shall extend to and embrace all the territory included within the boundary lines described as follows: Beginning at a point one-half mile from the center of the court-house on a line running due east from the northeast corner of the cemetery lot, running thence due east to the west side of Martial avenue, thence due south along the west side of Martial avenue and over Standpipe hill and across tan-yard branch to the north side of the road running through Jones' farm, thence along the north side of said road to Main street, thence due west to the east side of the Esom hill road, thence due north to the center of tan-yard branch, thence down the center of tan-yard branch to the east bank of Cedar creek, thence down the east bank of Cedar creek to the mill-dam of the Cherokee Iron Company, thence east to the road or street east of the mill, thence north to the south side of West avenue, thence east along the south side of West avenue to a point one-half mile from the center of the court-house, thence forming a part of a circle going to the north of the court-house embracing a radius of one-half mile to the starting point. The city limits may be extended upon petition of two-thirds of the tax-payers of the territory sought to be included; any part of the territory inside of the city limits may be excluded upon a two-thirds vote of the qualified voters of said city voting at a regular election or an election to be called for that purpose, said election to be called by the mayor and council. Corporate limits.

Sec. XV. Be it further enacted, That the city of Cedartown shall be divided into five wards, as follows: Ward No. 1 shall be bounded as follows: Beginning at the intersection of Main and Prior streets and running northward along the center of Main street to the center of Sycamore street, thence west along the center of Sycamore street to the center of College street, thence north along the center of College street to the city limits, thence west around the city limits to the center of West avenue, thence
east along the center of West avenue to the center of College street, thence north along College street to the center of Prior street, thence east along the center of Prior street to the starting point. Wards. No. 1.
Ward No 2 shall include all that part of the city south of ward No. 1, and west of the center of Main street. No. 2.
Ward No. 3 shall include all that part of the city east of Main street and south of Herbert street and West of Jones street extended south to city limits and north to Herbert street. No. 3.

Ward No. 4 shall include all that part of the city west of Main street and north of Sycamore street, not included in the first ward, and north of Herbert street and west of that portion of the line dividing land lots Nos. 951 and 994 extended to the city limits that lies north of Herbert street. No. 4.
Ward No. 5, shall include all that part of the city east of the center of Jones street, extending south to city limits and north to Herbert street, and east to ward No. 4. No. 5.
That each ward shall be represented on the city council by one alderman who when elected shall be a resident of said ward.

Sec. XVI. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council shall have perpetual succession; shall have a common seal; be capable in law and equity to purchase, have, hold, receive, enjoy, possess and retain to them and their euccessors, for the use of the Mayor and Council of Cedartown, any estate or estates, real or personal, of whatsoever kind or nature, within or without the jurisdictional limits of said city for corporate purposes, and shall have the right to rent, lease, sell and dispose of any of said property, and shall by the said name be capable of suing and being sued in any court of law or equity in this State, and shall succeed to all rights and liabilities of the corporation of the city of Cedartown. Corporate powers.

Sec. XVII. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall have full and complete control of the streets, alleys, sidewalks and squares of said city; and shall have power and authority to open, lay out, widen, straighten, close or vacate, curb, pave and keep in good order and repair, or otherwise change all streets, sidewalks, alleys and squares in said city. That said mayor and council are authorized to condemn property which may be needed for said purposes, in the judgment of the mayor and council, the condemnation proceeding in all cases to conform to the laws of the State authorizing and regulating the condemnation of private properties for public uses. Streets, etc.

Sec. XVIII. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council
of Cedartown shall have full power and authority to establish and fix such a system of grading and draining of the streets of said city, as may be deemed proper; and shall have power to compel owners and lessees of property to curb, pave and construct and keep in good repair the streets, sidewalks and open sewers in their front. If any owner or lessee shall fail to comply with the requirements of the mayor and council in this regard the work shall be done under the direction of the city and execution shall issue for the cost and expenses thereof against such owners or lessee, to be collected as other executions issued by the clerk. Grades and drainage.

Sec. XIX. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Cedartown shall have full power and authority to maintain and control, subject to the provisions of the sections 37, 38, 39 and 40 of this charter, a system of waterworks and sanitary sewerage for said city, and to compel lot owners to connect with said sewers and to pay for same and the use thereof, payments to be enforced as the mayor and council may, be ordinance, direct; and may purchase or condemn any property within or without the city that may be necessary for either of said public works. In case it shall become necessary to condemn any property under this section, or for any other public works, the proceedings shall be the same as in section 17 of this charter. Waterworks, sewerage.

Sec. XX. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Cedartown shall have power to fix and establish fire limits, and from time to time enlarge the same; to provide and maintain a fire department and a system of fire alarms, within which fire limits as established it shall not be lawful for any one to build or cause to be built other than fire-proof buildings, and in case of any offense against ordinances passed in pursuance of this Act, the said mayor and council, after five days' notice given, shall cause the said not fire-proof building to be removed, at the expense of the owners or builders thereof, to be collected by execution as other executions issued by the city; and the said mayor and council shall have the right to determine what are not fire-proof buildings. Fire limits.

Sec. XXI. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Cedartown shall have power and authority to establish and regulate markets; prescribe time for holding the same; to prevent injury and annoyance to the public or individuals from anything dangerous, offensive or unwholesome; to prevent dogs, hogs, cattle, sheep, horses, mules, goats, asses, and all other animals and fowls of all kinds, from going at large in said city, or in any prescribed territory therein; to protect places of divine worship; to
abate, or cause to be abated, anything which, in the opinion of the council, is a nuisance; to regulate the keeping and selling of gunpowder, kerosene, and all other combustible or hazardous articles of merchandise; to guard against danger and damage by fire; to regulate the running and managing of steam engines and locomotives, whether for factories, furnaces, cotton-gins or railroads, within the corporate limits of said city, or for any and all sorts of vehicles, howsoever drawn or propelled, that may traverse or cross any street, avenues or alleys, lanes and roads; to guard against and prevent the fast driving and riding of any horses or bicycles on the streets of said city; to provide places for the burial of the dead, and to regulate interments therein; to provide for the regular building of houses or other structures; the drainage of lots by proper drains and ditches; to define the duties and prescribe the powers of all officers or agents appointed by them; to fix their salaries and term of office; to require and take from them such bonds as will protect the tax-payers of said city. Markets. Police powers.

Sec. XXII. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall have the power and authority, subject to the provisions of sections 37, 38, 39 and 40 of this charter, to light the streets of said city by means of gas, electricity or otherwise, as they may see proper, and for this purpose they may have power to lay mains, or pipes, along the streets or highways in said city. Lights.

Sec. XXIII. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Cedartown shall have power and authority to establish police rules and regulations; to pass all laws and ordinances not in conflict with the Constitution and laws of the State of Georgia, which tend to promote the safety, health, good order, morality and general welfare of the inhabitants of said city. General welfare.

Sec. XXIV. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council of Cedartown shall have authority to regulate, restrict or prohibit the sale of spirituous, malt or intoxicating liquors or bitters in said city, and may, for any violation of the laws and ordinances of said city, declare any license void and punish by fine and imprisonment. Liquor, sale of

Sec. XXV. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Cedartown shall have power and authority to borrow money and contract temporary loans to meet casual deficiences, subject to restrictions of the Constitution of the State of Georgia, Code of 1895, section 5895 [7]. Loans.

Sec. XXVI. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Cedartown shall have the authority to pass such ordinances as they may deem best for the exempting from city or municipal
taxation any manufacturer, person, company or corporation, for a period of not longer than eight years. This section to take effect so soon as the Constitution of the State of Georgia is changed so as not to be in conflict herewith. Manufacturers.

Sec. XXVII. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Cedartown shall have authority and power to appoint a board of health for said city, and also water and light commissioners, also strect commissioners, city attorney, recorder, and such number of marshals or deputy marshals as they may deem proper and necessary, and such other officers and agents as may be necessary to the interest of said city; to prescribe their duties and fix their compensation, and may at discretion suspend, remove or discharge them at any time, with or without cause. Department boards and officers.

Sec. XXVIII. Be it further enacted, That the mayor shall be the chief executive of the mayor and council of Cedartown; he shall see that all laws, ordinances, regulations and rules of the city are faithfully executed and enforced; that all officers of the city shall faithfully discharge the duties required of them; he shall have the general jurisdiction of the affairs of the city; he shall preside at all meetings of the mayor and council; he shall have five days, after the meeting at which any ordinance, order or resolution was passed, in which to file with the city clerk, in writing, his dissent thereto, which, when filed, shall have the effect to defeat such ordinance, order or resolution; but, any ordinance, order or resolution, may be passed over his veto by a four-fifths vote of all the members of the council. In the absence of the mayor, the veto power may be exercised by the mayor pro tem. Mayor, duties and authority.

Sec. XXIX. Be it further enacted, That there shall be a court for the trial of all offenders against the laws and ordinances of the city, to be held by the mayor, and in his absence or disqualification, by the mayor pro tem. Said court shall have the power to preserve order and compel the attendance of witnesses, to punish for contempt by imprisonment, not exceeding five days, or fine not exceeding $25, one or both; that the mayor, or, in his absence, the mayor pro tem., shall, as often as may be necessary, hold a police court, to be known as the mayor's court, for the trial of all offenders against the laws and ordinances of said city of Cedartown. Said mayor's court shall have full power and authority, upon conviction, to sentence such offenders to labor upon the streets or public works for a period not to exceed sixty days, or to impose a fine not to exceed $100, or to confine in the city prison not to exceed fifty days, either or none, or all of said penalties may be imposed, in the discretion of the court. There shall be an appeal
within four days to the mayor and council of said city after judgment is entered, the defendant paying all cost and giving bond in such sum as the mayor may fix for his personal appearance, and to abide the final judgment in said case. Mayor's court.

Sec. XXX. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and each of the aldermen shall be bound to keep the peace, and shall be ex officio justices of the peace, so as to enable them to issue warrants for the violation of the criminal laws of the State committed within the city of Cedartown, and shall have full power, on examination, to commit offenders to jail, or bail them, if the offense be bailable, to appear before the court having jurisdiction. Mayor and aldermen ex officio justices of the peace.

Sec. XXXI. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Cedartown shall have power and authority to establish a recorder's court and elect a recorder when in the discretion of the mayor and council the said court may be established and a recorder elected; said recorder's court shall take the place of the mayor's court hereinbefore described, and the recorder shall perform all the duties specified for the mayor to perform in connection with said court. Should the recorder be disqualified in any case the mayor shall appoint some one to hold said court in said disqualified case or cases; said recorder to have no salary; his compensation shall be derived solely from his fees. Recorder.

Sec. XXXII. Be it further enacted, That the clerk shall be the keeper of the records of the city; shall keep a full and correct account of all the acts and doings of the mayor and council; shall be the clerk of the mayor's court, or the recorder's court, should one be established; he shall issue all processes, shall make up the tax digest and shall discharge all duties that may be required of him by the laws, ordinances, rules, resolutions and regulations of the mayor and council, and shall give such bond as the mayor and council may require; that the treasurer shall be custodian of the funds of the city, and that he shall pay out said funds only as the mayor and council may by ordinance direct. Clerk, duties of. Bond. Treasurer, duties of.

Sec. XXXIII. Be it further enacted, That for the purpose of raising revenue for the support and maintenance for the city government, the mayor and council of Cedartown shall have full power and authority and shall prescribe by ordinances for the assessment, levy and collection of an ad valorem tax on all real and personal property within the corporate limits of said city, to defray ordinary annual expenses of the city government, a tax not to exceed one-half of one per cent. per annum; to pay the principal and interest on the bonded indebtedness and to support the public school system of said city, and any other extraordinary expenses of the city
government, such taxes as may be necessary, in the discretion of the mayor and council. Advalorem tax.

Sec. XXXIV. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Cedartown shall have power and authority to license, regulate and control all taverns, hotels, cafs, restaurants, boarding-houses, livery-stables, hacks, drays and other vehicles, auctioneers, vendue-masters, itinerant traders, theatrical performances, shows circus and exhibitions of all kinds, itinerant lightning-rod dealers, emigrant agents, clock and stove peddlers, peddlers of all kinds, itinerant dealers in jewelry and all other traveling or itinerant venders of articles, goods, wares and merchandise of every nature whatsoever; every keeper of a shooting gallery, ten-pin alley, upon the keeper of any other table, stand or place for the performance of any game or play, whether played with sticks, balls, rings or other contrivance; upon the keeper of flying-horses, bicycle, velocipede or skating rinks, insurance agents, life and fire insurance companies, brokers, dealers in futures, loan agents and agents for any other business or calling whatsoever; keepers of slaughter-houses, beef markets, green groceries, dealers in fish, oysters, vegetables, fruits, breads and other articles of food; upon every junk-shop, pawn-broker; upon all other establishments, businesses, calling or avocation not hereinbefore mentioned, and which, under the laws and constitution of the State of Georgia, are subject to license or a special tax. Specific taxes.

Sec. XXXV. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Cedartown shall have power and authority to require every male inhabitant of said city who is subject to road duty under the laws of this State, to work such length of time on the streets of said city as such mayor and council shall by ordinance direct, or they may prescribe a commutation tax to be paid by such person in lieu of such work; and they shall have power and authority to enforce obedience to their laws and ordinances under this section by fine and imprisonment, or either, and no tax paid in lieu of such work, or any money arising from fines or forfeitures for failure to perform such work, shall be used for any purpose except in payment for work done or improvements put on the streets or side-walks. Streets, how worked.

Sec. XXXVI. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of Cedartown shall have power and authority to enforce, by execution, the collection of any debt, demand or any amount due or to become due to it, such execution to be issued by the clerk against the person, corporation or firm by whom any such debt may be due or may become due, which execution may be levied by the
marshal on the property of the owner against whom such execution shall issue, and the same sold as provided by Code of 1895, sections 732, 733, 734 and 735, for municipal sales for taxes. Municipal demands, how enforced.

Sec. XXXVII. Be it further enacted, That a commission, composed of three persons, to be known as the Water and Light Commission, to be elected, except the first board herein named, as hereinafter provided, is hereby created for the city of Cedartown. The first board shall consist of the following persons, who shall hold their respective offices as follows: B. F. Lowther, for one year; J. Wright Adamsom, for two years; H. N. Vandevander, for three years, from and after the first day of December, 1898, until their successors are elected and qualified. The mayor and council of Cedartown shall in November, 1899, and annually thereafter, elect a commissioner who shall succeed the commissioner whose term expires in such year, and all commissioners so elected shall hold their offices for three years from the first day of December following their election; said commissioners shall each be paid a salary of not more than $25 per annum. Water and Light commission.

Sec. XXXVIII. Be it further enacted, That the following powers and duties shall be, and are, hereby vested in and imposed upon said commissioners, to wit: to elect annually, in the month of December, the following officers, who shall hold their respective offices for one year, until their successors are elected and qualified, unless removed therefrom by said commission, to wit: A superintendent, an engineer, and clerk, who shall be the city clerk, and the clerk of said board and the bill collector and ex officio treasurer; to define the duties of each of said officers, and to appoint such other agents and persons as may be necessary to carry on and operate said water-works and electric light plant; to fix the salaries and the pay of all such officers and employees, and to alter the same from time to time at their discretion; provided, that this clause shall not in any way affect the existing contract between the present council and the present superintendent of water and lights; to manage and control the entire electric light and water-works system of said city, and to maintain, repair and extend the same; to erect, alter and maintain fire plugs and public hydrants, poles and wires and lights, in such places within the limits of said city as the mayor and council may direct, and to regulate the use thereof; to supply the city with lights and water for fire purposes, sprinkling the streets, flushing the sewers, and for lighting the streets, and for such other purposes as may be necessary; to regulate and distribute the use of water and lights in all places and for all purposes; to fix the price, time and place for
payment for the uses thereof; to collect and expend the income of said electric light and water-works system for the purposes herein named, and to pay all surplus income and money received into the treasury of the city; to issue executions against tenants and land-lords, jointly and severally, for lights and water rents due by them or either of them, to be levied and collected as other executions in favor of said city; to require payment in advance or at maturity, as they may elect, and in case payment shall not be made as required, to shut off the lights and the water from all buildings, places and premises, and to keep the same at their discretion shut off, until all arrears, with interest thereon, shall be fully paid; and to make such rules and regulations as they may see fit and proper for the sale and distribution of the products of these plants. That said commissioners shall make no contracts for the use of water for a longer period than two years, nor shall they, by any contract, limit or restrain their power, or that of their successors, to make contracts with other persons, or to modify or to discontinue such as they may make whenever, in their judgment, it may be necessary for them to do so. That said commissioners may remove without cause any person appointed by them. That said commissioners shall make quarterly returns to the mayor and council of said city of all receipts and disbursements made by them, and of such other matters as they may see fit or the council may require. Powers of commissioners.

Sec. XXXIX. Be it further enacted, That said commission shall be amenable to the mayor and council of said city, and they shall be subject to removal from office for neglect of duty or for malfeasance therein, on trial and conviction thereof, by such mayor and council. Commission amenable to mayor and council.

Sec. XL. Be it further enacted, That said commissioners may pass such ordinances, rules and regulations, as they may see fit and proper for the protection of said systems, and the mayor and council shall have the right and authority to punish all persons for violation of the same. Mayor and council to enforce rules of commission.

Sec. XLI. Be it further enacted, That the city clerk shall open the tax books for receiving tax returns from all persons owning or claiming real estate and personal property of any and every kind, sort or description, subject to taxation, and all businesses, special or license taxes, on the first day of April of each year and keep the same open until the first day of June, in which returns all property, both real and personal, of every kind and description, owned by the person, firm or corporation on the first day of April, must be included, and should any person or firm begin a mercantile business in said city, or any other business after the first day of
April, then the mayor and council shall have power and authority, and it shall be their duty to levy and collect an ad valorem tax from said person, firm or corporation, for the year in which he or they began business; said tax shall be due and collected at the time of beginning business. Said returns to be made out on blanks prepared by the mayor and council of said city, said blanks to be so made as to accurately describe all real estate, and any person, firm or corporation returning taxes must answer under oath any and all questions on said blank, and must sign and swear to said return before the city clerk, who is hereby authorized to administer and attest oaths, and should any person, firm or corporation make a false return they shall be subject to prosecution for false swearing. Said clerk shall turn over all of said tax returns to the tax revisers, on or by the tenth day of June of each year. Tax returns.

Sec. XLII. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council shall have power and authority to appoint three tax revisers, not members of their body, freeholders, residents of said city, whose duty it shall be to scrutinize carefully each return of property, real and personal, made by every tax payer of said city, and if, in their judgment they shall find the property embraced in said return, or any portion thereof, returned below its value, they shall assess its true value. And said tax revisers shall also assess the value of all property in said city not returned for taxation; and all property not returned as hereinbefore provided for shall be taxed twenty-five per cent. above the regular rate, as a penalty for failing to return the same, which penalty shall not in any case be relieved or remitted. The tax revisers shall give notice, in writing, to every person whose property they have revised; and any one dissatisfied with the assessment of his or her property may enter an appeal in writing, within fifteen days from the date of the notice given, to the mayor and aldermen, whose decision in the matter shall be final and conclusive. That said revisers and said mayor and council shall have power and authority to subp[oelig]na witnesses for the city and for the complaining party and hear evidence as to the true value of said property. Mailing a notice to the person or their agents whose property has been raised, addressed to them at their last known post-office, shall be sufficient compliance with this section as to giving notice. Tax assessors.

Sec. XLIII. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council shall also make or cause to be made by the persons having such matters in charge a quarterly statement and account, under oath, of the financial condition of said city; such account shall be a full and itemized statement of all moneys collected, when and from
what source collected, of all amounts paid out, and when and on what accounts paid out, the sum due the city and from what source due, the existing liabilities of the city and the balance on hand. Each statement and account shall be published. Financial statements.

Sec. XLIV. Be it further enacted, That it shall not be lawful for any person holding any office in said city, whether by election or by appointment, to be interested either directly or indirectly, in any contract to which said city is a party; and any contract made in violation of this section shall be void as against said city, and any officer violating this provision shall be dismissed from office. Illegal contracts.

Sec. XLV. Be it further enacted, That nothing in this Act shall be construed so as to repeal, alter or annual an Act to authorize the town of Cedartown, in Polk county, Georgia, to establish and maintain a system of public schools for said town, approved September 9, 1887, and any and all Acts amendatory thereof. Public schools.

Sec. XLVI. Be it further enacted, That any and all ordinances, rules and regulations now of force in said city of Cedartown, and not inconsistent with this Act shall be and remain of full force and effect, until altered, amended or repealed by said mayor and council. Laws of force continued.

Sec. XLVII. Be it further enacted, That the Act providing a new charter for Cedartown, approved November 11, 1889, and all laws and parts of laws in conflict therewith, the same be, and are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: CLARKSTON, TOWN OF, INCORPORATED.
law.fulltitle: An act to provide a new charter for the town of Clarkston in said State and the county of DeKalb, to define the powers and duties of the officers thereof, to prescribe their terms of office and the manner of election, to repeal the present laws in regard thereto, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That the town of Clarkston in the county of DeKalb, be, and the same is, hereby incorporated as a town under the name of the town of Clarkston Clarkston, town of incorporated

Sec. II. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the corporate limits of said town shall extend one-half mile in each and every direction from the depot of the Georgia railroad in said town. Corporate limits.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That an election elecion shall be held upon the third Wednesday of December, 1898, and annually thereafter on the third Wednesday of December, for a mayor and five council members who shall serve one year, or until their successors are elected and qualified; the polls shall be opened at 8 a. m. and closed at 6 p. m. Mayor and councilmen, election of.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the term of office of said mayor and town council shall begin upon the first Wednesday in January of each year, and the regular meetings of the council shall be held on the first Monday in each month. Terms of.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no one shall vote for or be eligible to the office of mayor or council, who does not reside in the corporate limits thereof, and who is not qualified to vote for members of the General Assembly of this State (except all voters in town elections must have resided in said town six months next preceding said election). Said election shall be held and conducted in the same manner as elections for county officers in this State, and a certificate of the managers shall be sufficient authority to the persons elected to enter on the discharge of the duties of the offices to which they have been elected. The returns of the election shall be made to the mayor and council of said town. Qualifications of voters and officers. Elections, how conducted.

Sec. VI. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That before entering upon the discharge of their duties the mayor and each council member shall subscribe the following oath, which may be administered by any person authorized by laws of this State to administer oaths. I do solemnly swear that I will faithfully discharge all the duties devolving on me as mayor (or council as the case may be) of the town of Clarkston, to the best of my ability and understanding, during my continuance in office, so help me God. Mayor and councilmen, oath of.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said mayor and town council shall have power and authority to elect a mayor pro tem., from their number, also a marshal, a clerk, a treasurer, and a tax-collector who shall also be tax-receiver; but the said mayor and town council shall have the authority to combine such of the above offices as they may deem fit and proper, that they shall have the right to constitute such other subordinate offices as
they may deem necessary for carrying into effect the powers herein conferred upon them; to prescribe the fees and duties of such subordinate officers, and require such bonds for the faithful performance of their duties as they may deem necessary and proper. Subordinate officers.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor shall be ex officio a justice of the peace, and shall have full power and authority to issue warrants for any offense committed within the corporate limits of said town, and shall compel the attendance of witnesses; to examine them under oath; to admit any offender to bail or commit him or her to jail for violating any of the laws of this State, and fine not exceeding fifty dollars or commit to the guard-house not exceeding thirty days for any violation of the ordinances of said town; and in the absence of the mayor the mayor pro tem. shall have the authority to hold a mayor's court to try offenders against the ordinances of said town. Mayor ex officio a justice of the peace, authority of.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said mayor and council shall have power to levy and collect a tax not exceeding one-fourth of one per cent. upon all property, both real and personal, within the corporate limits of said town, for the support of the town government. Tax.

Sec. X. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said mayor and council shall be known as the mayor and council of Clarkston, and as such a corporate name shall sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and do all other acts in their corporate capacity, and shall be capable in law to purchase and hold, enjoy, possess, and retain to them and their successors in office, for the use and benefit of the town of Clarkston, in perpetuity, or for a term of years, any estate or estates, real or personal, lands, tenements, hereditaments, of what kind or nature soever, within the limits of said town, and sell, alien, exchange or lease the same or any part thereof in any way whatever, and they shall have power to pass every other by-law, regulation or ordinance that shall appear to them necessary and proper for the security, welfare and interest of said town, and for preserving the peace, health, good government and good order thereof; they shall have power to make all contracts in their corporate capacity which they may deem necessary for said town; they shall have power to levy tax on all kinds of business carried on in said town, not in conflict with the laws of said State of Georgia; they shall require all town taxes to be collected (and paid over at once or as soon as collected to the town treasurer) at such times and in such manner as the mayor and council may direct in their by-laws, and in case any person or persons, citizens of said
town, or who have property subject to taxation within the limits of the same, shall fail, refuse or neglect to pay the taxes imposed in this Act, the clerk of the council shall issue executions for same, which execution shall be signed by said clerk and bear test in the name of the mayor, and be directed to the marshal of said town, commanding him to levy upon the goods and chattels, lands and tenements of the defendants, or so much thereof as may be sufficient to satisfy the demand and cost, which execution shall bind all the property of defendant from the date thereof, and the cost thereof shall be the same as on tax collectors' executions by the law of the State, and the said marshal shall proceed to advertise and sell in such manner as the ordinance of said town shall or may direct; they may require a license not exceeding fifty dollars on all ten-pin alleys, billiard and pool tables, and other establishments calculated to encourage idleness, and all shows, itinerant traders, and exhibitions performing for the purpose of gain; and they shall have power to regulate or prohibit the sale of spirituous liquors in said corporation, and fix the amount to be paid quarterly, in advance, for license to sell spirituous liquors in said town, said license not to be less than five hundred dollars per annum, and to make ordinances for the abatement of all nuisances, and to provide in or near the town places for the burial of the dead and regulate interments therein; to protect places of divine worship in and about the premises where held, to keep in good order and repair all streets, sidewalks, cross-walks and drains for the use of the public, and having them kept free from obstructions on or over them (the streets now existing as originally laid out by the Georgia Railroad Company shall be preserved and kept open), and to extend and lay out streets and regulate the width and length of same; they also shall have power to require all persons within said corporation who are subject to road duty under the laws of this State to work on the streets of said town not exceeding ten days during the year, or they may prescribe a commutation tax which may be paid in lieu of work on said streets, and shall have power to imprison any defaulter who fails or refuses to work on said streets when required, in the guard-house of said town, not exceeding two days for each day he fails or refuses to work. Corporate name and powers. Taxing powers. Liquor, sale of. Nuisances. Cemetery. Churches. Streets.

Sec. XI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor of said town shall be chief executive officer of said town; he shall see that the rules, ordinances and by-laws of said town are faithfully executed; he shall have control of the police of said town, and may appoint special police when he may deem it necessary, and it shall be his duty especially to see that the peace and good
order of the town are preserved and that persons and property are protected therein, and to this end he may cause the arrest and detention of all riotous, drunken and disorderly persons in said town; he shall have power to issue execution for all fines, penalties and costs imposed by him, or he may require the immediate payment thereof, and in default of immediate payment he may imprison the offender in the guard-house of said town, or in lieu of imprisonment the offender shall work the streets under the directions of the marshal until the fine is satisfied; provided, that no fine shall exceed fifty dollars, and no imprisonment be longer than thirty days for each offense, and in case the defendant should be dissatisfied with the judgment of the mayor he shall have the right of appeal to the town council upon the payment of all costs which may have accrued up to the time of entering the appeal; provided, that the entering of such appeal shall not operate to release the defendant from custody without giving bond and security for his appearance as may be approved by the proper officers of said town. Mayor, authority and duty.

Sec. XII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the expenditures of the mayor and council, and the compensation for officers shall be paid out of town funds, by order drawn by the clerk upon the treasurer, and countersigned by the mayor, but that they may make the fees of such officers contingent upon their collection by the officers from defendants. Municipal expenses, how paid.

Sec. XIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in case the mayor or any member of the board of council of said town while in office, be guilty of any willful neglect, malpractice in or abuse of said office, he or they shall be liable to be indicted before the superior court of the county of DeKalb, and on conviction thereof shall be fined in the sum not exceeding five hundred dollars for each and every such offense, and shall moreover be removed from office, which fine or fines shall be paid over to the town treasurer for the use of said town. Malfeasance.

Sec. XIV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all warrants, summons, precepts, executions or other process issued by the clerk of the council of Clarkston, shall be directed to the marshal of said town of Clarkston. Process to marshal.

Sec. XV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if at any time the office of mayor or councilman shall become vacant by death, resignation or otherwise, the remaining members of the council shall order an election to fill such vacancy, of which election at least ten days' notice shall be given, either by advertisement in some public gazette of said town, or by posting in three or more public places therein. Vacancies.
Sec. XVI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: COCHRAN, BONDS FOR WATER-WORKS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize and empower the mayor and council of the town of Cochran, Georgia, to purchase, build, contract for and maintain a system of water-works and other permanent improvements, to hold an election to determine the question of making contracts for the purpose above named, and creating a debt by the issue of bonds for such purpose, or otherwise; to provide for the assessment and collection of an annual tax for the payment of said debt, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted, That the mayor and council of the town of Cochran be, and they are, hereby authorized and empowered to contract for, purchase or build, and to maintain and operate a system of water-works for the said town, whenever they shall think best, and to make, or cause to be made, from time to time, such other permanent improvements for the benefit of the said town, or its inhabitants, as to them shall seem best, being hereby vested with full power and authority to exercise a broad discretion in determining upon such improvements, and to provide for the same, either as the property of the said town, or by contract with private individuals or corporations, making and giving to them such grants, exclusive or otherwise, as to the mayor and council shall seem best. Cochran, water-works for.

Sec. II. For the purpose of paying for said water-works and other permanent improvements, any or all, the said mayor and council, subject to the election by the people of the said town to be held under the Constitution and laws of this State, are hereby authorized to issue the coupon bonds of said town, not to exceed in the aggregate fifteen thousand dollars, of such denominations, payable at such time or times not more than thirty years from date, with such rate of interest not exceeding six per cent, and having such covenants
and conditions as to the said mayor and council shall seem best. The bonds shall be executed under the corporate seal of the town and the signature of the mayor and clerk; the coupons may be signed only by the clerk, whose signature may be lithographed or engraved. Election for bonds to pay for same.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That said bonds, or such of them, as shall be from time to time issued, may be used by the said mayor and council for the purpose of paying for the said water-works, or other permanent improvements, under contracts to be made by the said mayor and council; but if the said mayor and council should at any time, or from time to time, prefer to sell said bonds for cash, then the same shall be sold, only after advertisement for not less than thirty days in a newspaper in which the sheriff's advertisements of Pulaski county shall be published, and in such other newspapers as to them shall seem best, said advertisement to call for sealed bids for the said bonds; and on the coming in of all the said bids the said bonds shall be sold to the best and highest bidder at a price not less than par, with the right on the part of the mayor and council to reject any or all bids; but under no circumstances shall the said bonds, or any portion thereof, be issued to any person or corporation except for cash, unless in the notice of election required by law to determine whether or not the said bonds shall be issued, it shall be stated that it is proposed that the said bonds shall be issued and sold for work, labor or property, any or both. Bonds, how disposed of.

Sec. IV. At the time of issuing the said bonds, the said mayor and council shall provide by ordinance for an annual tax sufficient in amount to pay the principal and interest of the said bonds as the same shall fall due, in not more than thirty years, and may provide for the setting apart of a sinking fund with which to pay the said bonds at maturity; and the said tax, so levied by the said mayor and council, shall in no event be repealed or withdrawn by the said mayor and council, or their successors, until the said bond shall have been fully paid off; the tax herein provided for shall be in addition to any tax levied for any other purpose. Tax to pay bonds.

Sec. V. The said bonds, as they shall severally fall due, and the interest coupons upon the same, shall be paid by the clerk or treasurer, or other proper officer, on presentation or demand, at the treasury of the said town, or at such agency in the city of New York as may be designated; and the principal of the said bonds, and the interest coupons thereon when severally due, shall be received by the town and the proper officers thereof in payment of all
dues or taxes to the said town; the bonds shall not be taxed directly or indirectly by the town of Cochran. Bonds, how paid.

Sec. VI. Nothing herein contained shall be so construed as to permit the said bonds, or any portion thereof, to be issued until after an election by the qualified voters of said town has been held, as now or hereafter provided by law, and the assent of two-thirds of the said voters has been obtained thereto. Bonds must be authorized by election.
Sec. VII. All laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: DAWSON, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the city of Dawson, so as to empower the mayor and aldermen to fix the maximum license at $500.00 for conducting any business or carrying on any trade, avocation or profession; also, to fix the license at not less than $3,000 and not to exceed $5,000 for the sale of spirituous, vinous, malt or intoxicating liquors; to provide for the assessment of tax upon personal property, and to prohibit the erection of wooden structures within the fire limits, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of the Act, the charter of the city of Dawson (Act 1882-3, p. 104-110, approved September 21st, 1883) be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking out of the seventh clause, after the enacting clause, the words twenty-five, and inserting in lieu thereof the words five hundred, so that said section when amended shall read as follows: Be it enacted, etc., That the mayor and aldermen shall have power and authority to levy and collect by execution or other legal process, taxes within the corporate limits of said city, upon all property, real and personal, liable to be taxed for State and county purposes; provided, the rate of taxation shall not exceed one per cent. upon all taxable property; and the said mayor and aldermen are hereby empowered to require any person, firm, company, corporation, or agent thereof, engaged
in, prosecuting or carrying on, or that may engage in, prosecute or carry on any trade, business, calling, avocation or profession within the corporate limits of said city, to register their names, business, calling, vocation or profession, and to pay for such registration, and for license to engage in, prosecute or carry on such business, calling or profession aforesaid, not exceeding five hundred dollars per annum. Dawson. Business license.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the tenth section of said charter as found on page 407 of the published Acts of the General Assembly of Georgia, for the session of 1882-3, be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking out of said section the clause said amount not to exceed five hundred dollars per annum, and inserting in lieu thereof the clause said amount shall not be less than $3,000 and shall not exceed $5,000 per annum, so that when amended said section shall read as follows: Be it further enacted, That the mayor and aldermen shall have the sole and exclusive right to grant license to sell or retail all spirituous, vinous, malt or intoxicating liquors within the limits of said city and of fixing the rate and amount of such license. Said amount shall not be less than three thousand dollars and shall not exceed $5,000 per annum, and the terms and conditions upon which they shall issue, and to declare said license void when said terms and conditions are not complied with, and to punish any person who may violate the same. Liquor license.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the fifteenth section of said charter, as found on page 409 of the published Acts of the General Assembly of Georgia, for the session of 1882-3, be, and the same is, hereby amended by inserting after the words real estate and before the word situate the words and personal property, so that the amended clause in said section shall read as follows: It shall be the duty of said assessors to place a true and just valuation on all real estate and personal property, situated within the limits of said city, liable to taxation and return the same to the mayor and aldermen on or before the first day of August, in each year, or as soon thereafter as practicable, the parts of said section preceding and subsequent to said clause remaining in full force as heretofore. Assessment of real and personal property.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the seventeenth section of the amended charter of the city of Dawson, found on page 617 of the published Acts of the General Assembly of Georgia for the session of 1887, be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking thereform all of said section after the first two lines except the proviso, and inserting in lieu thereof
after the word territory and before the proviso the following: extending from Second avenue to Fourth avenue, from Vine to Stonewall streets and on Lee to Orange street; except with the nnanimous consent, of the mayor and aldermen of said city of Dawson. Said mayor and aldermen shall have power and authority, whenever it shall be by them deemed necessary to the security, welfare, convenience and interest of said city of Dawson to remove any wooden building now standing in the limits provided in this section; provided, c.; the first two lines of said section and the proviso remaining of full force as heretofore. Fire limits.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed; provided, that said amendment shall not empower the Mayor and council to tax the dispensary established by Acts 1897, p. 562, for the county of Terrell.

law.shorttitle: EASTMAN, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to alter and amend the 20th section of an Act approved December 15th, 1871, entitled an Act to incorporate the town of Eastman, in the county of Dodge; and to repeal said Act so far as the same may relate to the property (live stock) of non-residents and by prohibiting the authorities of said town from exercising the powers conferred by said 20th section of said Act upon the property (live stock) of said non-residents.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives in General Assembly met, That from and after the passage of this Act, that an Act to incorporate the town of Eastman, in the county of Dodge, to define the limits of the same, and to repeal all previous Acts passed incorporating the same, approved Decemberthe 15th, 1871, and the 20th section thereof, be so amended as to add to said section the following provision: provided, that the provisions of this section shall not relate to the property (live stock) belonging to non-residents of said town; so as said section, when so amended, shall read as follows: That the mayor and aldermen shall have power to take up and impound any horses
mules, dogs, hogs, cows, or other cattle running at large in said town, and to pass and to enforce all ordinances which they may deem necessary and proper for the regulation and control of all such animals in said town; provided, that the provisions of this section shall not relate to the property (live stock) belonging to non-residents of said town. Eastman. Live stock of non-residents not to be impounded.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: EDGEWOOD INCORPORATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to incorporate the town of Edgewood, in the county of DeKalb; to define the corporate limits thereof; to provide a municipal government for said town; to confer certain powers and privileges on the same; to establish a system of public schools for the said town of Edgewood; to provide for the support and maintenance of same by taxation and otherwise; to create a Board of Education therefor; to authorize and require the State School Commissioner to pay to said Board of Education of said town their pro rata share of the State school funds for the children residing in said limits, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That the town of Edgewood, in the county of DeKalb, be, and the same is, hereby incorporated as a town, under the name of the town of Edgewood. Edgewood, town of, incorporated.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That the corporate limits of said town shall be as follows: Commencing at the southwest corner of McLendon street, and the county line, thence south along said line to a point two hundred (200) feet south of Hardee street, thence east to the branch which runs east of Foote avenue, thence northerly along said branch to the south line of the right of way of the Georgia Railway, thence easterly along said right of way to a point due south of the northwest corner of Decatur street and the east line of Colquitt Hill, thence north to a point 200 feet north from McLendon street, thence westerly parallel with McLendon street to east line of Mell avenue, thence north to Arnold street, thence west to east line of Smith street, thence north along said line to
the Decatur turnpike, thence west to county line, and thence south to the starting point. Corporate limits.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That the municipal government of said town shall consist of a mayor and five aldermen, who are hereby constituted a body corporate under the name and style of the mayor and council of the town of Edgewood, and by that name and style shall have perpetual succession, and to do all acts relating to their corporate capacity; and shall be capable in law to purchase, hold, receive, enjoy and possess, to retain to them and their successors, for the sole use and benefit of the said town of Edgewood, in perpetuity or for a term of years, any estate, real or personal, within the limits of said town, and to sell, exchange or lease the same in any way whatever. Mayor and aldermen, corporate name and powers.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, That on the second Wednesday in January, 1899, and annually thereafter for aldermen, and biennially thereafter for mayor, an election shall be held in said town. The mayor to hold office two years, and the aldermen, after the first election, shall hold office two years; but at the first election two of the aldermen shall be chosen for one year, and the other three for two years. The terms of office of each and all elected to begin with the first Monday of February after their election. Said election shall be held and conducted in the same manner as the elections for county officers in the State, and the certificate of the managers shall be sufficient authority to the persons elected to enter on the discharge of the duties of the offices to which they have been elected. Elections.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That the qualified voters of said town shall be all such persons as are qualified to vote for members of the General Assembly for said county, and who have bona fide resided in said town for six months previous to the election whereat they shall offer to vote. Qualified voters.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and aldermen shall, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, subscribe to the following oath, which may be administered by any person in the State authorized to administer oaths: I do solemnly swear or affirm that I will faithfully discharge all the duties incumbent upon me as the mayor (or alderman) of the town of Edgewood, according to the best of my ability, so help me God. Mayor and aldermen, oath of.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and aldermen shall have power and authority to elect a marshal and clerk, and to prescribe the duties of such officers and require of them such bonds as they may deem necessary; but no salary whatever shall
be paid to said mayor and aldermen or other officers, except the marshal, who shall act as clerk, tax-receiver and tax-collector. Marshal.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and aldermen shall have the power to make and pass all ordinances, by-laws, rules and regulations that may seem necessary for the good government, peace, order and health of said town, and for the enforcement of all powers herein granted; provided, that they are not repugnant to the Constitution and laws of the State of Georgia, or of the United States. General welfare.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and aldermen shall have power to levy a tax, not to exceed one-half of one per cent. on all property, real and personal, subject to the State tax, within the corporate limits of said town for the purpose of paying the expenses of the town and of the system of public schools hereinafter provided, for, and the returns as made to the State and county tax receiver of DeKalb county shall be accepted as the correct assessment. They shall also have the power and authority to require all persons subject to road duty, under the laws of this State, to work on the streets and sidewalks of said town, but they may receive in lieu of said work such commutation fee as said mayor and aldermen shall prescribe. Tax. Streets.

Sec. X. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and aldermen shall have the power to provide for the arrest, trial and punishment of offenders against any ordinance, by-law, rule or regulation of said town by fine, imprisonment or work on the streets of said town; provided, said fine shall not exceed twenty-five dollars, and such imprisonment shall not exceed twenty-five days. Polic powers.

Sec. XI. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and aldermen shall have power to elect a mayor pro tem., who shall perform all the duties of the Mayor when from any cause he cannot be present to execute the duties of his office; also to fill any vacancy that may occur in the office of mayor or aldermen, or any subordinate office of said town. Vacancies.

Sec. XII. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and aldermen shall have the power to provide by ordinance for the collection of all taxes, moneys, and flues due said town by execution to be issued by the mayor and executed by the marshal thereof. Taxes and other dues, how collected.

Sec. XIII. Be it further enacted, That the mayor, or mayor pro tem., shall have power to compel the attendance of witnesses, to examine them under oath, to admit any offender to bail, or commit him to the guard-house or county jail for the violation of the ordinances of said town. Mavor's court.

Sec. XIV. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council
shall be forever prohibited from granting license in any form to any person for the sale of spirituous, vinous, malt or other intoxicating liquors within said corporation of Edgewood; also shall they be prohibited from allowing tenpin alleys, billiard and pool tables, and from allowing any other like devices and contrivances used for the purpose of gaming, or carrying on any other game of chance by selling cards, tickets or numbers, or by using any other article or contrivance. Liquor, sale of and places for gaming prohibited.

Sec. XV. Be it further enacted, That the mayor of said town shall be the chief executive officer; he shall see that the ordinances, by-laws, rules and regulations of the council are faithfully executed; he may appoint special police when he may deem it necessary, of whom he shall have full control; he shall have power to issue executions for all fines, penalties and costs imposed by him, or he may require the immediate payment thereof, and in default of such immediate payment, he may imprison the offender in the guard-house of said town, or county jail not exceeding twenty-five days. Mayor, duties and powers.

Sec. XVI. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and aldermen shall have authority to devise, design and adopt a thorough system of public instruction in said town, and shall have exclusive jurisdiction over all the schools established under said system and modify the same from time to time as circumstances may require; to establish such schools as they may deem proper, not exceeding one for the white race and one for the colored race; no white child shall attend colored school and no colored child attend a white school; to appoint, remove or suspend teachers in their discretion; to fix salaries for teachers, to prescribe a curriculum or course of study; to make such by-laws for the control and government of said schools as they think proper, and to do all lawful acts conducive to the proper and successful operation of said school system. Public schools.

Sec. XVII. Be it further enacted, That it shall be the duty of the said mayor and aldermen to have, prepare and furnish the State School Commissioner each year a list or census of all the pupils residing in said town entitled to the State school fund, and said State School Commissioner shall pay over to the said mayor and aldermen such proportion of said educational fund as said pupils are entitled to under the rules of distribution. Pro rata part of State school fund.
Sec. XVIII. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: ELBERTON, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to alter and amend sections four and five of an Act incorporating the city of Elberton, in Elbert county, approved December 19th, 1896; to declare what officers shall constitute the municipal government of said city; to fix the time of elections and the term of office of said city officials, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, section four of an Act incorporating the city of Elberton in Elbert county, approved December 19, 1896, be, and the same is, hereby altered and amended as follows: By striking from the third line of said section all the words except the words five councilmen, at the beginning of said line; further by striking from said section all the words in lines four, five, six and seven, and the words of Elberton, at the beginning of line eight; further by striking out the word annually in line eight, and inserting in lieu thereof the word biennially; further by striking out the words one year in line nine and inserting in lieu thereof the words two years, so that said section, when so amended, will read as follows: That the municipal government of said city shall consist of a mayor and five councilmen, all of whom shall be elected biennially on the days fixed by ordinance, and hold their offices for two years and until their successors are elected and qualified; each of whom shall take an appropriate oath provided by ordinance, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, which oath may be administered by any person authorized to administer oaths under the laws of this state. That the council may appoint or elect such other subordinate officers as may become necessary at any time for the enforcement of the provisions of this charter, or any ordinance passed by said council in pursuance of the rights and powers herein conferred, all of which subordinate officers, as may be thus appointed or elected, shall be deemed and held to be lawful officers of this state and of the city of Elberton. All subordinate officers or such as are elected or appointed by the council shall hold their office at the will of the council and receive such salary as may be fixed by the council, each of whom shall take an appropriate oath before entering upon the discharge
of their respective duties, and shall give bonds as the council may require. Elberton. Mayor and councilmen. Terms of office. Subordinate officers.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all of section five of said Act be, and the same is, hereby stricken out and the following inserted in lieu thereof, as section five of said Act: Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, that the present officers of said city, to wit: Willis B. Adams, mayor; McAlpine Arnold, Isaac G. Swift, Dillard H. Brown, John R. Mattox and Ira C. Van Duzer, councilmen, be, and they are, hereby declared to be the lawful officers of said city of Elberton until the second Wednesday in January, 1899, and until their successors are elected and qualified, at which time there shall be an election held in said city, under the laws of the state applicable and under such rules and regulations as have or may be by ordinance adopted, for the election of a mayor and two councilmen, who shall hold their offices for two years from their election, and for the election of three councilmen who shall hold their offices for one year from their election. That at the election to be held on the second Wednesday in January, 1900 (or the time fixed in lieu thereof), three councilmen shall be elected for the term of two years, so that from and after the election for 1900 all of the elective officers of said city shall be elected for the term of two years, electing three councilmen one year and a mayor and two councilmen the next, alternately. That an election shall be held annually at the time fixed by ordinance under the provisions of this charter for the election of city officials in accordance with the above stated plan. The time of the annual election may be changed by ordinance, if not done so as to lengthen the term of office of any official, holding office at the time the change is made. All vacancies shall be filled by an election called by the council for the purpose, which shall be advertised at least fifteen days before the election is held, and those elected shall hold only the unexpired term of the person or persons whose death, resignation or disqualification caused the vacancy. Mayor and councilmen. Elections Vacancies.
Sec. III. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: FITZGERALD, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the city of Fitzgerald, in the county of Irwin, as said charter is contained in the original incorporating Act of 1896, approved December 2, 1896, and in the Act of 1897, approved December 14, 1897 (pages 212 to 217, Act 1897), in the following particulars, to wit: To repeal of said 1897 Act section two, relating to the manner of passing and signing city ordinances; section four, relative to amendment of section forty-three of the original city charter; section five, creating the office of city marshal; all of section six (6) which relates to the amendment of section fifty-eight of the said original charter; section seven, relative to the duties of city assessor; section eight, relative to the repeal of section fifty of the original charter; section twenty, which amends section six of the original charter; section twenty-two, relative to the compensation of city officers; to repeal the following sections of the original charter, viz.: section four, relative to the manner of filling vacancies in city offices; section ten, relative to the power of the mayor to sign or veto ordinances and resolutions; section fifty-two, relative to the manner of issuing city warrants; sections sixty-three and seventy-three, relative to the powers and duties of the recorder; to amend the following sections of said original charter, viz.: section nineteen, relative to the manner of passing and signing city ordinances; section twelve, relative to filling vacancies in city offices; section forty-three, specifying the officers of said city; section forty-five, relative to the manner of election or appointment of certain city officers; section ninety, defining the qualifications of voters at city elections; section seventy-eight, defining the powers and duties of the chief of police relative to city tax sales; to abolish the office of recorder and to create a mayor's court, and to define its powers and duties; to authorize the council to provide for the compensation of city officers and to limit the compensation that may be so provided, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the following section of an Act of the Georgia Assembly of 1897, to amend the charter of the city of Fitzgerald, in the county of
Irwin, which amending Act was approved December 14, 1897, and is contained on pages 212 to 217 of the 1897 Acts of Georgia General Assembly, to wit: section two, relative to the manner of passing city ordinances; section four, relating to the amendment of section forty-three of the original charter of said city; section five, relating to the office of city marshal; all that part of section six which seeks to amend section fifty-eight of the original city charter; section seven, relative to the assessment of property for city taxes; section eight, which repeals section fifty of the said original charter of said city; section twenty, which amends section six of the original charter, and section twenty-two (22), relating to the compensation of city officers, be, and the same are, hereby each repealed. Fitzgerald. Amendments to charter repealed.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section four of the original city charter of the city of Fitzgerald, the same being an Act of the Georgia Assembly, passed and approved by the Governor December 2, 1896, entitled: An Act to incorporate the city of Fitzgerald, in the county of Irwin, and for other purposes, and contained in 1896 Acts of General Assembly of Georgia, on pages 157 to 183, which section relates to the manner of filling a vacancy in the office of mayor, be, and the same is, hereby repealed. Section 4 of original charter repealed.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section numbered ten of said original charter of Act of 1896, relating to the duties of the mayor in reference to city ordinances, and section nineteen, relative to the manner of passing city ordinances, and the vetoing of same by the mayor, be, and the same are, each hereby repealed, and in lieu of said two repealed sections the following section is hereby enacted by the authority aforesaid: All ordinances shall be read twice, and one week shall intervene between the first and second reading. All ordinances shall, when passed, be deposited in the office of the city clerk, to enable the mayor to sign the same, and it shall be the duty of the mayor to sign all ordinances and resolutions within one day (Sundays excepted) after same have been passed by the council. All resolutions shall be spread in full upon the minutes of the council. No ordinance shall take effect until it has been published once in the official paper of the city, and it is hereby made the duty of the city clerk to cause such publications to be made in the first issue of the official paper after the time for the signing the ordinance has elapsed, or the first issue after such ordinance has been signed. The failure by the mayor to sign any ordinance or resolution shall in no wise affect its validity. The clerk shall record
in a book to be provided by the council, and kept for that purpose, all ordinances passed by the council. It shall be the duty of the clerk to attach to each ordinance as soon as passed a certificate under his official signature and the seal of said city, which certificate shall state that the ordinance was adopted by the council on a certain date, naming it, and shall state the names of the aldermen voting for or against it. All ordinances so passed or certified, or certified copies of such ordinances, shall be receivable as evidence in any courts of this State. Ordinances, how passed

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section twelve of said original charter of said city, to wit, said Act of 1896, relative to the manner of filling vacancies in certain city offices, be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: Strike said section entire, except the enacting clause, and substitute in place thereof these words: That if any vacancy shall occur in any city office which is elective by the voters of said city, except members of the board of education, the same shall be filled by election by the city council until the next regular annual election of said city. Vacancies.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section forty-three of said original charter, to wit: Said Act of 1896, which section enumerates the city officers of said city, be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows, to wit: Strike all of said section after the enacting clause, and in place thereof substitute these words, viz.: The officers of said city shall consist of a mayor, one alderman at large, two aldermen from each ward of the city, a city clerk, a city treasurer, a city attorney, a city assessor, a street commissioner, a city engineer; provided, however, that the city council may by ordinance create such other city offices as may be deemed necessary, and may by ordinance provide for the manner of filling such offices, and the terms and compensation of the officers. Officers.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the section of said original charter number forty-five, and relating to the manner of electing certain city officers, be amended so that when amended it shall read as follows: Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all officers provided for in section forty-five shall be elected by the city council for a period of two years, except where a different method of election and term of office is specially provided for in this charter. Officers elected by city council.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section number fifty of said original city charter, to wit: said Act of 1896 incorporating said city, which section relates to the duties
of the city treasurer, and which section was repealed by mistake by section number eight of an Act to amend the said city charter, passed by the General Assembly, and approved December 14, 1897, and which repealing section is found on page 214 of said 1897 Acts of the Georgia General Assembly, be, and the same is, hereby re-enacted and made a part of said city charter. Treasurer.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section number fifty-two of said original charter, to wit, the Act of 1896, relating to the issuing of city warrants, be, and the same is, hereby repealed. City warrants.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section sixty-three and seventy-three of said original charter, to wit, the said Act of 1896, relating to the powers and duties of the recorder of said city, be, and the same are, hereby repealed, and in place thereof there is hereby enacted by the authority aforesaid the following section, to wit: That for the trial of offences against the city laws, there is hereby created a police court, to be known as the mayor's court, over which it shall be the duty of the mayor of said city to preside. In the absence or disability of the mayor it shall be the duty of the president of the council to preside over said court, and when both are absent or unable to act, the vice-president of the council shall preside. It shall be the duty of said court to hear, try and determine all offences against the city laws, and of such cases said court shall have exclusive jurisdiction, except where otherwise provided by general law of this State. All fines collected by the mayor's court shall be paid into the city treasury, and shall be placed to the credit of the salary fund of said city. Mayor's court.

Sec. X. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That each and every of the sections of said Act of 1896, incorporating the said city, referring to the recorder of said city, be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: Strike from each of said sections, wherever same appears, the word recorder and substitute the word mayor. Office of recorder abolished.

Sec. XI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section 78 of said original incorporating Act of 1896, for said city, which section relates to the powers and duties of the chief of police, be amended by adding to the end of said section the following: All sales of property for delinquent city taxes due to said city shall be advertised, and conducted by the chief of police of said city, and said officer shall have the power and authority to make deeds and deliver the same to any purchasers at such tax sales, and to collect moneys bid at such sales, and receipt for same,
and all moneys so collected by such officer shall be paid by him into the city treasury, and he shall file the treasurer's receipt therefor with the city clerk. Tax sales.

Sec. XII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section ninety of said original incorporating Act for said city defining the qualifications of voters of said city, be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: Strike from the third line of said section the words sixty days and in place thereof substitute the words six months. Qualification of voters.

Sec. XIII.
