Be it likewise enacted, That said dispensary shall be maintained exclusively from the profits arising from the same; provided, that the council may appropriate from time to time such amounts as may be necessary to maintain said dispensary, from the other public funds, such amounts to be returned out of the first profits thereafter derived from said dispensary. How maintained.

Sec. XLV. Be it likewise enacted, That said commissioners shall make quarterly reports to the mayor and council of said town, showing amount of sales, disbursements and net profits thereof. That said council shall appropriate the profits thereof to the payment of current expenses of said town, and to public schools located in said town; provided, at least 25 per cent. of the profits thereof shall be appropriated to the use of the schools thereof. Reports of commissioners. Profits.

Sec. XLVI. Be it further enacted, That said dispensary commissioners shall not receive a sum as salary in excess of twentyfive dollars each per annum; and for any neglect or malpractice in office shall be discharged and removed from said office by said mayor and council. They shall receive no subsidies or presents of goods, liquors or merchandise, or other thing of value from prospective sellers to said dispensary to influence them in making purchases for the same. Compensation of commissioners.

Sec. XLVII. Be it further enacted, That said dispensary may be suspended or discontinued at any time by a vote of a majority of the voters in said town, at an election called by the council after two weeks' notice. Suspension

Sec. XLVIII. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed; provided, that all ordinances now in force shall be continued as under the old charter at the will of the council unless in conflict, and then this charter shall take effect until January 1, 1899. Except that the registration books may be opened immediately after the passage thereof for the next regular election; provided, that there shall be no registration of voters required under this charter for the election of mayor and councilmen for the year 1899. Repealing clause.

law.shorttitle: LEESBURG DISPENSARY.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the town of Leesburg in the county of Lee, State of Georgia, so as to authorize and empower the mayor and council of said town to maintain a dispensary in said town for the sale of ardent spirits, malt liquors, wines, ciders and other intoxicants; to provide regulations for the management of said dispensary, the appointment of managers, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That from and after the passage of this Act the charter of the town of Leesburg, Ga., be amended so as to authorize and empower the mayor and council of said town to maintain and operate a dispensary in said town for the sale of ardent spirits, malt liquors, wines, ciders and other intoxicants, as hereinafter provided. Leesburg Dispensary.

Sec. II. Be it enacted likewise, That at the first regular meeting of council after the passage of this Act, or as soon as practicable thereafter, said mayor and council may elect three persons, qualified voters of said town, of good moral character and business capacity, who shall be known as dispensary commissioners, one to hold office for one year, one for two years and one for three years or until their successors are elected and qualified as hereinafter provided. At the first regular meeting of council in each succeeding municipal year thereafter, or as soon thereafter as practicable, said mayor and council shall elect a successor to the dispensary commissioner whose term of office is about to expire, and each of said subsequently elected dispensary commissioners shall hold office for three years or until their successors are elected and qualified; vacancies occurring from any cause in the office of said dispensary commissioners shall be filled at once by the said mayor and council in the same manner as in the regular elections, and the officers elected to fill such vacancies shall hold office only for the unexpired terms of their predecessors. The dispensary commissioners provided for by this Act shall, before entering upon the discharge of their duties as such, take and subscribe an oath that they will faithfully and honestly discharge all the duties imposed upon them by this Act and the ordinances of said town, said oath to be administered by the mayor and entered upon the minutes of council. Commissioners.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That the dispensary commissioners
may maintain at some central point in the town of Leesburg, a dispensary for the sale of ardent spirits, malt liquors, wines, ciders and other intoxicants. They shall, on the day after their election and qualification and annually thereafter, elect a manager for said dispensary, who shall be of good moral character and sober habits, to be known as dispensary manager, who shall have charge and control of said dispensary under their supervision. Said manager shall be chosen for one year, but shall be removable at any time by said commissioners for neglect of duty or violation of law. Said manager shall be required to take and subscribe such oath and give bond for his faithful discharge of duty, and to account for all moneys, stock, merchandise or other thing of value belonging to said town and that may come into his hands as such manager. Said bond to be fixed by the mayor and council. Vacancies occurring in said office shall be filled for unexpired term as in regular election. Manager.

Sec. IV. Be it likewise enacted, That said manager shall, under the direction of said commissioners, purchase and keep for sale a stock of ardent spirits, wines, ciders, malt liquors and other intoxicants in such quantities as said commissioners may direct; all bills incurred in the operation of said dispensary shall be approved by a majority of said commissioners and countersigned by the mayor or mayor pro tem. and paid as other accounts against said town. A separate account of the operations of said dispensary shall be kept by the clerk of said town. Said manager shall sell only for cash, shall not sell in quantities less than one-half pint, shall not sell in other than sealed packages, bottles or other receptacles; shall allow no drinking on the dispensary premises, shall not open said dispensary before sunrise nor close the same later than sundown. He shall turn over all cash received by him at least once a week and take the treasurer's receipt for the same. He shall be bound by all State laws relating to the sale of liquors, and such ordinances as may be enacted, not in conflict with said laws; he shall likewise be bound by all needful rules and regulations of said dispensary commissioners. He shall report not later than once each month to said commissioners, showing amount of sales and stock on hand on the last day of said month. Stock. Management.

Sec. V. Said manager shall allow no one to loiter in or about said dispensary premises, and for failure to comply with this section he shall be removed from office; and any person who, after being notified, refuses to comply with said notice to leave said premises shall be fined in the discretion of the mayor. Loitering.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted, That said dispensary shall be
maintained from the profits arising therefrom; provided, the mayor and council may appropriate such sums as may be necessary to supply casual deficiencies; such amounts so appropriated to be returned out of the first profits of said dispensary to the town treasury. How maintained.

Sec. VII. Be it enacted further, That said commissioners shall make a full and complete report to the mayor and council once each quarter showing receipts, disbursements, expenditures, stock on hand and condition of said dispensary. Reports of commissioners.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted, That the profits arising from said dispensary shall be appropriated to the payment of the ordinary current expenses of said town and public improvements and to aid public schools in said town, both white and colored, provided at least 25 per cent. of said profits shall be devoted to schools. Profits, how applied.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted, That said commissioners shall receive a salary to be fixed by the council, and in case of neglect of duty or malpractice in office shall be dealt with as council may provide by ordinance. Salary. Malfeasance.

Sec. X. Be it further enacted, That the commissioners and the mayor and council shall have power to pass all lawful orders and ordinances to carry this Act into effect, and to provide penalties for a violation of the provisions thereof by the manager or other persons. Control.

Sec. XI. Be it further enacted, That said dispensary may be abolished by council after a vote of a majority of the qualified voters of said town whenever the same shall fail to be self-sustaining and pay the expenses of maintenance thereof; provided, said election shall be advertised by publication thirty days and conducted as elections for council; provided further, that sufficient time shall be given to close out said dispensary with as little loss to said town as possible. How abolished.
Sec. XII. Be it enacted further, That all Acts, laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: LUMPKIN, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle:
An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to incorporate the town of Lumpkin in Stewart county, Georgia, assented to December 26, 1831, and the various Acts amendatory thereof, so as to provide
for the election of the marshal of said town by the city council of said town; to change the term of mayor from one to two years; to provide for the election of a mayor pro tem. to change the number of aldermen from five to six, and to change their term of office from one to two years, three to be elected each year, and for other purposess.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, the charter of the town of Lumpkin, in the county of Stewart, said State, and the Acts amendatory thereof be amended so as to provide that the election of the marshal of said town shall be by the aldermen composing the city council of said town at the first meeting of said aldermen after they have been duly qualified as provided in the charter of said town, and that the term of said marshal so elected by said aldermen shall be for one year, and that said marshal shall be subject to removal by said aldermen for a failure to discharge his official duties as required by law. Lumpkin. Marshal.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That the term of office of the mayor of said town be changed from one to two years, said change to take place from and after the first election held after the passage of this Act and the approval of the Governor of the same. Mayor, term of.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That the aldermen of said town shall elect one of the aldermen of said town as mayor pro tem. who shall have all the powers of mayor in the absence of said mayor, both as presiding officer, and in the discharge of his duties in the trial of offenses and enforcing fines or imprisonment for violations of the ordinances of said town. That said mayor pro tem. shall be elected at the same time, and in the same manner as the marshal above provided for, and that his term of office shall be for one year as said mayor pro tem. Mayor pro tem.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, That the number of aldermen be changed from five to six, and that their term of office be for two years instead of one year, as now provided under the existing charter of said town. That three of said aldermen be elected each year. That said change shall take effect at the first election after the passage and approval of this Act, at which election three of said aldermen shall be voted for for a term of one year and three for two years, and that at each subsequent election three be elected for the full term of two years. Number of aldermen. Terms of office.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That all laws conflicting with
the provisions of this Act be repealed, and the same are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: LYERLY, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to incorporate the town of Lyerly in Chattooga county, State of Georgia, and for other purposes, by changing in said Act the number of section eight to number nine, and by inserting a new section in said Act numbered section eight and providing in said new section for a public fund by the levy and collection of an ad valorem tax, other taxes, license other than license to sell intoxicating liquors and fines and forfeitures.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That an Act entitled an Act to incorporate the town of Lyerly in Chattooga county, State of Georgia, and for other purposes, be amended by changing the number of section eight of said Act to number nine, and inserting in lieu of section eight of said Act, a new section, which shall read as follows, granting to said corporation the rights, powers and privileges as in said new section set out: Lyerly.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted by authority of the same, That the public fund of said town shall be made up of an ad valorem tax on all the property in said town subject to state tax, street tax, license other than for the sale of spirituous or intoxicating liquors, which shall not be granted, tax on dogs and fines and forfeitures, all of which the council of said town may levy and collect, in any sum and under any rules and ordinances not contrary to the Constitution and laws of said State. At the first annual meeting of the new council after each election, or as soon thereafter as practicable, the council shall levy said tax and fix said license, and the same shall be entered on the minutes. When on account of default, an execution is issued and levied on real estate, the same shall be advertised in the town of Lyerly at some public place and also in the newspaper in said county in which sheriff's advertisements are published, and sold before the court-house door in said county, by the marshal of said town, as
sheriff's sales are made. Executions may be issued, not only against the person defaulting, but against property, specially, and as against property not returned, the same may be doubly assessed. The mayor of said town is authorized to bid in such property for said town, provided the same sells for no sum greater than the cost and tax. The owner of any real estate sold for taxes may redeem the same within two years of the sale by paying all costs and taxes, and twenty per cent. interest on the sum at which the same was sold. Taxes, how laid. How collected. Redemption.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted That all laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: MARIETTA, REGISTRATION OF VOTERS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the city of Marietta and to enact and prescribe a system for registration of voters at the municipal election thereof, to prescribe for the appointment of registrars and to declare who are qualified voters at said election, and to make and prescribe penalties for violating all such laws, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. The General Assembly of the State of Georgia do enact, That from and after the passage of this Act, there shall be established a system of registration for the city of Marietta, in the county of Cobb in said State. Marietta. Registration.

Sec. II. Three registrars shall be elected for said city and shall serve for a term of two years. They shall be elected by the following officers of Cobb county, to wit: clerk of the superior court, ordinary, sheriff, tax collector and tax receiver. It shall require a majority of said officers voting in favor of any registrars to elect them, and they shall be upright and intelligent freeholders of said city and entitled to register and vote. If any registrar elected shall fail to serve said county officers shall elect another in his place. Registrars, election of.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That said registrars, before entering upon their duties, shall take and subscribe the following oath: I do solemnly swear that I will faithfully and impartially discharge to the best of my ability the duties imposed
upon me by law as city registrar. Said oath shall be filed with the clerk of council and record, together with a minute of how the registrars were elected. Said registrars shall be elected between the first and tenth days of October of the year in which the election for Mayor and Council occurs by law. Neither of said registrars shall be a candidate for Mayor or Councilmen at the next election, nor for any office under them, and the fact that any person has acted as registrar shall disqualify him from being elected to any such office during the next term of such office. Oath. When elected. Cannot hold other city office.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, That a majority of such registrars shall be competent to transact all business, but in case of difference between them, the third registrar shall be called in to decide. Public notice shall be given of the time and place of registration at least one week before the books are open, both in the city official organ and by handbills. Said registrars shall keep the registration books open at the council chamber for six days between the 20th day of October and the 5th day of November from 6 o'clock in the morning until 5 o'clock p. m. Said days need not be consecutive if notice is given beforehand what days said registrars will sit. During the sittings of the registrars, the marshal shall make public proclamation at the court-house door of the opening and closing of their session each day. Said registrars, or either of them, shall be authorized to administer all oaths, issue subp[oelig]nas for all witnesses and hear and determine all questions that may arise in the discharge of their duties. Notice of registration. Books of. Marshal. Authority of registrars

Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That the clerk of council shall previously prepare all books or lists, voters' oaths and blanks that may be required by law in making and carrying out said registration. Books, etc.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted, That the qualification of voters in said city shall be the same as specified in section 32, vol. 1 of the Code of Georgia of 1895, with the addition that the voter must have paid all city taxes since the adoption of the Constitution of 1877, except for the year in which he proposes to register and vote, and must have been, bona fide, a resident of said city for six months immediately preceding the next city election. Qualifications of voters.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted, That the method of registering on voters' book, or if subscribing voters' oaths to be posted in a book, as prescribed in the Code of Georgia of of 1895, vol. 1, sections Nos. 40, 41, 42, 43, 44 and 45
shall be followed except that the registrars herein provided shall take the place of the tax collector and his clerk. The oath to be subscribed by the voter shall be the same as prescribed in section 36, vol. 1, of the Code of Georgia, except that instead of the last sentence the following shall be substituted: I do further swear or affirm that I have resided in the city of Marietta for six months immediately preceding the date of this oath, or will have so resided on theday ofof this calendar year; and that my age is, that my occupation isand my place of residence is. That I have been a resident of Cobb countyyears. That I have been a resident of the State of Georgiayears. Said blanks shall be properly filled and the oath signed by the voter and dated. The registrars shall note whether white or colored, and any fact of identification. No person totally unknown to the registrars and to the city marshal shall be allowed to register until he produces proof of residence in the city. Registry, how made.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted, That the registrars shall identify each voters' oath by their signatures or stamp, and number the same as taken consecutively, from one up. A list of the names shall be taken down by the clerks of council, or by some one appointed for that purpose, as the voters sign the oath, and numbered to correspond with the numbers on the oaths. As soon as the time for registration has expired said registrars shall make out and file with the clerk of council an alphabetical list of all registered voters, giving name, age, occupation, color and residence, which shall be open to the inspection of all persons interested, but shall not be removed or taken from the custody of the clerk. The voters' books or oaths shall be securely sealed up, plainly marked on the outside and signed on the outside by the registrars and deposited with the ordinary each night for safe keeping. Duty of registrars

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted, That said registrars shall appoint a time not less than five nor more than ten days after the completion of the taking of registration oaths when they, in open session in the council chamber, will hear all complaints. When complaint is made that any voter has registered who was not entitled by law to do so, he shall have two days' personal notice if in the city, and if not in the city, then two days' notice by leaving copy at his residence of the time and place of hearing and of the grounds of challenge, and the registrars shall sit as a court to review said case, subp[oelig]na witnesses, hear evidence, and determine whether in law such names should remain
or be stricken. They shall also hear complaints of any one who has been refused registration, hear evidence and determine whether such applicants should be allowed to register. Said registrars may, on their own motion, review their work, but any voter affected, must be notified and have an opportunity to be heard as before provided. All their actions in revising the list of voters must be in public in the council chamber. In making said registration lists and in revising their work, the registrars shall examine the grounds of disqualification of voters, including criminal records, insolvent tax lists, tax digests, tax execution dockets and tax executions. Complaints before registrars, how heard and determined.

Sec. X. Be it further enacted, That after said registrars have fully reviewed their work and revised the registration list to make it conform to the truth under the law, they shall carefully and plainly make out two alphabetical lists, exactly the same, giving name, age, occupation, color and residence of each voter and shall certify to the correctness of each list, and date and sign the same officially. One copy they shall file with the clerk of council for the inspection of all parties concerned. The other copy they shall securely seal, plainly mark and sign on the outside officially and deliver to the ordinary for safe keeping until the day of election. The voters' oaths after being deposited each night with the ordinary for safe keeping may be withdrawn each day while said registrars are sitting and opened by them in public, but must be sealed by them at the close of their session in public and delivered back to the ordinary for safe keeping. When said list of registered voters is revised and completed, said voters' oaths or voters' books shall be in the same manner sealed and delivered to the ordinary for safe keeping until after the next city election. The marshal or his deputy or any party may serve all summonses, subp[oelig]nas, notices or other papers required in the hearing before the registrars. Lists of voters. Voters' oaths, how kept.

Sec. XI. Be it further enacted, That on the morning of any city election day the ordinary or the registrars before the opening of the polls, shall furnish to the election managers the sealed list of registered voters, which was deposited with said ordinary. When organized, ready for receiving votes, said managers shall break the seal and use said list in said election, and shall not permit any person to vote whose name is not on said list. Said managers shall plainly mark or check each name as voted. After said election said registry list shall be sealed up, distinctly marked and signed on the outside by the
managers officially and returned to the ordinary for safe keeping. He shall keep the same until the council then elected shall go out of office. If there shall be within the next two years any special election for mayor or councilmen to fill an unexpired term, said registry list shall be used at such election in the same way, the managers using a different check mark. After such special election such registry list shall be sealed and returned to the ordinary in the manner before stated. Said ordinary shall produce said list to the court trying any contest or any other court when the same may be legally required. When the occasion for such production is ended, said list shall be returned to the ordinary. After keeping said list for two years the ordinary shall turn over the same, together with the voters' oaths, to the city court to be filed away and preserved by them. List of voters to managers Its return. Special elections.

Sec. XII. Be it further enacted, That any person who shall register illegally under this Act, or be guilty of a violation of any of the provisions of section 625 of the Penal Code of Georgia of 1895 in registering under this Act, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Illegal registry.
Sec. XIII. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of said city shall have power and authority to fix the compensation of registrars and to pay the same. Compensation of registrars.

Sec. XIV. Be it further enacted, That at any election of any of the officers of said city of Marietta, no person shall be permitted within fifty feet of any polling place except voters approaching the polls for the purpose of voting, the election managers and clerks, county or municipal officers called in by the managers to preserve order and persons passing along the highways on their business. Polls.

Sec. XV. Be it further enacted, That it shall be unlawful for any person or persons to electioneer or in any way to influence or try to influence any voter or speak to him on the subject of voting within fifty feet of the voting place. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the managers of the polls in the discharge of their duty as such; provided, they do not electioneer or try to influence any voter in any particular way. Electioneering at polls.

Sec. XVI. Be it further enacted, That it shall be unlawful for any person or persons to lead or carry a voter to the polls or accompany or follow him, either to influence his vote or to see how he votes, or to see that he votes in any particular way. Freedom of voters.

Sec. XVII. Be it further enacted, That any person or persons who shall in any manner violate either or any of the provisions
of sections 14, 15 and 16 of this Act shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be punished as prescribed in section 1039 in the Criminal Code of Georgia of 1895. Penalty.
Sec. XVIII. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: MACON, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the city of Macon, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the XXII. section of the charter of the city of Macon, appearing in the Act approved November 21, 1893, which section prescribes the term of office and the duties of the mayor and which was amended by the Act approved December 13, 1895, shall be amended by striking therefrom the words appearing in said amended Act, as follows: He may be elected to a second term of two years, but shall not be eligible for a third term till the expiration of two years from the end of said second term, so that when said Act is so amended the disabilities provided in said Act shall be removed and the mayor shall be eligible to succeed himself. Macon. Mayor may succeed himself.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section XXIII. of said Act, approved November 21, 1893, be amended by striking from said section the words as follows: They shall be ineligible to succeed themselves or to hold any other city office until the expiration of two years from the end of the term for which they were respectively elected, so that when said Act is so amended the disabilities provided in said Act shall be removed and the aldermen of the city of Macon shall be eligible to succeed themselves and to hold any other city office to which they may be elected or appointed. Aldermen may succeed themselves.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section II. of the Act of the legislature approved December 11 1897, be amended as follows: by striking out the word two'
after the word for and before the word years in the ninth line of section II. of said Act, on page 200 of the Acts of the legislature of 1897, and inserting in lieu thereof the word three, so as to provide that the four aldermen elected from each of the four wards in December, 1897, shall serve for the term of three years, as was intended to be provided in said Act. Terms of aldermen.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor and council of the city of Macon shall have full power and authority to require any railroad company or any street railroad company, whose tracks shall cross any of the streets of the city of Macon by any overhead bridge or structure, to drain, curb and pave the entire width and length of said street extending three feet beyond said track or tracks for the entire space covered by and between said tracks and three feet on each side of the abutments or trestle supporting said track or tracks, at such time and in such manner and with such materials as the mayor and council of the city of Macon may prescribe; and in the event that any railroad company shall fail to grade, curb or pave any street or portion thereof as herein provided, within thirty days from the passage of any ordinance requiring said work to be done, then the mayor and council shall have authority to proceed at once to do such work at the expense of the railroad company and collect the cost of doing such work in the same manner as now provided for the collection of assessments for street drainage, grading, curbing and paving. Railroads and street railroads to pave street crossings.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That said Act, approved November 21, 1895, and amended by the Act approved December 13, 1895, be amended by striking from the IV. section of said Act, and the Acts amendatory thereof, the words Saturday and inserting the word Tuesday, so that all elections for mayor and aldermen of the city of Macon shall occur on the second Tuesday in December of such years as are provided. Election days.
Sec. VI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: MILLEDGEVILLE, SYSTEM FOR WORKING STREETS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to establish a system for working the streets, lanes and alleys in the city of Milledgeville, and the fixing and levying of a commutation tax in lieu of the street work; to provide penalty for failure to work on the streets of said city or to pay the commutation tax; also, to provide the manner for working said streets and the collection of said tax in lieu of the street work; also of classifying and defining who shall be subject to the street duty or work, or the payment of said tax; the time and manner of giving notice to those who are subject to street work or tax, and for issuing warrants against the defaulters, their trial, conviction, sentence, etc.; to authorize the mayor and aldermen of said city to enact all such ordinances, rules or regulations as shall be necessary for the purposes of carrying into effect the provisions of this Act, and the establishment of said system of working the streets of said city, and the collecting of the commutation tax, as provided for in this Act, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, every male citizen of the city of Milledgeville between the ages of sixteen and fifty years shall be subject and bound to do and perform street duty or work in and upon the streets of said city, or to pay a commutation tax in lieu of such street work, as hereinafter provided; the mayor and aldermen of said city shall have the authority and power to compel all such citizens to work on the streets of said city for a term of not more than ten days in each year, or to levy and collect from all such citizens a commutation tax in lieu of said work; the amount of said commutation tax to be fixed by said mayor and aldermen, but in no event shall they fix said amount at more than three dollars for each year; the said mayor and aldermen of said city shall be authorized and empowered to levy said tax, or require said street work to be done at such time in each year as they may deem conducive to the best interest of said city. Milledgeville. Street hands. Commutation tax.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That any person or persons who shall be subject to work on the streets of said city or to pay the commutation tax, who after being properly notified or summoned to work on the streets of said city, or the payment of said tax, and
shall fail or refuse to obey said notice or summons, or to pay the tax in lieu of said work or who shall fail, refuse, or neglect to carry the implements, tools, etc., as notified or ordered, or appearing with or without such tools, implements, etc., neglects or refuses faithfully to work, shall be deemed guilty of violating the provisions of this Act, and upon trial and conviction shall be punished as hereinafter provided. Refusal to work or pay tax made penal

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That thirty days continuous residence within the corporate limits of said city shall constitute one a resident citizen of said city, so as to subject him to the liability to work the streets of said city, or to pay the said commutation tax in lieu thereof. Residents.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and aldermen of said city shall have the power and authority to designate and require any policeman of said city, or elect any person or persons to serve the notices or summons upon all such person or persons as may be subject to street duty or work or said commutation tax, and that the person so elected, or policeman so designated, shall give to each person who shall be subject to such street work or tax, at least one day's notice of the time and place to meet the street overseer or the chairman of the street committee, so that said person or persons may begin work on said streets; said person or persons shall be given notice at the same time what kind or character of tools or implements he shall produce or use for the purpose of working said streets. Notice of work required.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That when any person or persons shall be subject to such street work, or the payment of said tax, shall fail or refuse to pay said tax, or to appear, or after appearing, fail or refuse to faithfully work upon the said streets as directed by the proper authority, such person or persons shall be deemed a street defaulter and violator of the provisions of this Act, and upon trial and conviction shall be punished as hereinafter provided; provided, however, that when such person or persons shall fail or refuse to work upon said street or to pay said tax as aforesaid, when properly notified or summoned so to do, any policeman, marshal, or any other person employed by said city to perform said duty, or any alderman of said city, shall be, and he is, hereby authorized and empowered to swear out a warrant before the mayor of said city, against any such street work or tax defaulter, charging said defaulter with the offense of being a street or tax defaulter; and that said policeman, marshal, or such other persons employed by said city, shall be authorized and empowered to arrest said street or tax defaulter and have him tried before the proper city official as hereinafter provided;
said defaulter shall have the right to give bail for his appearance at such time and place for trial as may be designated by the mayor or the arresting officer. Defaulters. Arrests.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted, That the mayor of said city of Milledgeville shall be, and he is, hereby clothed with full power to try any such person or persons who shall be charged with the violating of any of the provisions of this Act, or being a street or tax defaulter, just as he has jurisdiction and the power to try any case of the violation of any city ordinance; provided, however, that the right of appeal shall lie to board of aldermen of said city, just as provided for the trial of offenses for violating any city ordinance. Trial.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted, That any person or persons who shall, after trial and conviction of violating any of the provisions of this Act, shall be fined by the mayor (or the board of aldermen in case of an appeal) to do and perform hard labor in the chain-gang of said city, upon the streets of said city, for a period or term of not more than fifteen days in each year, or to pay a fine in lieu of said work on said streets in said chain-gang in a sum of not more than fifty cents per day for each of the days he refuses to work or was a street or tax defaulter, and all the costs of prosecution, trial and conviction. Penalty.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and aldermen of said city shall have the right and authority in addition to the issuing of a warrant, the trial and conviction of any street or tax defaulter, to issue against said defaulter a tax execution for the amount of said commutation tax, and the same shall be a lien upon all the property of such defaulter, with the same priorities, dignity and effect as any other municipal tax execution issued by them; and that the trial, conviction and serving of the sentence by such defaulter shall not relieve him from the payment of said commutation tax, unless he has worked a sufficient time upon the streets to have discharged the amount of said tax fixed by ordinance, and all the costs incident to, and connected therewith, at the rate of fifty cents per day for each day of his term of service. Executions

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and aldermen of said city shall have authority to enact all such ordinances, rules and regulations that may become necessary, from time to time, to carry into full force and effect the provisions of this Act, and the further perfecting and completing a system of street work, duty and tax. Powers of mayor and aldermen.
Sec. X. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: MONROE, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the city of Monroe (Acts 1896, p. 212), so as to provide for the erection and equipment of a school building in said city, and for the issue of bonds to pay for the same, and to amend the charter of said city, in other particulars, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That the mayor and council of the city of Monroe shall provide for an election to be held in said city within sixty days after the passage of this Act, by giving thirty days' notice thereof immediately preceding said election, as is now provided by law, to determine whether school bonds shall be issued by said city in the manner now provided by law. Said election shall be held and returns thereof made in the same manner as elections are held for mayor and council of said city, and the qualifications of voters in said election shall be the same as in other elections provided under the charter of said city. All persons voting in said election who favor the issuing of school bonds shall have written or printed on their ballots For issuing bonds, and all persons voting in said election who oppose issuing said school bonds shall have written or printed on their ballots Against issuing bonds. Monroe. Election for. School bonds.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall declare the result of said election, and if it be found that two-thirds of the qualified voters of said city have voted in favor of issuing bonds, said mayor and council shall be authorized to issue school bonds as aforesaid, and to provide for the payment of the same, under the conditions hereinafter prescribed. And if it be found that the requisite two-thirds of the qualified voters of said city have not voted for the issuing of said bonds, then said mayor and council may call another election after one year has elapsed from the election already provided for, and annually thereafter until said school bonds are authorized as aforesaid. Result of election.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That if authorized as aforesaid, the mayor and council of said city shall issue bonds of said city of Monroe, not to exceed the amount of ten thousand dollars, to run not exceeding thirty years, bearing interest at a rate not to exceed six per cent. per annum, payable annually at such time as the mayor and council may determine. Said bonds to be issued in amounts
to be determined by the mayor and council of said city, and the same shall be signed by the mayor and countersigned by the clerk of council, and shall have coupons attached for each installment of interest, which coupons shall be signed and countersigned in the same manner as said bonds, and the principal of said bonds and the interest coupons shall be payable at maturity on presentation to the city treasurer. Said mayor and council are authorized to negotiate the sale of said bonds, or such portion thereof as they may deem necessary for the erection and equipment of a school building in said city, and the purchase of real estate for a suitable site therefor. Bonds. Sale of.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, That for the purpose of providing for the payment of the principal and interest of said bonds so issued and negotiated, when the same shall become due, said mayor and council may set apart from the funds annually raised by taxation in said city sufficient amounts to meet said payments. And said mayor and council are hereby required to levy and collect such tax upon the taxable property of said city as will be necessary to carry out the provisions of this Act, said tax not to exceed twenty-five cents on every one hundred dollars' worth of taxable property of every kind in said city, in addition to the tax authorized to be levied and collected as provided in section 22 of the charter of said city of Monroe, found in Acts of 1896, p. 218. Tax for payment of bonds.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council shall determine in what amounts said bonds shall be issued and paid, and when the principal shall be payable. And each of said bonds shall have printed on the face thereof the time when the same shall become due. How payable.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted, That within thirty days after said city shall have voted in favor of issuing such bonds, the mayor and council of said city shall elect a board of education, consisting of five freeholders, who are otherwise qualified to hold office in said city. The members of said board of education shall be elected biennially thereafter by the mayor and council of said city, who shall also immediately fill all vacancies that may occur in said board at any time. That the proceeds arising from the sale of said bonds shall be paid over by said mayor and council to said board of education, who shall expend and use the same in the purchase of a site for a school building and the erection and equipment of the same. And the title to all property so purchased or acquired shall vest in said board of education and their successors in office. And said board of education shall have control and direction of the schools to be conducted in said building, elect the teachers therefor,
and exercise all other acts of direction and control usually applicable to boards of education. Board of Education.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted, That the registration law found in section 8 of the charter of said city be, and the same is, hereby amended so as to read as follows: That the clerk of said city council shall keep a book in which the voters of said city shall register their names and ages, or if such person who desires to register cannot write his name, the clerk shall sign his name for him in said book, after the applicant has read, or the clerk has read to him, the following oath written or printed in said book, the person swearing and subscribing to the same: I do solemnly swear that I am 21 years of age, or will be by the time of the election next to be held in said city; I have resided in the State of Georgia twelve months, or will have resided in said State twelve months by the time of said election; I have resided in the city of Monroe six months, or will have resided in said city of Monroe six months by the time of said election; I have paid all taxes required of me by said city, and am otherwise qualified to vote in said election. If the clerk of council be sick, absent, or otherwise prevented, the mayor may appoint some person to perform the duties of clerk provided in this section. Registration of voters.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted, That section 31 of the charter of said city (Acts 1896, p. 221) be amended to read as follows: That the mayor's court of said city shall have full power and authority, upon conviction of any person for a violation of any of the laws of said city, to sentence such person to labor on the steets or any other works of said city for a period not exceeding one hundred days, or to be imprisoned in the city prison or other place of confinement in said city for a period not exceeding fifty days, or to impose a fine not exceeding one hundred dollars; either one or all of said penalties may be inflicted for any offence in the discretion of said court. Penalties.
Section IX. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: NEWTON, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act incorporating the town of Newton, Georgia, approved January 20th, 1872, and the Act amendatory thereof, approved December 15th, 1897, so as to change the time of payment of street tax in said town; to provide for the working of persons upon the streets of said town for the non-payment of fines imposed by the mayor or council of said town, and to increase the license fee or tax imposed upon dealers in intoxicating liquors in said town, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That the above recited Act incorporating the town of Newton in Baker county, Georgia, approved January 20th, 1872, and the Act amendatory thereof, approved December 15th, 1897, be, and the same is, hereby amended as hereinafter provided. Newton.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That the street tax imposed by the council of said town upon persons residing therein who are subject to road duty, shall become due and payable on the first day of April of each year instead of October as now provided by law. Street tax.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That for the non-payment of fines imposed by the mayor or council of said town, such mayor shall have power and authority to cause such person so failing or refusing to pay said fine to be worked upon the streets of said town for not exceeding thirty days. Non-payment of fines punishable-

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, That the license fee or tax imposed by said council upon persons engaged in the sale of intoxicating liquors in said town shall not exceed the sum of fifty dollars per annum. Liquor tax.
Section V. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: NEWMAN, BONDS FOR SEWERAGE.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the mayor and aldermen of the city of Newnan, in the county of Coweta and State of Georgia, to establish and maintain a system of sewerage and drainage for said city; to issue and sell bonds for the purpose of building said sewers and drains; to levy and collect a tax on all property in said city; to redeem said bonds and pay the interest that may accrue thereon; to provide for submitting the question of issuing said bonds to the qualified voters of said city; to authorize the condemnation of property, both in and out of the city; to empower the said mayor and aldermen to assess, not exceeding two-thirds the cost of constructing said sewers and drains, upon the real estate abutting on streets through and along which sewers and drains may be placed and constructed and upon any real estate through and upon which the same may be constructed or placed; to provide for the collecting of such assessments, and to do all things necessary and incident to the building and operation of said system of sewers and drains; and to fix the terms and conditions upon which connections may be made to said sewers by private parties, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That the mayor and aldermen of the city of Newnan be, and they are, hereby authorized and empowered to establish and maintain a system of sewerage and drainage for said city, and to issue and sell bonds for the purpose of building said system of sewers and drains, not to exceed in the aggregate thirty thousand dollars ($30,000,) of such denomination as the said mayor and aldermen may determine, to be due and payable at any time within thirty years after issue, as they, the said mayor and aldermen, may determine. The said bonds, when so issued, shall bear interest at not exceeding the rate of six per cent. per annum. Newnan. Sewerage, bonds for.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That it shall be the duty of said mayor and aldermen, and they are hereby empowered to assess and collect a tax upon the taxable property within the corporate limits of said city, sufficient to pay off said bonds, principal and interest, within thirty years, as they may become due, as provided in section one of this Act. Said bonds, or so much of them as may be necessary for the purposes for which they may be issued, shall be signed by the mayor and the clerk of council of said city of Newnan,
and shall be sold in such a manner as said mayor and aldermen may determine to be for the best interest of said city. Tax to pay.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and aldermen be, and hereby are authorized to condemn property for the purpose of constructing said sewerage, both in and out of said city of Newnan, under the same rules as prescribed for the condemnation of property for public roads in this State; to assess not exceeding two-thirds the cost of constructing said sewers and drains, upon real estate abutting on streets through and along which sewers and drains may be placed and constructed, and upon any real estate through or upon which the same may be constructed or placed; to provide for the collecting such assessments, and to do all things necessary and incident to the building and operation of said system of sewers and drains; to fix the terms and conditions upon which connections may be made to said sewers by private parties and other purposes. Condemnation. Assessments.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, That after the said bonds shall have been issued and sold as hereinbefore provided, it shall be the duty of said mayor and aldermen to apply the proceeds from the sale of said bonds to the building a system of sewerage and drainage, as said mayor and aldermen in their discretion may deem best for the health and public interest of said city. Proceeds of bonds, how applied.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That after the passage of this Act the mayor and aldermen of said city shall submit the question of issuing said bonds to an election, to be voted upon by the qualified voters of said city, on a day to be fixed by said mayor and aldermen. Notice of said election shall be given by advertising the same fifteen days before the election in the paper in which the legal advertising of Coweta county is done; said election to be held in the same manner and under the same rules prescribed by law for holding elections for members of the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, unless otherwise provided in this Act. Should the assent of two-thirds of such qualified voters voting at said election be received thereto, the provisions of this Act shall obtain and be of full force and effect, and said bonds shall be issued in pursuance thereto. Election for bonds.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted, That those who favor the issue and sale of said bonds, as set forth in this Act, shall have written or printed on their ballot For bonds, and those who are opposed to the issue and sale of said bonds, as set forth in this Act, shall have written or printed on their ballot Against bonds. Ballots.
Sec. VII. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: OCILLA, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the town of Ocilla in the county of Irwin, approved November 24th, 1897, so as to change and fix anew the boundaries and corporate limits of said town; to provide for the compensation of the officers of said town, and to limit the amount of compensation which may be paid; to provide for the election of certain town officers, and to authorize the town council to fix the time, place and manner of holding town elections and advertising same; to prescribe additional powers and duties of the mayor and marshal of said town; to authorize the town council to pass all needful and proper ordinances for the government of the town; to authorize it to determine and fix additional qualifications of voters at town elections; to provide a system of public schools; to create and elect a board of school trustees for government of said schools; to authorize the levy of a tax on the property within said town for the support and maintenance of said schools, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That section one (1) of the original charter of the town of Ocilla, in the county of Irwin, incorporating said town and describing its boundaries and limits, approved November 24th, 1897, be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows, to wit: Strike all of said section after the word whatever in the sixteenth line of said section, and insert in lieu of the part thus stricken the following words, to wit: The corporate boundaries and limits of said town shall be as follows: Beginning at the southwest corner of land lot number forty-two (42) in the 5th land district of Irwin county, and running north on the original west line of said lot to the north line of Second street in said town of Ocilla; thence west in land lot number 43 of said district, two hundred fifty-five (255) feet; thence north to south side of Fourth (4th) street; thence west to the first branch on the west side of said town; thence up the center of the stream of said branch in a northerly direction to the north original line of said land lot number 43; thence east on the said north original line of land lot number 42 and 43 to the west side of the right of way of the
Georgia and Alabama Railway; thence north on the west side of said right of way seven hundred (700) feet; thence east in a straight line one thousand (1,000) feet; thence south in a straight line seven hundred (700) feet to the north original line of said land lot number 42; thence east on said north original lot line to the east side of Oak street, in town of Ocilla; thence south to the north line of Fourth street in said town; thence due east six hundred (600) feet; thence south to the south original line of said land lot number 42; thence west on said south original line of lot number 42 to the southwest corner of said land lot, being the place of beginning. Ocilla. Corporate limits.

Sec. II. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section two of said original charter relative to the officers of said town and the manner of their election be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: Strike all of said section except the enacting clause, and in lieu thereof substitute the following words, to wit: The officers of said town shall consist of a mayor and five (5) aldermen, who together shall constitute a town council; also a town attorney and a judge of the police court, to be styled recorder, and such other officers as the town council may, by ordinance, provide. Each officer herein named shall be elective by the people at the regular biennial election, which shall be held on the first Tuesday in January, 1901, and every two years thereafter; each officer shall hold his office for the period of two years and until his successor is elected and qualified; provided, however, that the hereinafter named persons shall be the officers of said town until the regular biennial election in January, 1901, and until their successors are elected and qualified, viz.: mayor, J. A. J. Henderson; aldermen J. C. Luke, D. H. Paulk, G. L. Stone, L. R. Tucker and J. H. Powell; town attorney, M. J. Paulk; recorder, C. H. Martin. No annual election shall be held for 1899. Each of the herein named persons shall qualify and assume the duties of his respective office within ten days after the passage and approval of this Act, and it is hereby made the duty of the present town government to turn over to such named officers all books, papers, records and property of every kind and description belonging to said town. All vacancies in any office of said town, except school trustees, shall be filled by election by the town council. Officers. Terms of. Vacancies.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section three (3) of said charter, relating to the compensation of the officers of said town, be amended so that the said
section when amended shall read as follows, viz.: Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the town council shall by ordinance provide for the compensation of the town officers, and the time and manner of payment; provided, however, that the council shall have no power to provide any compensation for the services of the mayor, any alderman or any member or officer of the board of school trustees, except that it may exempt such officers and trustees from the payment of any street tax which may be imposed by the council on the male residents of said town. Compensation of officers.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no person shall be allowed to vote at any town election in said town who does not possess the qualifications of a voter under the general laws of the State, and such voter shall also possess such other additional qualifications as the council may lawfully impose by town ordinance. The town council are hereby authorized and empowered to provide by ordinance for the registration of all voters at town elections, under such regulations as the council may deem best, and to prescribe the qualifications of voters at town elections, to appoint managers and clerks for such elections, and in all respects to control and manage said elections. The council shall have the power, and it shall be its duty to canvass and consolidate all town election returns and declare the result thereof, and cause a statement of such result to be entered on the minutes of the council; the council shall provide by ordinance for the time, place and manner of holding such elections, and may by ordinance change the time of holding the annual election for said town. Voters. Registration.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the town council shall have the power and authority to declare by ordinance what shall be considered a nuisance, and to abate the same; to do all Acts, make all regulations, pass all ordinances and laws which may be necessary or expedient for the promotion of the health, morals, or temperance of the town; or the suppression of crime, or disease therein; to own, establish or regulate cemeteries within or without the town; to regulate or prohibit the establishment of offensive or unwholesome business within the town; to regulate the police of the town, and to pass and enforce all necessary police ordinances; to appropriate, damage, take or condemn any property or any corporation, firm or person within the town for the purpose of establishing, changing, opening, widening, extending, grading or improving any public street or alley within said town;
to lay out, establish and in any way improve or repair public streets and alleys within said town; to name and rename or change the name of any street or alley; to establish fire limits in said town and to provide regulations for the construction of buildings within said limits; to prevent the construction of dangerous chimneys, fireplaces, hearths, ovens and boilers, and to require to be removed or placed in a safe condition any such already in a dangerous condition; to provide for fire protecttion, and for the purchase of fire engines and building of engine houses; to provide regulations for the safe storage of gunpowder, benzine, or any other explosive or combustible materials; to regulate or prohibit the running at large of dogs, cattle horses, or any kind of animals; to prohibit the keeping within said town for illegal sale any kind of intoxicating liquors; to prescribe penalties for the violation of any ordinance or law of the city; to require railroad companies to make and keep in repair drains and crossings where same may be necessary on account of said railroads, and to require any railroad to conform to such grades as may be established by the town authorities; to impose a tax on all dogs within the town; to allow telephone companies to erect a system of telephones. General welfare.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the mayor shall preside at all meetings of the council. The town marshal shall have the power and authority and it shall be his duty, under the regulations imposed by the council, and also those imposed by the general laws of the State, to advertise and conduct all delinquent tax sales for unpaid town taxes, and to make and deliver tax deeds to purchasers at such sales. Marshal.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in addition to the oath required by general law of all civil officers in this State, each town officer and school trustee shall take and subscribe the following oath, which shall be filed with the council:
Georgia, Irwin County, Town of Ocilla.

I, , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will faithfully discharge the duties of the office of in the town of Ocilla, according to the laws of the said town and the State of Georgia to the best of my ability, so help me God. All town officers, except aldermen and school trustees, shall, before assuming the duties of their office, give a bond in amount to be prescribed by the council, with good and sufficient security, which bond shall be filed with and approved by the council, said bond to be payable to the town
of Ocilla and shall be conditioned for the faithful discharge of the duties of the principle's office and for a faithful accounting of all moneys coming into such officer's hands, in the time and manner provided by law. Oath of officers.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said town of Ocilla be, and the same is, hereby created an independent school district which shall be known and called Ocilla Independent School District, and it shall have the power and authority to purchase, acquire, lease or otherwise provide for buildings and grounds for the use of the public schools within said town. Said town council shall have power on complying with the provisions of the constitution and laws of this State relative to same, to maintain a system of free public schools within the said town, and to levy a tax of not to exceed one-half of one per cent. upon all the taxable property within said town to support said schools. Public schools.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That J. L. Paulk, L. R. Tucker, A. L. Hayes, J. B. Davis and J. R. Goethe be, and they are, hereby elected as trustees of said Ocilla School District. Each shall hold his office until the regular annual election in the year 1900 and until his successor is elected and qualified, and thereafter members of said board of trustees shall be elected by the qualified voters of said town at the regular annual election, and shall each hold office for one year. Said trustees shall qualify within ten days after the passage of this Act, and they and their successors shall thereafter during their term of office have full control of the public schools of the town and are hereby authorized to make and prescribe all needful rules and regulations for the said schools, and shall have full power and authority to employ all necessary teachers and janitors; prescribe the course of study and the length of the school year, fix and determine the price to be charged non-resident pupils; to receive direct from the State authorities without the intervention of the town council any public school moneys due the said district from the State, and in general to have complete control of the schools of said town. Trustees of schools.

Sec. X. The said trustees shall elect one of their number president and one clerk and treasurer of the board. All moneys expended for school purposes shall be paid out on the warrant or order of the president of the board after being authorized by the board. The board shall keep a record of their proceedings, and no warrant shall be drawn by the president until the authority therefor is first recorded in the book of minutes to be kept by the clerk
of the board. The board may make all needful rules for their own meetings, and shall provide for the time and place of such meetings. All vacancies in the board shall be filled by the board. Board of Trustees.

Sec. XI. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the board shall, not later than the first day of March of each year, file with the city council a written estimate of the amount necessary for the ensuing year to support the public schools of the town, which estimate shall be signed by the president of the board and shall be itemized as to amounts deemed necessary for each department of the schools and for all expenses, including teachers' wages; and said board shall attach to said written estimate a recommendation as to the amount of tax necessary to be levied for support of schools for ensuing year, and if the amount of tax recommended is not in excess of one-half of one per cent. on the taxable property of the city, it shall be the duty of the council to levy a tax as recommended by the board of trustees. School tax.
Sec. XII. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws or parts of laws in anywise conflicting with this law are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: PAVO, TOWN OF, INCORPORATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to incorporate the town of Pavo in the counties of Thomas and Brooks, to grant certain powers and privileges to the same, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That the town of Pavo, in the counties of Thomas and Brooks, be, and the same is, hereby incorporated as a town under the name of the town of Pavo. The corporate powers of said town shall be vested in a mayor and five councilmen, and by the name of the mayor and council of the town of Pavo they may sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded and exercise all other corporate powers that may be necessary in performing their duties. Pavo. Corporate name and powers.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by authority of same, That the corporate limits of said town shall extend one-half mile in every direction from a center at the intersection of Harris and Main streets of said town of Pavo. Corporate limits.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That H. Roberts be, and he is, hereby appointed mayor, and P. A.
Adams, T. N. Reddick, R. A. McGraw, J. W. L. Brannon and E J. Cheek be, and they are, hereby appointed councilmen of said town of Pavo, to hold their offices until the first annual election as hereinafter provided and their successors are qualified. Mayor and councilmen.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That an election shall be held in said town on the fourth Monday in December, 1899, and annually thereafter for a mayor and five councilmen to serve for one year, and until their successors are elected and qualified; said election to be held in said town under the supervision of the justice of the peace of the 763d district, G. M., and of three freeholders resident in said town. The polls shall be opened by eight o'clock a. m. and closed at five p. m., standard time. No one shall be entitled to vote in said election or any municipal election in said town unless he is a duly registered voter of said town; said election to be conducted in all respects as election for members of the General Assembly in said State, except that only two lists of voters and two tally-sheets need be kept, and except as herein provided. Election for mayor and councilmen. Voters.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the treasurer of said town shall be ex officio registrar of said town, and open his books of registration on the first Monday in November, 1899, and annually thereafter on the same day, and shall keep them open until six o'clock p. m. on the first Monday in December next thereafter, at his office in said town every day, Sundays excepted, from nine a. m. until six p. m., and he shall register all male members who apply in person, but not by proxy, within the time prescribed and who will take and subscribe the following oath, which said treasurer is hereby authorized to administer, to wit: You do solemnly swear that you have attained the age of twenty-one years; that you are a citizen of the United States; that you have resided in the State for the past twelve months, and in the county of Thomas for the past six months; that you have paid all State and county taxes required of you since the adoption of the constitution of 1877, except for this year; that you have never been convicted of a felony or larceny; that you have resided in the corporate limits of the town of Pavo for the past six months and have paid all taxes legally required of you, including street tax and any license tax, and have considered this town your home for that length of time, so help you, God. Any person who shall take the said oath and shall swear falsely in so doing shall be guilty of false swearing and shall, on conviction therefor, be punished as prescribed by the statute in such case made; and provided, each person so registering shall give the street, block or other designation
of his residence in said town, which shall be recorded along with his name in the book kept by the registrar for that purpose; that said registrar shall furnish the superintendent of election with at least two copies of said list. No candidate for any town office shall be eligible as a superintendent or manager of said election. Registration.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no one shall be eligible to the office of mayor or councilman who is not registered as a voter of said town; that the superintendents of such election shall declare those persons receiving the highest number of votes for mayor and councilmen duly elected, and furnish a certificate to that effect; shall return one tally-sheet and list of voters with the ballots, under seal, to the town clerk and the other tally-sheet and list of voters to the ordinary of Thomas county; the persons so elected must present themselves at the council chamber within ten days and take an oath before the outgoing mayor, or any officer authorized to administer an oath, faithfully to discharge the duties of mayor or councilmen, as the case may be. Any one desiring to contest any election shall file a notice of contest with the ordinary of Thomas county within three days after said election, setting forth all the grounds for contest, and upon payment of a fee of ten dollars ($10) in advance, the ordinary of Thomas county shall cause a copy of said notice to be served by the sheriff or his deputy upon the contestees, and give notice at the same time to both parties of the time and place of hearing. Not later than ten days from the date of said service the ordinary of Thomas county is authorized to hear and determine the contest (with the right of certiorari to the superior court), the cost to be paid by the losing party. Qualifications of officers. Result of elections. Contest.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in case of vacancy in the office of mayor, the councilmen shall elect one of their own number for the unexpired term, and in case of a vacancy in the board of councilmen, the remaining members shall elect a citizen of said city to fill such vacancy for the unexpired term. Vacancy.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That should the mayor or any member of the board of councilmen be guilty of malpractice in office, or any abuse of the powers confided to him, he shall be subject to indictment in the superior court of Thomas county, and on conviction shall be imprisoned not exceeding sixty days, or pay a fine not exceeding one hundred dollars, which fine shall be paid over to the treasurer of said town; either or both of said punishments may be imposed, in the discretion of the court. The mayor and councilmen, for cause,
suspend, fine or remove from office, or suspend from pay and duty, any officer of said town elected or appointed by them. Malfeasance.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said mayor and councilmen shall have power at any regular meeting to elect a clerk, a marshal, policeman, chain-gang keeper and guards, a sexton or cemetery-keeper, and such other officers as they may deem necessary; to regulate the time, mode and manner of electing each and all of said officers; to fix their fees and salaries; take their bonds, and prescribe their powers and duties; they shall also have power to provide for the appointment of a health officer and a board of health, and to prescribe their powers and duties. Officers.

Sec. X. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said mayor and each of said councilmen shall be ex officio a justice of the peace, and shall have full power and authority to issue warrants for the arrest of any person charged with the commission of an offense against the laws of the State, within the limits of said town; hear their testimony under oath as to guilt or innocence of the party accused; to commit to jail, or the guard-house of said town, or to require bond with good and sufficient security, if the offense is a bailable one, for the appearance of the accused before any court authorized by law to try and determine the case. Mayor and councilmen ex officio justices of the peace.

Sec. XI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said mayor and councilmen shall have full power and authority to levy and collect a tax upon all and every species of property in said town subject to State tax; upon banking and insurance capital employed in said town; upon brokers and factors; upon each and every business, calling, trade and profession carried on in said town; to tax all theatrical performances, shows and exhibitions for gain; upon bank, insurance, telegraph and express agencies in said town, or of any profit in said town; to tax all itinerant traders or peddlers; all venders of patent medicines, drugs, books, nostrums, or devices of any kind; all solicitors or canvassers selling goods, wares or merchandise by sample at retail or to consumers; all said taxes (except the tax on real or personal property, which shall be ad valorem, and not exceeding one-half of one per cent. for ordinary current expenses) shall be in the nature of a license, which must be paid in advance of doing business or carrying on the trade or occupation, or convassing, or offering for sale any of the articles above set forth; and the said mayor and councilmen shall provide by ordinances for the punishment of all parties required to take out license, who do or attempt to do any business
before taking out such license and complying fully with all requirements of said mayor and councilmen made with reference thereto. Taxes.

Sec. XII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said mayor and councilmen shall have full powers and authority to prevent any party from encroaching upon the streets, alleys and sidewalks, or placing any obstruction in or on or over any streets, alley or sidewalk, and to remove or cause to be removed any such encroachment, whether building, porches, steps, signs, or whatever it may be, already erected, and to prevent and abate any nuisance in the public squares, forks, streets, lanes, alleys, sidewalks of said town, now dedicated or that may be dedicated to public use, or on the premises of any person or persons in said town; to establish a market or markets and regulate the same, and regulate at what places and within what hours fresh meats, fish, fowls and game may be sold at said markets or other places in said town, and what license shall be paid for selling such articles; provided, all farm products, including fish, meats, fowls and game, can be sold without taxed lieense after eight o'clock a. m. by the producer; to license and regulate all hotels and boarding-houses; to prevent the erection and maintenance in said city of butcher-pens, slaughter-houses, tan-yards, blacksmith-shops, wood-working mills, saw-mills, grist-mills, forges and chimneys, except by the permission of said mayor and councilmen, and to cause the removal of any and all such establishments whenever they become dangerous to the health and welfare of the citizens, endanger the lives or property, or both, of others, or become nuisances; to cause all lots or premises to be thoroughly drained, and to this end may open ditches or drains at the expense of the owner or owners thereof when they, after reasonable notice, fail to do so, said expense to be collected as city taxes are collected;
