section 4 of this Act is provided, a mayor and four aldermen, who shall be known and styled the mayor and aldermen of the town of Warsaw, and who, under the latter name and style shall succeed to and be invested with all the authority and powers conferred upon said board of commissioners in said section 77 of said Act, and in all other sections of said Act not inconsistent with the provisions of this Act, and be subject to all provisions therein provided, and said mayor and aldermen shall have authority to prescribe the salaries and compensation to be paid to the officers and employees of said town of Warsaw. Mayor and aldermen.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, That any person shall be eligible to the office of mayor or alderman of said town of Warsaw who shall be duly qualified as a voter for any of said officers as is hereinafter in this section prescribed for the qualification of voters at elections for mayor and aldermen of said town, and no person not so qualified shall be eligible thereto. The qualification necessary to entitle a person to vote for mayor or alderman of the town of Warsaw at elections therefor shall be as follows, to wit: Said person shall be a male person who shall have attained the age of twenty-one years; shall be a freeholder, owning in fee simple in his own right a lot or parcel of land containing not less than one-eighth of an acre of land in dimension situated within the corporate limits of the town of Warsaw, as said corporate limits are prescribed and defined in section 2 of this Act; shall be a citizen of the United States; shall have been a resident of the State of Georgia continuously during the six months immediately preceding said election; shall have been regularly domiciled in said town and residing continuously in the corporate limits thereof, as said corporate limits are prescribed and defined in section 2 of this Act, during sixty days immediately preceding said election; shall have paid all taxes legally required and demanded of him by the authorities of said town, and shall have registered in conformity to such regulations as shall have been prescribed by ordinance of said town for the registration of voters for mayor and aldermen of said town. Qualifications of. Voters.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That the first election after the passage of this Act for mayor and aldermen of the town of Warsaw shall be held on the first Monday in May, 1899, and that all subsequent elections for said mayor and aldermen shall be held biennially from and after the said first Monday in May, 1899. Said first election shall be held under the superintendence of a justice of the peace and two freeholders in the county of Chatham, who shall be appointed by the municipal authorities of said town; in the event, however, of the absence of a justice of the peace any three
freeholders in the county may superintend said election. The mayor and aldermen then and so elected and their successors shall have authority thereafter to prescribe by ordinance the manner of holding subsequent elections for mayor and aldermen of said town; in the event of failure at any time to elect a mayor and aldermen as provided for in this Act, another election for said mayor and aldermen may be held at any time on five days' notice thereof from any three freeholders in said county being posted at a conspicuous place in said town, and the mayor and aldermen so elected shall hold their offices until the next regular time of election or until their successors are elected and qualified; if any vacancy shall happen in the municipal board of said town the vacancy may be filled by an election made by remaining members of said board, and the person so elected shall hold his office so long as his predecessor would have held the same. Election. Managers. Vacancy.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and aldermen be, and are, hereby invested with power and authority to provide regulations for the registration of persons qualified to vote for mayor and aldermen of said town of Warsaw as provided in section 4 of this Act.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted, That in case the superintendents of any election for mayor and aldermen of the town of Warsaw shall have reasonable doubt as to the qualification of any person who presents himself at the polls thereof in order to vote thereat, said superintendents shall have power and authority to administer to such persons the following oath: You do solemnly swear that you have attained the age of twenty-one years; that you are a freeholder, owning in fee simple in your own right a lot or parcel of land containing not less than one-eighth of an acre of land in dimension, situated within the corporate limits of the town of Warsaw, as said corporate limits are prescribed and defined in the charter of said town as amended in 1898; that you are a citizen of the United States; that you have been a resident of the State of Georgia continuously during the last six months past; that you have been regularly domiciled in said town and residing continuously within the corporate limits thereof during the last sixty days past; that you have paid all taxes legally required or demanded of you by the authorities of said town, and that you have registered as required by the regulations prescribed by the ordinances of said town for providing for the registration of voters in such manner as to entitle you to vote at this election, so help you, God. Any person refusing to so make oath shall not be permitted to vote at said election, and any person who shall take said oath and therein
swear falsely shall be subject to indictment and prosecution for false swearing, and on conviction thereof to imprisonment in the penitentiary not less than one year nor more than two years. The voting at said elections shall be by ballot, and no person whose name does not appear in the list of registered voters entitled to vote at such election shall be permitted to vote. The polls at the election shall be closed promptly at the time fixed for the closing thereof, and the ballots counted by the superintendents as soon as practicable thereafter, and the person or persons receiving the highest number of votes at said election shall be declared duly elected and said superintendents shall thereupon issue certificates to that effect, and the certificates so issued shall be prima facie evidence of the election of said mayor and aldermen and entitles them to be installed into their respective offices. Oath of voters.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted, That section 3 of said Act which relates to license of spirituous liquors be, and the same is, hereby altered and amended by adding on to said section 3 at the end thereof the following words, to wit: And the said commissioners and the mayor and aldermen who shall succeed to the municipal government of said town of Warsaw, upon and after the abolishment of said commissioners, shall also be authorized and empowered to prescribe by ordinance for the regulation and sale of spirituous liquors within the corporate and jurisdictional limits of said town under all licenses which may be granted and issued under the provisions of said section 3 of said Act, so that said section 3 of said Act, when so altered and amended, will read as follows: Be it further enacted, That said commissioners shall have the exclusive right to grant license to retail spirituous liquors or to prohibit the traffic in the same in the town of Warsaw, and also to extend the same right for the distance of one mile from the boundary of the town of Warsaw, and the said commissioners and the mayor and aldermen who shall succeed to the municipal government of said town of Warsaw upon and after the abolishment of said commissioners shall also be authorized and empowered to prescribe by ordinance for the regulation and sale of spirituous liquors within the corporate and jurisdictional limits of said town under all licenses which may be granted and issued under the provisions of said section 3 of said Act. Liquor, sale of.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and aldermen of said town of Warsaw who shall be elected under the provisions and authority of section 3 of this Act and their successors shall be invested with power and authority to prescribe taxes to be paid on real and personal property in said town, and make provisions for
assessing the value of property in said town, and prescribe special taxes to be paid on all business occupations, enterprises and amusements carried on in said town, and on all clubs and secular associations established and having quarters in said town, and for licensing the same; also with authority and power to grant franchises to construct and operate electric railways and other transportation enterprises in and upon the streets of said town; also to control all public streets now in said town, and remove obstructions therefrom, and to open, lay out and construct such other streets as they may deem necessary, and drains and sewers therein, and to purchase and dispose of property for municipal purposes therein; to provide for a board of health and water, lights and market places for said town; to provide for the issuing of executions and making levies for the collection of unpaid taxes on property in said town. Taxes. Special powers.

Sec. X. Be it further enacted, That all provisions of said Act in which the words commissioners and board of commissioners appear be, and the same are, so repealed, altered and amended as to eliminate said words therefrom and substitute the words mayor and aldermen for the same, so that from and after the passage of this Act the present municipal board shall cease to be known and styled the board of commissioners of the town of Warsaw, and shall thereupon and thereafter be known and styled the mayor and aldermen of the town of Warsaw, and all resolutions and ordinances passed and all business transacted thereafter for said town shall be done in and under the name and style of the mayor and aldermen of the town of Warsaw; the chairman of the present board of commissioners of the town of Warsaw shall thereupon be officially recognized as the mayor of said town and shall continue to be so recognized during the incumbency of said present municipal board, and any member of said board may act as his official substitute in case of his absence, disqualification or disability as such official with the assent of the other members of the municipal board. Corporate name.

Sec. XI. Be it further enacted, That a court shall be, and is hereby created and established, in and for the said town of Warsaw, and that the same shall be denominated the police court of the town of Warsaw, and shall have power and authority, from and after the passage of this Act, to take cognizance of, and try and determine in a summary manner, any and all cases involving infractions of and offenses against the ordinances of the said town of Warsaw, whether such ordinances
shall have been passed by the municipal board of said town, which existed prior to the election of the mayor and aldermen, who shall succeed to the municipal government of said town after the abolishment of the board of commissioners thereof, as provided in this Act, or by the mayor and aldermen thereof elected and having succession under the provisions of this Act, and to impose a fine, not exceeding one hundred dollars, or imprisonment not exceeding sixty days for each infraction or offense, either with or without labor, or both, at the discretion of said court, upon any person convicted thereof, and to examine into the facts of any case in which a person shall be arrested and brought before said court charged with an offense against the penal laws of the State or the United States, and commit the accused to the jailor of Chatham county, to appear before any court having jurisdiction of such case, and it shall be, and is hereby made the duty of said jailor to receive any and all prisoners so committed and safely keep them until tried and convicted or discharged by due process of law; said police court shall be held at such place in said town, and at such times as shall be appointed by the authorities thereof, during the existence of the present municipal board of said town; the chairman thereof, who, from and after the passage of this Act, shall be known and styled the mayor of the said town, shall be presiding officer of said police court; in case, however, of the absence of, or the disqualification or disability of said chairman to so preside, one of the members of said municipal board shall act as his official substitute and preside therein; and upon and after the abolishment of the said board of commissioners, as provided in section 3 of this Act, the mayor of said town shall be the presiding officer of said police court, or in case of his absence or disqualification, or disability to preside in said police court, one of the aldermen of said town shall act as his official substitute and so preside in said police court. Sessions of said police court shall be held as often as may be necessary to insure speedy trial and expedite justice therein. The presiding officer of said police court shall have power and authority to impose a fine not exceeding twenty dollars, or to imprison not more than thirty days, any person who shall disturb said court during its sittings, or who shall in any manner be in contempt of the same. If any person shall be dissatisfied with any judgment pronounced by said presiding officer, said person shall have the right of appeal to the municipal board of said town then in existence, at its
next regular meeting, by giving notice at the time of the pronouncement of said judgment, or when the officers go to execute the same, which notice shall supersede the said judgment until the hearing of said appeal, provided the person thus appealing shall, if required, give bond with good security, in the sum of two hundred dollars, to be judged of by the said presiding officer, payable to said presiding officer and his successors in office, conditioned to stand and abide the judgment to be rendered in said case, which bond may be forefeited for non-appearance; and upon a rule to show cause, judgment may be rendered by said presiding officer in the same manner as judgments are rendered on forfeited recognizances in the superior court of this State, and execution had and issued thereon in such a manner as shall be provided by ordinance of said town for the issuing of executions, the same to bear test in the name of said presiding officer and be issued and signed by the clerk of said police court. Said court shall have power to issue all proper processes, summons, subp[oelig]nas and executions, and the same shall also bear test of the said presiding officer and be issued and signed by the clerk of the said police court and directed to the marshal of said town and be executed by him or his deputy; said court shall have an information docket in which all persons charged with violations of the ordinances of said town or the penal laws of the State or the United States, shall be docketed, the entry thereof stating the name of the accused, setting forth the offense and date when same was committed. Any person so accused may be imprisoned until tried, unless such person shall give good and sufficient bond for his or her appearance at the trial thereof. The presiding officer shall have power to compel the attendance of witnesses at trials before said police court, and before the mayor and aldermen on trial of appeal cases before them. Said presiding officer may appoint by order entered upon the minutes of said police court any person to act as clerk or bailiff during absence at any time of the clerk, marshal or bailiff of said court. The marshal of said town and his deputy shall be ex officio constables of said town and bailiffs of said police court. A minute book shall be kept in said police court for recording the minutes thereof. Police court.
Sec. XII. Be it further enacted, That all laws or parts thereof in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: WASHINGTON, BONDS FOR WATER-WORKS, ETC.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the mayor and council of Washington, Georgia, to issue bonds to the amount of thirty thousand dollars for the purpose of paying for water-works and an electric plant for Washington, Georgia, and to sewer the streets of said town, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That the mayor and council of Washington, Georgia, shall have power, and the same is hereby conferred on them, to issue bonds to the amount of thirty thousand dollars; provided, the qualified voters of said town shall, at an election to be held for the purpose, by a constitutional majority vote in favor of issuing said bonds, and it is hereby made the duty of said mayor and council to order such election. Washington. Bonds.

Sec. II. Said bonds shall be of such denomination as the said mayor and council shall decide upon and direct; they shall bear such rate of interest, not to exceed six per cent. per annum, as may be determined upon by said mayor and council. Interest.

Sec. III. With the proceeds arising from the sale of said bonds, the said mayor and council are hereby authorized to construct a system of water-works for said town; to construct a system of electric lights for said town, and to provide for said town a suitable and proper system of sewers. Said mayor and council, instead of erecting a system of water-works or a system of electric lights may, in their discretion, use the fund aforesaid, or any part thereof, in purchasing and enlarging or improving any system of water-works or electric lights already existing in said town. Water-works, electric lights, sewers.

Sec. IV. Said mayor and council, in addition to supplying said town with such water and lights as are necessary for public purposes, are also authorized and empowered to contract with private individuals and corporations to furnish water and electricity and to charge for and collect for the same whatever may be agreed upon. Contract.
Sec. V. All laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: WAYNESBORO, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend section 4 of the Act incorporating the city of Waynesboro, approved December 15th, 1893, by causing all elections to fill vacancies in the offices of mayor or aldermen to be by vote of the people instead of such vacancies being filled by the remaining members of the board of aldermen, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That section IV. of the above stated Act be amended by striking out of the fifth line of said section the words the remaining members, a majority being sufficient to elect, and inserting in lieu thereof the words the voters of said city, said election to be held not later than twenty days after such vacancy shall occur, the date of such election to be fixed by the remaining members and advertised by the clerk of the council at least ten days before the date so fixed; provided, that no special election shall be necessary when such vacancy occurs not more than three months before a regular election, in which case such vacancy shall be filled at the regular election, so that said section so amended shall read as follows: That in case of a vacancy in any of the offices mentioned in the preceding section, by death, resignation, failure to elect, removal from office, removal from the city or otherwise, said vacancy, whether mayor or aldermen, shall be filled by an election by the voters of said city, said election to be held not later than twenty days after such vacancy shall occur, the date of such election to be fixed by the remaining members, and advertised by the clerk of the council at least ten days before the date so fixed; provided, that no special election shall be necessary when such vacancy occurs not more than three months before a regular election, in which case such vacancy shall be filled at the regular election. Waynesboro. Vacancies in offices.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: BANK OF THE UNIVERSITY, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to incorporate the Bank of the University at Athens, Georgia, approved February 14, 1873, so as to provide that a person may be eligible to be a director of said company who owns ten or more shares of its stock, instead of twenty or more shares, as now required by the above Act.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, section 2 of the above recited Act be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking out the word twenty in said section, and inserting in lieu thereof the word ten, so that the part of said section proposed to be amended, instead of reading as it now does, and no person shall be a director of said company who shall not be a stockholder to the extent of twenty shares or more, shall read as follows: and no person shall be a director of such company who shall not be a stockholder to the extent of ten shares or more. Bank of the University. Directors
Sec. II. That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the foregoing be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: HOME LOAN AND BANKING COMPANY, CHARTER AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved December 26th, 1888, entitled an Act to incorporate the Home Loan and Banking Company, of Atlanta, by giving said company the power to conduct a title abstract and title guarantee business in counties in this State having seventy thousand inhabitants or more, to make copies from the public records of counties in this State having seventy-five thousand inhabitants or more, and other power related to said business, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That an Act approved December 26th, 1888, entitled an Act to incorporate the Home Loan and Banking Company, of Atlanta, be, and the same is hereby amended by adding at the end of the eleventh section of said Act the following words: And also to carry on a title abstract and a title guaranty business in counties of this State having seventy-five thousand inhabitants or more, and said corporation is hereby given the power and authority to make or procure copies and abstracts from the public records of counties in this State having seventy-five thousand inhabitants or more, and gather information therefrom and from all other available sources relating in any manner to real estate and to the character and validity of titles thereto, but on terms satisfactory to the clerk or other officer having charge of said records; to make, procure, publish and furnish or sell maps and plats; to make, publish and sell abstracts of title and certificates of opinion as to titles to any real estate, and to make and issue contracts of guaranty or policies of insurance upon such terms as may be agreed guaranteeing or insuring owners or mortgagees of real estate or other persons having or claiming any right, interest or estate whatever in or lien upon the same, against loss by reason of defective titles, liens or other encumbrances; provided, that nothing herein contained shall be so construed as to authorize
any unlawful interference with the public officers of any county or city of this State in the discharge of their duties in connection with said public records, maps, plats or other books or papers in their custody or control, so that the said eleventh section of said Act, thus amended, will read as follows: Section 11. Be it further enacted, That said company shall be, and are, hereby given the right to carry on the business of guarantee insurance, and to insure and guarantee the payments of any dividents, bonds, notes, undertakings, mortgages or other securities or evidences of indebtedness, or the interest thereon, of any person, partnership or corporation for any price and on any consideration agreed on; and also to carry on a title abstract and title guarantee business in any county in this State having seventy-tive thousand inhabitants or more, and said corporation is hereby given the power and authority to make or procure copies and abstracts from the public records of counties in this State having seventy-five thousand inhabitants or more, and gather information therefrom and from all other available sources relating in any manner to real estate and to the character and validity of titles thereto, but on terms satisfactory to the clerk or other officer having charge of said records; to make, procure, publish and furnish or sell maps and plats; to make, publish and sell abstracts of titles and certificates of opinion as to titles to any real estate, and to make and issue contracts of guaranty or policies of insurance, upon such terms as may be agreed guaranteeing or insuring owners or mortgagees of real estate or other persons having or claiming any right, interest or estate whatever in or lien upon the same against loss by reason of defective titles, lines or other encumbrances; provided, that notbing herein contained shall be so construed as to authorize any unlawful interference with the public officers of any county or city of this State in the discharge of their duties in connection with said public records, maps, plats or other books or papers in their custody or control. Home Loan and Banking Company. Abstract and guaranty business. Guarantee business. Insurance.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: ALBANY, CITY COURT OF, PRACTICE IN.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act creating the city court of Albany in and for the county of Dougherty, approved December 16, 1897, so as to deny defenders in said court the right to demand indictment by grand jury, to provide for the payment of the fees of clerk, sheriff, justices of the peace and notary public and ex officio justices of the peace, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the
same, That section 31 of the above recited Act be, and the same is, hereby repealed, and in lieu and instead thereof it is hereby enacted as follows: That all criminal trials in said court shall be tried by the judge thereof without a jury except when the accused shall in writing demand same, and a plea to the accusation shall be a waiver of said demand, and if upon the trial of any case in which the accused has not been indicted, it shall appear to the judge that the evidence makes the case a felony against the accused, he shall thereupon suspend the trial and commit the defendant, bail him or bind him over to next superior court as in preliminary examinations. City Court of Albany. Trial of criminal cases.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section 45 of said Act be, and the same is, hereby repealed, and in lieu and instead thereof, it is hereby enacted as follows: That all fines and forfeitures arising from cases tried in said city court, except the proportions due the solicitor, which shall be paid into the county treasury as now provided by law under section 5 of the Act establishing the city court of Albany, shall be subject to the payment of the fees and costs of the clerk and sheriff of said court, the same to be distributed pro rata under the same rules and regulations governing the fees of said officers as now provided by law; provided, however, that in all cases transferred from the superior court of Dougherty county to said city court, the solicitor-general of the superior court shall be entitled to such solicitor's costs as shall have accrued on such bills of indictment or special presentments up to the time of transfer; provided further, that in all cases in which justices of the peace or notary public and ex officio justices of the peace have bound over any offender to said court, or to the superior court and the case is afterwards transferred to said city court, such magistrate binding over shall be entitled to share as to his costs in the particular case with the officers of said city court hereinbefore named upon the same terms in any fine or forfeiture that may arise therefrom; provided further, that county of Dougherty shall not be liable to the officers of said court, to wit: the clerk, sheriff and justices of the peace and the notary public and ex officio justice of the peace and the solicitor-general of the superior court for insolvent costs, in any criminal case except the cost in the cases where the convicted defendants are used or hired out by the county authorities, in which event the county authorities shall pay to the officers above named the costs in all such cases. Fines and forfeitures.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid,
That section 29 of said Act be, and the same is, hereby repealed, and in lieu and instead thereof it is hereby enacted as follows: That in all cases in said court, both civil and criminal, a jury of twelve (12) shall be selected from a panel of eighteen (18) drawn as aforesaid, by giving to the plaintiff and defendant three strikes each in civil cases and the defendant four and the State two strikes in criminal cases. In case from any cause said panel should be reduced below eighteen (18) the judge of said court shall have power to fill it by causing talesmen to be summoned instanter. Juries.
Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: ATLANTA, CRIMINAL COURT OF, ELECTION OF JUDGE AND SOLICITOR.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the Act of September 6, 1891, and the Acts amendatory thereof, establishing the criminal court of Atlanta, by providing for the election of the judge and solicitor thereof by the people of Fulton county, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That an Act approved September 6, 1891, establishing the criminal court of Atlanta, and the Acts amendatory thereof, which provides for the appointment of judge and solicitor of said criminal court of Atlanta by the governor, be amended as follows: At the next general State election an election shall be held for judge and solicitor of said criminal court of Atlanta, whose terms of office shall begin on the first of January after said election, and shall continue four years, or until their successors are elected or appointed and qualified as hereinafter provided. The successors of the first judge and solicitor to be elected as herein provided shall hold office for the term of four years, or until their successors shall be elected, and the election shall be held at the next general election immediately preceding the expiration of said terms of office,
and is to conducted under the laws applicable to the election of county officers of Fulton county, with a like qualification for voters. At the election those qualified to vote for county officers of Fulton county at the general election, shall be qualified to vote for said judge and solicitor. In the event of a vacancy arising in said office of judge or solicitor, the governor shall, by appointment, fill the same until the next general election, when a judge or solicitor shall be elected to fill the unexpired term as herein provided; provided, the terms of judges and solicitors appointed before the next election shall expire on the first of January after such general election. Criminal Court of Atlanta. Election of judge and solicitor.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That the criminal court of Atlanta be established in the city of Atlanta.
Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: ATLANTA, CITY COURT OF, ELECTION OF JUDGE FOR.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the Act of December 15th, 1871, and Acts amendatory thereof, establishing the city court of Atlanta, by providing for the election of the judge thereof, by the people of Fulton county, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That an Act, approved December 15th, 1871, establishing the city court of Atlanta, and the Acts amendatory thereof, which provide for the appointment of a judge of said city court of Atlanta, by the governor, be amended as follows: At the next general State election, an election shall be held for a judge of said city court of Atlanta, whose term of office shall begin on the first of January, after said election, and shall continue four years, or until his successor is elected, or appointed, and qualified, as hereinafter provided. The successors of the first Judge to be elected, as herein provided, shall hold office for the term of four years, or until their successors shall be elected; and the election shall be held at the next general election, immediately preceding the expiration of said terms of office; and is to be conducted under the laws
applicable to the election of county officers of Fulton county with a like qualification for voters. At the election, those qualified to vote for county officers of Fulton county, at the general election, shall be qualified to vote for said judge. In the event of a vacancy arising in said office of judge, the governor shall, by appointment, fill the same, until the next general election, when a judge shall be elected to fill the unexpired term, as herein provided; provided, the terms of judges and solicitors, appointed before the next general election, shall expire on the first of January, after said general election. City Court of Atlanta. Election of judge.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: CLARKESVILLE, CITY COURT OF, ESTABLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to establish a city court of Clarkesville in Habersham county, to define its jurisdiction and powers, to provide for the appointment of a judge and other officers thereof, and to define their powers and duties; to provide for pleading and practice and motion for new trials therein, and writs of error therefrom, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, the city court of Clarkesville is hereby established, to be organized, located and held in the city of Clarkesville, with jurisdiction, civil and criminal, over the entire county of Habersham. City Court of Clarkesville.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said city court of Clarkesville shall have jurisdiction to try and dispose of all cases, of whatever nature, except those cases over which exclusive jurisdiction is vested in other courts by the constitution of the State of Georgia; provided, however, said city court shall not have original jurisdiction in civil cases where the amount involved is less than one hundred dollars. Jurisdiction. Civil.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said city court of Clarkesville shall have jurisdiction to try and dispose of all criminal cases for all offenses committed in
the county of Habersham, where the offender is not subjected to the loss of life or confinement in the penitentiary. Criminal.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That there shall be a judge of said city court of Clarkesville who shall be appointed by the governor by and with the advice and consent of the senate, whose term of office shall be four years, and all vacancies in said office shall be filled by appointment of the governor for the residue of the unexpired term, such appointment being subject to the approval of the senate, which may be then in session, or if the senate be not in session at the time of such appointment, or shall fail to act, then subject to the approval of the senate at its next session thereafter; provided, that the judge first appointed under this Act shall, if the senate be not in session, or shall fail to act, hold and fill the office, subject to the approval of the senate at the next session thereafter. The judge of the said city court of Clarkesville shall receive a salary of five hundred dollars per annum, which shall not be increased or diminished during his term of office, and shall be paid monthly out of the treasury of the county of Habersham. Judge. Salary.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That any person who shall be appointed judge of said city court must, at the time of said appointment, be at least twenty-seven years of age; he must also have been a resident of Habersham county at least four years immediately preceding his appointment, and must also have been a practicing attorney at law at least five years before his appointment, and before entering upon the discharge of the duties of his office he shall take and subscribe the following oath: I solemuly swear that I will administer justice without respect to persons and do equal right to the poor and rich and that I will faithfully and impartially discharge and perform all the duties which may be required of me as judge of the city court of Clarkesville, according to the best of my ability and understanding, according to the laws and constitution of this State and of the United States, so help me God. And said oath shall be forwarded to the governor and filed in the executive department. Said judge shall have the right to practice law in all courts except the city court of Clarkesville. Qualifications. Oath.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That there shall be a solicitor of said city court of Clarkesville to be appointed by the governor, by and with the advice and consent of the senate, whose term of office shall be four years,
and all vacancies in said office shall be filled by appointment of the governor for the residue of the unexpired term, such appointment being subject to the approval of the senate which may be then in session, or if the senate be not in session at the time of such appointment, or shall fail to act, then subject to the approval of the senate at its next session thereafter; provided, that the solicitor first appointed under this Act shall, if the senate be not in session, or shall fail to act, hold and fill the office, subject to the approval of the senate at the next session thereafter. The fees of such solicitor shall be as follows: For every case finally disposed of in said city court founded on accusation, ten dollars ($10.00); for every indictment or special presentment finally disposed of in the city court, five dollars ($5.00); for every case for a violation of the gambling laws of this State, twenty-five dollars ($25.00); for representing the State in each case carried to the supreme court from said city court, fifteen dollars ($15.00). Said solicitor shall for his services in the supreme court be paid out of the treasury of the State by warrant, drawn by the governor, upon certificate of the clerk of the supreme court as to the performance of such services, and the certificate of the clerk of the city court of the insolvency or acquittal of the defendant. For all services for which this Act does not provide said solicitor shall receive the same fees now allowed by law for similar services in the superior court. Said solicitor, before entering upon the duties of his office shall give bond with good security in the sum of one thousand dollars, conditioned for the faithful discharge of the duties of his office, and shall in addition to the oath required of all civil officers take and subscribe the following oath: I do swear that I will faithfully and impartially, and without fear, favor or affection discharge my duties as solicitor of the city court of Clarkesville, so help me God. Said bond shall be payable to the governor, shall be approved by the judge of said city court and shall, together with said oath, be entered on the minutes of said court by the clerk, and may be sued on by any person interested. If for any reason said solicitor shall fail or be disqualified to act in any case the court shall have power to appoint a solicitor pro tem. Solicitor. Fees. Bond. Oath. Solicitor pro tem.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the clerk of the superior court of Habersham county shall be ex officio clerk of the said city court and shall perform in said city court the same duties that are by law, required
of him as an officer of the superior court, so far as the same are applicable, and for his services shall receive the same compensation he is entitled to receive for similar services in the superior court, and for his attendance on the regular terms of said city court he shall receive three dollars ($3.00) per diem. Clerk.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the sheriff of Habersham county shall, by virtue of his office, be sheriff of the city court of Clarkesville and in his official connection with said court shall be known as the sheriff of the city of Clarkesville. Before entering on the discharge of the duties of his office he shall execute a bond with good security in the sum of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) for the faithful discharge of the duties of his office. He shall have power, with the consent of the judge of said court, to appoint a deputy, who shall, before entering upon the discharge of the duties of his office, give a good bond in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) conditioned as the bonds of other deputy sheriffs. Said sheriff shall receive the same fees as are now or may be hereafter allowed by law to the sheriff of Habersham county, and for his attendance at the regular terms of said city court he shall receive two dollars per diem to be paid in the manner as now or as may hereafter be allowed him for similar services in the superior court of Habersham county. Sheriff. Bond. Deputy. Bond. Fees.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the judge of the city court of Clarkesville is empowered to exercise the same authority over the clerk and sheriff and deputy sheriff of said court as may be exercised by the judges of the superior court over the clerks and sheriffs and deputy sheriffs in the counties in Georgia. Judge, power of.

Sec. X. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the judge of the city court of Clarkesville shall have authority to issue criminal warrants, warrants to dispossess tenants holding over, and intruders; to issue distress warrants; to issue attachments and garnishments; to attest deeds and other papers, and take affidavits anywhere in this State; and said judge, solicitor, clerk and sheriff and his deputy shall have power to administer all oaths, and do all other official acts pertaining to their offices respectively as the judge and other officers of the superior court may in like cases do; said judge shall also have power to issue writs of habeas corpus and hear and determine the same as judges of the superior court may
do; to cause testimony to be taken to be used de bene esse and for the purpose of perpetuating testimony within his jurisdiction, and generally to do all acts which the judges of the county courts of this State are authorized to do, unless otherwise provided in this Act. And said judge of the city court of Clarkesville shall have all the powers and authority, throughout his jurisdiction, of judges of the superior courts, except where, by law, exclusive power and authority is vested in the judges of the superior court, and all laws relating to and governing judges of the superior courts shall apply to the judge of said city court, so far as the same may be applicable, except as herein provided. Authority of.

Sec. XI. Be it further by the authority aforesaid, That the regular terms of said city court of Clarkesville shall be held quarterly, beginning on the first Mondays in February, May, August and November of each year. The judge of said court shall have power to hold said court in session from day to day for a period not longer than one week from the beginning of each term. Terms.

Sec. XII. Be it further enacted, by the authority aforesaid, That suits in said city court shall in all respects be conformable to the mode of proceedings in the superior courts, except as hereinafter provided; but the process to writs shall be annexed by the clerk of said city court, shall be attested in the name of the judge thereof, and be directed to and served by the sheriff of the city court of Clarkesville or his deputy thereof, and all executions issuing from said court shall be attested in the name of the judge and signed by the clerk and directed to the sheriff or his deputy of the city court of Clarkesville, and to all and singular the sheriffs or their deputies of the State of Georgia. Practice in.

Sec. XIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid That in all matters pertaining to service and pleading and practice, the laws governing the superior courtwhere not inconsistent with this Act, and unless otherwise specially provided for in this Actshall be applicable to said city court. Pleadings.

Sec. XIV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the judge of said city court shall have power and authority to hear and determine all civil cases of which said court has jurisdiction and to give judgment therein; provided, that either party in any civil cause pending in said court shall be entitled to a trial by a jury in said court, upon entering a demand therefor, by himself or his attorney, in writing, on or before the call of the appearance docket at the appearance term
of said case, in all cases in which such party may be entitled to a trial by jury under the constitution and laws of this State. Jury trials.

Sec. XV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said court shall have jurisdiction of all claim cases, where personal property is levied under process from said court, which claim shall be tried in the same manner as claims in the superior court, except that the pleadings in the case shall make the issue, and it shall be unnecessary for the parties to tender and join issue in claim cases as is practiced in other courts. Claim cases.

Sec. XVI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws upon the subject of attachments and garnishments in the superior courts of this State shall apply to said city court so far as the nature of the city court will admit. The judge of said city court or any other officer authorized by law to issue attachments, may issue attachments returnable to said city court under the same laws that govern the issuing of attachments in the superior courts, and all attachments returnable to the city court of Clarkesville shall be directed to all and singular the sheriffs and constables of this State and may be served by the sheriff of the city court or his deputy, or any sheriff or constable or other officer authorized by law to levy attachments returnable to other courts. Attachments and garnishments.

Sec. XVII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That garnishment proceedings in said city court shall be conformable to the laws in the State on the subject in the superior court. Garnishments.

Sec. XVIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all proceedings to make parties in any cause in the city court shall conform to the laws on that subject in the superior court. Rules to make parties.

Sec. XIX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the general laws of this State with regard to the commencement of suits in the superior courts, defenses, sets-off, affidavits of illegality, arbitration, examination of witnesses by interrogatories or under subp[oelig]na, witnesses and their attendance, continuances and all matters pertaining to pleading and practice, and all matters of judicial nature within the jurisdiction of said city court shall be applicable to said city court. Pleading and practice.

Sec. XX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said city court of Clarkesville shall be a court of record and shall have a seal, and the minutes, records, dockets, and other books and files that are required by law to be kept for
the superior courts shall be kept in and for said city court and in the same manner, and all laws applicable to the duties of the clerk and sheriff of the superior court shall apply to them in said city court, except where they conflict with the provisions of this Act. Court of record.

Sec. XXI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws regulating the enforcement of judgments of the superior courts, whether civil or criminal, shall apply to said city court, and executions shall issue and be levied and sales be had thereunder under the same rules and laws regulating the same in the superior courts. Judgments of.

Sec. XXII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the judge of the city court of Clarkesville shall have the power to enforce his orders, to preserve order, punish for contempt, and to enforce all his judgments as is vested by law in the judges of the superior court of this State. Contempt.

Sec. XXIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That traverse jurors in the city court of Clarkesville shall be procured in the following manner: The clerk of said court shall provide a city court jury box similar to the traverse jury box of the superior court, and shall write upon separate pieces of paper the names of each person upon the grand jury list of the superior court and of each person upon the traverse jury list of the superior court, and shall place said names of all persons on said superior court list in the city court jury box, from which shall be drawn traverse juries to serve in the city court. All laws with reference to the drawing and summoning and empaneling traverse jurors in the superior court shall apply to the city court of Clarkesville; provided, that the number of jurors so drawn shall be fifteen instead of thirty-six as provided for in the superior courts, and said city court judge shall have the same power to summons tales jurors for the city court that the judges of the superior court have for the superior courts. Jurors in said city court shall receive the same pay and be paid in the same manner and under the same rules and regulations as jurors in the superior courts are or may hereafter be paid. The sheriff shall be entitled to a fee of two dollars for summoning the jurors for each term. Traverse jurors.

Sec. XXIV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws with reference to the qualification, empaneling challenging and fining jurors, now of force or hereafter to be enacted, regulating the same in the superior court, shall apply to and be observed in said city court, except when inconsistent
with the provisions of this Act. In all cases where issues are to be tried by jury, the parties shall be entitled to twelve jurors from which to strike. In civil cases each party shall be entitled to three peremptory challenges, and in criminal cases the defendant shall be entitled to four peremptory challenges and the State two, and all laws and rules governing the selection of juries in the superior courts shall apply to the city court of Clarkesville, unless inconsistent with this Act. Jurors.

Sec. XXV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all civil cases pending in said city court in which a jury is demanded by either party, as provided in section fourteen of this Act, and all criminal cases in which the defendant shall demand a jury, as provided in section twenty-seven of this Act, a jury trial shall be had in term time under the provisions of this Act by a jury of six men. All civil cases in which no jury is demanded by either party shall be tried by the court in term time, and all criminal cases in which no jury is demanded by the defendant shall be tried by the court either in term time or at any time between the regular terms of said court, and said court shall be open for the trial of such criminal cases at all times. Jury trials:

Sec. XXVI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That defendants in criminal cases in said city court of Clarkesville may be tried on written accusation setting forth plainly the offense charged, which accusation shall be signed by the prosecutor and by the prosecuting officer of said city court. Accusations.

Sec. XXVII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That when any criminal case in the city court, founded either upon indictment or presentment by a grand jury, or upon an accusation in said city court, is called for trial, and before the arraignment of the defendant, the judge shall inquire of the defendant whether he demands a trial by jury, and the response of the defendant shall be entered on said indictment or accusation and signed by the prosecuting officer in said court. If the defendant demands a trial by jury and the said court is not sitting at a regular term the judge shall admit the defendant to bail to appear at the next regular term, or on the defendant's failure to give bond, shall commit him to jail to await his trial at a regular term. If the defendant waives trial by jury, then the judge of said court shall proceed to hear and determine such criminal cause without a jury; provided, always, that a reasonable time may be granted the State or defendant to procure witnesses. Demands for jury trial.

Sec. XXVIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the judges of the superior court of Habersham county may transfer any or all presentments or bills of indictment for misdemeanors to said city court for trial, the order so transmitting the same be entered on the minutes of both courts. Cases transferred

Sec. XXIX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the judge of said court shall have the same power to appoint bailiffs at each term of the court that judges of the superior court have. Bailiffs.

Sec. XXX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That a writ of error direct from said city court of Clarkesville to the supreme court of this State shall be upon bills of exceptions filed under the same rules and regulations as govern and control the filing of bills of exceptions and the issuing of writs of error in the superior courts of this State. Writ of error.

Sec. XXXI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all cases, civil and criminal, now pending and undisposed of in the superior court of Habersham county, of which said city court of Clarkesville has jurisdiction, shall be, and the same are, hereby transferred to said city court of Clarkesville, and the same shall be tried and disposed of as other cases in the city court of Clarkesville. All final and other processes heretofore issued returnable to the superior court of Habersham county shall be returned to the city court of Clarkesville. The judge and other officers of the city court of Clarkesville shall have power to issue and enforce in the name of the city court of Clarkesville any and all processes in any case from the superior court of Habersham county necessary to the final disposition of the same, which from any cause have not been issued and enforced by the officers of the superior court of Habersham county. Cases transferred from Superior Court.

Sec. XXXII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the judge of said city court of Clarkesville shall have power to grant new trials in all cases, civil and criminal, in said court upon the same terms and conditions and under the same laws and regulations in every respect governing the granting of new trials in the superior courts. All rules of pleading, practice and procedure governing motions for new trial in the superior courts shall apply to and govern the same in said city court. New trials.

Sec. XXXIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the first term of said court to which a case is
brought shall be the appearance or return term, and the second term shall be the trial or judgment term. And all the laws, rules and practice in the superior courts with reference to the terms thereof shall apply in the city court of Clarkesville, unless in conflict with this Act, or otherwise provided herein. Appearance and trial terms.

Sec. XXXIV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That whenever the judge of said city court is from any cause disqualified from presiding in any case, and the judge of the superior court, on account of absence or other cause, shall fail to preside in said court, as provided in the constitution of this State, then, upon consent of parties or upon their failure or refusal to agree, said cause may be tried by a judge pro hac vice selected in the same manner as now provided for in the superior court. Judge pro hac vice.

Sec. XXXV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the judge of said city court shall have power and authority to hire out convicts of said city court, under and subject to the laws and regulations governing the hiring out of misdemeanor convicts of this State, and the money arising from such hire shall constitute part of the insolvent fund of said court, and shall be paid out by said judge together with fines and forfeitures, as provided in section thirty-six of this Act. Hire of convicts.

Sec. XXXVI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That at or within ten days after each regular term of said city court, and oftener if he shall deem proper to do so, the judge of said court shall distribute the fines and forfeitures and convict hire arising from cases tried in said court as follows: Fines, forfeitures and convict hire arising in cases which originate in said city court shall be prorated between the solicitor and clerk and sheriff of the city court and justices of the peace and constables on their bills for insolvent costs in cases originating in said city court; fines, forfeitures and convict hire arising from cases transferred from the superior court to the city court shall be prorated between the solicitor, clerk and sheriff of the city court, the solicitor-general and clerk and sheriff of the superior court and justices of the peace and constables on their bills for insolvent costs in transferred cases. If at any time there shall be a surplus of the insolvent fund arising from cases originating in the city court after paying all insolvent costs on cases originating in the city court, the same shall be applied to the insolvent costs in transferred cases,
and if at any time there shall be a surplus of the insolvent fund arising in transferred cases after paying all insolvent costs in transferred cases, the same shall be applied to insolvent costs in cases originating in city court. The judge of said city court shall, before paying insolvent bill, approve the same and order them entered on the minutes of said city court, and such bills for insolvent costs shall be a lien on said insolvent funds superior to all other liens. Fines and forfeitures.

Sec. XXXVII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the ordinary of Habersham county shall provide the necessary books for keeping the dockets, minutes and records of said city court and all other books and stationery necessary to run said court, and that said city court shall be held in the courthouse of Habersham county in the city of Clarkesville. Books, etc.

Sec. XXXVIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in misdemeanor cases transferred from the superior court to the city court of Clarkesville the costs of the solicitor-general of the circuit shall be five dollars, to be collected and paid as other costs in the said city court. Costs.

Sec. XXXIX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the judge of the superior court of Habersham county may transfer all cases, civil or criminal, to the city court of Clarkesville in term time or in vacation. Transfers.

Sec. XL. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the several justices of the peace of said county in admitting defendants to bail in misdemeanor cases, and all other parties or officers taking bond for the appearance of any defendant who stands charged with a misdemeanor shall make same returnable to said city court of Clarkesville, either at term time or at such time as may be set or agreed upon in vacation for the trial of said case, whether said case originates by accusation in said city court of Clarkesville, or by indictment or presentment by the grand jury of said county. Appearance bonds

Sec. XLI. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That upon the failure on the part of any defendant to appear and answer to any charge he may stand accused of in said city court at the time named in said bond, said bond shall be forfeited, either in term time or in vacation, by the officers of said city court, under the same rules and regulations as bonds are now forfeited in the superior courts of this State, and the fees of the officers of said city court of Clarkesville, in cases of forfeited bonds, shall be the same as are now allowed by law to
the officers of the superior courts of this State for like service. Forfeiture.

Sec. XLII. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That no person charged with an offense falling within the jurisdiction of said city court of Clarkesville shall have the right to demand indictment by the grand jury before trial. Indictment
Sec. XLIII. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: DAWSON, CITY COURT OF, ESTABLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to establish the city court of Dawson in and for the county of Terrell, to define its jurisdiction and powers, to provide for the appointment of a judge, solicitor and other officers thereof and to define their powers and duties; to provide for pleading and practice and new trials therein and writs of error therefrom to the supreme court, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That the city court of Dawson, to be located in the city of Dawson, in the county of Terrell, is hereby established and created with civil and criminal jurisdiction over the whole county of Terrell, concurrent with the superior court to try and dispose of all civil cases of whatever nature wherein the amount claimed or involved, inclusive of interest, is as much as fifty dollars, except those of which the constitution of this State has given the superior court exclusive jurisdiction, and with criminal jurisdiction to try and dispose of all offenses below the grade of felony committed in the county of Terrell; that the jurisdiction herein conferred shall include not only the ordinary suits by petition and process, but also all other kinds of suits and proceedings which now or hereafter may be in use in the superior courts, either under the common law or
statute, including, among others, attachment and garnishment proceedings, illegalities, counter affidavits to any proceeding from said court, statutory awards, proceedings against intruders and tenants holding over, partitions of personalty, issues upon distress warrants, foreclosure of all liens and mortgages and quo warrantos. City court of Dawson Jurisdiction of.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said city court shall have concurrent jurisdiction with the superior court of all appeals and certioraries from all inferior courts in said county, except the court of ordinary, said appeals and certioraries to be had under the same rules governing such remedies in the superior court. The said city court judge is hereby given authority to sanction petitions for certiorari returnable to said city court. The writs of certiorari shall be issued in five days after filing the petition, and sanctioned and made returnable to the first quarterly term after twenty-five days from the date of said writ. As to everything else relating to certioraries the same rules shall apply as the superior court. Appeals shall be returned to the quarterly terms and stand for trial at the first term after ten days from the time of entering the appeal. Appeals and certiorari

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That there shall be a judge of said city court, who shall be appointed by the governor, by and with the consent and advice of the senate, who shall hold his office for the term of four years, and all vacancies in the office of judge shall be filled by appointment by the governor for the residue of the unexpired term, but should a vacancy occur when the senate shall not be in session, the governor shall make appointment to fill such vacancy, and submit such appointment to the senate which shall next thereafter convene. The judge of said city court shall receive a salary of six hundred dollars per annum, which shall neither be diminished nor increased during his continuance, except to apply to a subsequent term in office, and which shall be paid monthly by the treasurer of the county of Terrell; and it shall be the duty of the commissioners of roads and revenues of said county, or other proper officer, to make provision annually in levying the taxes for this purpose. The said judge shall receive no other compensation, but may practice law in any court except his own. Judge. Salary.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That no one shall be eligible to the office of said judgeship unless he be, at the time of his qualification, at least thirty years of age,
a resident of Terrell county for four years immediately preceding the appointment and must have practiced law four years. He shall before entering upon the duties of his office take and subscribe the following oath: I solemnly swear that I wil administer justice without respect to persons, and do equal right to the poor and rich, and that I will faithfully and impartially perform and discharge all duties which may be required of me as judge of the city court of Dawson, of this State, according to the best of my ability and understanding, agreeably to the laws and constitution of this State, and the constitution of the United States, so help me. God, which oath shall be filed in the executive department. Qualifications of judge. Oath.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That there shall be a solicitor of said city court, appointed by the governor, by and with the advice and consent of the senate, whose term of office shall be four years and whose duties it shall be to prosecute for all offenses cognizable before said court. All vacancies in said office shall be filled by appointment by the governor for the remainder of the unexpired term, and should a vacancy occur when the senate shall not be in session, the governor shall fill such vacancy by appointment, and shall submit such appointment to the senate at its next session thereafter. The said solicitor shall receive the same fees for each written accusation as are allowed a solicitor-general for each indictment in the superior court, and his fees for all other services rendered shall be the same as are allowed a solicitor-general of the superior court. In the absence or disqualification of said solicitor, the city court judge shall appoint a solicitor pro tem., who shall receive the same fees as are allowed the regularly appointed solicitor of said court. Solicitor. Fees.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the solicitor of said city court shall for his services in the supreme court be paid out of the treasury of the State in the same manner as the solicitor-general of the superior court is paid for like services rendered in the supreme court. In Supreme Court.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the clerk and his deputies of the superior court of Terrell county shall be ex officio clerk and deputies of said city court. Said clerk shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, take and subscribe an oath to faithfully and impartially discharge the duties thereof, which oath shall be entered on the book of minutes of said city court. He shall also before entering on the duties of his office execute a bond with good
security in the sum of one thousand dollars for the faithful discharge of the duties of his office. Clerk.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the sheriff of Terrell county shall be ex officio sheriff of said city court of Dawson, and in his official connection with said court he shall be known as the sherift of the city court of Dawson. Before entering upon the discharge of the duties of his office, said sheriff shall execute a bond with good security in the sum of two thousand dollars for the faithful discharge of the duties of his office. He shall have power to appoint a deputy or deputies with the consent of said judge. Sheriff.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all the duties and liabilities attached to the office of clerk of the superior court and to the office of sheriff shall be attached to the office of clerk of the city court of Dawson, and to the office of sheriff of the city court of Dawson, respectively, and that the judge of said city court of Dawson is empowered to enforce the same authority over the said clerk and sheriff and their deputies as is exercised by the judge of the superior courts over the clerks of the superior courts and sheriffs of the counties of Georgia. Clerk and sheriff.

Sec. X. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the clerk of said city court shall be paid two dollars per day, and the sheriff thereof three dollars per day for attendance upon said court, and unless otherwise specified in this Act they and their deputies shall receive for all other services the same fees as are allowed by law for like services in the superior court and for services rendered when no compensation is provided by law; they shall receive such compensation as the judge of said city court shall in his sound discretion allow; they shall be amenable to the same processes and penalties as they are now amenable to as officers of the superior court, and they shall be entitled to the same remedies to enforce the collection of their fees and costs in said city court as they are now entitled to in the superior court. Clerk and sheriff. Per diem. Fees.

Sec. XI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the judge of said city court shall have power to issue writs of habeas corpus and to hear and dispose of the same in the same way and with the same power as the judge of the superior court. Habeas corpus.

Sec. XII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the terms of said city court shall be monthly and quarterly; the monthly terms for the trial and disposition of criminal business and the quarterly terms for the trial and disposition of either
or both criminal and civil business. The times for holding said terms of said court shall be fixed by the city court judge, such terms to be as near equidistant as convenience will admit, notice of which shall be given by advertisement one time in the newspaper where the sheriff sales for said county are published. The terms of such court shall be held at the court house in the city of Dawson, in said county of Terrell, for which, when necessary, juries shall be drawn as hereinafter directed, and shall last until the business is disposed of, unless sooner adjourned for good cause. The judge of said city court shall, in his discretion, hold his court at the same place at any other times than the regular terms for the transaction of criminal business which does not require a jury, as speedily as possible, consistent with the interests of the State and the accused, and may also hold adjourned terms of the regular monthly and quarterly terms of said city court, for which he may draw new juries, or require the attendance of the same, as in his sound legal discretion may seem best. Said city court judge may also, in his discretion, set cases for trial at convenient times, and the same may then be tried as of the term, whether court has been held from day to day until said time or not. Terms.

Sec. XIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That suits in said city court shall in all respects be conformable to the mode of proceedings in the superior court, except as hereinafter provided, but the process to writs shall be annexed by the clerk of said city court, be tested in the name of the judge thereof and be directed to and served by the sheriff of the city court of Dawson or his deputies thereof. Practice.

Sec. XIV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That in all matters pertaining to service, pleadings and practice, the laws governing the superior court, where not inconsistent with this Act, and unless otherwise specially provided by this Act, shall be applicable to said city court. Practice.

Sec. XV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the judge of said city court shall have the power and authority to hear and determine without a jury all civil causes of which the said court has jurisdiction and to give judgment and execution therein; provided, always, that either party in any cause shall be entitled to a trial by jury in said court upon entering a demand therefor by himself or his attorney, in writing, on or before the call of the docket at the term to which the cause is returnable, in all cases where such party is entitled to a trial by jury under the constitution and laws of this State. Trials.

Sec. XVI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all judgments obtained in said court shall be a lien on all property of the defendant or defendants throughout the State in the manner as judgments of the superior courts are; but property exempt from levy and sale under laws of this State shall be exempt from levy and sale under process from said court, and all executions issuing from said court, shall be tested in the name of the judge and signed by the clerk and directed to the sheriff or his deputies of the said City Court of Dawson, and to all and singular the sheriffs or their deputies of the State of Georgia. Judgments.

Sec. XVII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said court shall have jurisdiction of all claim cases where personal property is levied on under execution or other process from said court, and such claims shall be tried in the same manner as claims in the superior courts. Claim cases.

Sec. XVIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That claims to real property levied on under execution or other process from said city court, shall be returned to the superior court of the county where such real property is situated, and shall there proceed as other claims in the superior court. Claims to realty.

Sec. XIX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws upon subjects of attachments and garnishments as to any manner whatever in the superior courts of this State shall apply to said city court as if named with the superior court, so far as the nature of the city court will admit. Attachments in said court, returnable to said court, shall be directed to the sheriff or his deputies of the city court of Dawson, and to all and singular the sheriffs and constables of this State, and the judge of said city court may, or any justice of the peaee or notary public may issue attachments returnable to said city court, under the same laws that govern the issuing of attachments returnable to the superior courts. Attachments and garnishments.

Sec. XX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That garnishment and attachment proceedings and proceedings on distress warrants in said city court shall be conformable to the laws of the State on the subject in the superior court. Garnishments, attachments and distress warrants.

Sec. XXI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That scire facias to make parties in any cause in said city court shall be had as in the superior court, but such scire facias shall run throughout the State, and may be served by any sheriff or his deputy thereof. Parties,

Sec. XXII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the general laws of this State, with regard to the commencement of suits in the superior courts, defenses, set-offs affidavits of illegality, arbitration, examination of parties to suits or witnesses by interrogatories or under subp[oelig]nas, witnesses and their attendance, continuances or other matters of a judicial nature within the jurisdiction of said city court, shall be applicable to said city court. Practice.

Sec. XXIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the judge of said city court shall have power to cause testimony to be taken and used de bene esse and for the purpose of perpetuating testimony within his jurisdiction in all cases according to the general laws of the State, and the judge and all other officers of said city court shall have power respectively to administer all oaths pertaining to their office as the judge and other officers of the superior court may in like cases do; and said judge shall have power to attest deeds and other papers and administer affidavits in all cases anywhere in the State in which by existing laws deeds and papers may be attested and affidavits administered by justices of the peace of this State, and the judge of the said city court shall have all the powers and authority throughout his jurisdiction of judges of the superior courts, and all laws relating to and governing judges of the superior courts shall apply to the judge of said city court, so far as the same may be applicable, except as herein provided. Judge, Powers of.

Sec. XXIV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said city court of Dawson shall be a court of record, and shall have a seal, and the minutes, records, order, and other books and files that are required by law, and rules, to be kept for the superior court shall be kept in and for said city court and in the same manner, and all laws applicable to the duties of the clerk and sheriff in said superior court shall apply to them in said city court, except where they conflict with the provisions of this Act. Court of record.

Sec. XXV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws regulating the enforcing of judgments of the superior courts, whether civil or criminal shall apply to said city court, and executions shall issue and be levied and sales be had thereunder under the same rules and laws regulating the same in the superior court. Judgments.

Sec. XXVI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the judge of said city court shall have the power to enforce
