law.shorttitle: CLARKSTON, PUBLIC SCHOOLS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to provide for a system of public schools for the town of Clarkston, in Dekalb county, to provide by special tax for the maintenance and support of the same, to provide suitable buildings therefor, to establish a board of education to conduct the same, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That there shall be established, conducted, maintained, supported and provided for by local taxation and otherwise, in the manner hereinafter provided in this Act, a system of public schools in and for the town of Clarkston, Dekald county, Georgia. Clarkston. Public schools.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That there shall be a board of education for said town under the corporate name of the Clarkston Board of Education, with the right to sue and be sued in said corporate name, and whose duty it shall be to establish, manage, control and maintain said public schools. Said board shall consist of five members, to be elected by the mayor and council of said
town within thirty days from the time this Act goes into effect, or as soon thereafter as practicable. At the first elections two members shall be elected for two years and three members shall be elected for the term of one year, and thereafter election for members of the board of education shall be held annually on the first Monday in December of each year, or so soon thereafter as practicable, and the terms of members elected after said first election shall be for two years. All vacancies on the board of education shall be filled by special elections for the unexpired terms only. The members of said board may hold their office until their successors shall be elected and qualified. No person shall be eligible to membership upon said board except such persons as would be eligible to the office of mayor of said town, and no person shall be eligible to election to such membership who at the time of his election is a mayor or a councilman of said town. Board of education. Corporate name and powers. Members of board. Election. Terms of office. Vacancies. Qualification of members.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That the officers of the board of education shall be a president, a vice-president and a secretary and treasurer and such other officers as the board may deem advisable. The secretary and treasurer of said board shall before entering upon the discharge of the duties of his office take and subscribe an oath to faithfully discharge the duties of his office, and shall give bond in such sum as may be fixed by the board to faithfully account for all moneys coming into his hands as such officer; which said bond shall be made payable to the said board of education, and the said board of education is hereby empowered to bring suit and maintain the same upon said bonds in any of the courts of this State for any breach of said bond by the said secretary and treasurer, and the proceeds of said suit shall be applied to the public schools of said town. Said secretary and treasurer shall pay out no moneys except by orders of the board. Officers of board.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, That the said board of education shall have the power, and it is hereby made the duty of said board, to speedily devise, design, adopt and establish under this Act, a system of public schools, to modify the same from time to time; to establish such schools as they see fit for the whites and also for the blacks of said town, and which for the two races shall be entirely separate and distinct from each other and not more than one school for each race unless said board of education shall, at a regular meeting, order more than one, and in this have the concurrence of the mayor and council of the town of Clarkston. Schools, how established.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That the said board of education shall keep full and accurate minutes of the proceedings of said board, which shall at all times be subject to the inspection of
the mayor and council of the town or of any citizen of said town. Said board shall supervise, regulate and make efficient said school system, shall prescribe the curriculum and the books to be used in said schools, shall elect and employ teachers for said schools, and if they see fit a superintendent for said schools; they shall fix the school terms and the time of beginning and closing of said schools; they shall have the right to suspend or remove such teachers and superintendent whenever, in the discretion of the members of said board they may deem such action to be for the best interests of said schools, and their action in so doing shall be conclusive in all cases and not subject to review by any body or court; they shall fix the compensation of the teachers and pay the same; they shall make such by-laws for the government of said board and for the control of said teachers and schools as may be deemed fit and proper when the same are not in conflict with the laws of the State; they may provide grades in said schools and provide suitable apparatus, furniture and appliances of every kind for the use of said schools, and do any and all other acts which they may deem best to promote the best educational interests of said town not in conflict with State laws. Board, proceedings of. Government of schools.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted, That said board is authorized and empowered to receive, hold, apply, sell or expend any donation, gift or bequest of property of any kind, real or personal, made to said board for the benefit of the schools of said town. School property.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted, That said board shall, out of any funds going into their hands, provide school houses, by renting or by purchasing suitable buildings, and shall properly furnish the same for school purposes. The title of all such property shall be in the corporation of the town of Clarkston. School-houses.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted, That said board of education shall keep accurate accounts of all moneys or property received by them for the use of said public schools and of all expenditures made by them; these accounts shall be at all times open to the inspection of the mayor and council of Clarkston or of any citizen of said town. The members of said board shall be personally liable to the corporation of the town of Clarkston for all moneys paid over to said board for the use of said public schools and by said board appropriated for any other purpose. Receipts and expenditures. Liability of members of board.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted, That said board shall annually make report to the mayor and eouncil of Clarkston in writing of the condition of said schools and shall accompany said report with a full and itemized statement of all moneys received and expended by said board and present the vouchers therefor. This report
shall contain an estimate of the amount of funds required for the proper conduct of said schools for the ensuing school year, and like reports shall be furnished at any time by said board to the said mayor and council at any time upon request of said mayor and council. Reports of board.

Sec. X. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the terms of office of the officers of said board shall be fixed by the by-laws of the board, and no officer shall have any compensation for their services except the secretary and treasurer, whose compensation shall be fixed by the board prior to his election and qualification. Officers of board, compensation of.
Sec. XI. Be it further enacted, That the public schools herein provided for shall run for a period of not less than five nor more than ten scholastic months in each year. School year.

Sec. XII. Be it further enacted, That if the election herein provided for shall be in favor of public schools, then the mayor and council of said town of Clarkston shall be authorized and empowered to assess, levy and collect annually a tax in addition to that now provided for by law, not to exceed one-fourth of one per cent. per annum, on all the taxable property of said town which shall be used solely and exclusively for the purpose of establishing and maintaining said schools and providing furniture, apparatus, grounds and buildings for said schools. This tax shall be collected by the first day of January of each year after the same is assessed and levied, and shall be turned over to the said board of education to be used for the purposes aforesaid and no other. School tax.

Sec. XIII. Be it further enacted, That all school children between the ages of six and eighteen years, who are bona fide residents of said town with their parents or guardians, shall be entitled to the benefit of said schools, and no such child or children shall be required to pay any tuition for such course of study as is now provided by law in the public schools of the several counties of the State; but the board may, in their discretion, require each child in said town, and children living outside the limits of said town, to pay an incidental fee during any term of said school outside of the terms when the free schools are taught, not exceeding fifty cents per month, and said board may require children living outside of the limits of said town to pay tuition except for and during the free school terms. All such tuition charges shall become a part of the fund for the maintenance of said public school system and
must be so used and accounted for as shall likewise all other fees. School children. Tuition.

Sec. XIV. Be it further enacted, That authority is hereby granted to the trustees of any school, white or colored, now in said town of Clarkston, or that may hereafter be in said town, to turn over or legally convey any school property, real or personal that they hold to the Clarkston board of education for the public schools of said town; and all property so turned over and conveyed by the trustees of a white school shall be used exclusively for the establishing, support and maintenance of the public schools for the white children of said town, and all property turned over and conveyed to the board of education by the trustees of any colored school shall be used exclusively for the establishment, support and maintenance of the public school of the colored children of said town. The title to all such property shall be vested in the mayor and council of Clarkston. Trustees of other schools.

Sec. XV. Be it further enacted, That moneys arising from, furnished, or collected by the corporation of the town of Clarkston under this Act for the establishment, maintenance and support of the said public schools, shall be paid over to the Clarkston board of education, upon said board giving bond with good security payable to the corporation of the town of Clarkston, in such sums as the mayor and town council may fix, conditioned for the faithful application of all of said funds in establishing and maintaining the public schools in this Act provided for; provided, it shall be optional with the mayor and town council to exact such bond, or not, as they may deem best. Bond of board.

Sec. XVI. Be it further enacted, That the board of education of Dekalb county shall not establish or open any school within the corporate limits of said town of Clarkston, nor have any authority or voice in the management of the school therein established under the provisions of this Act by the board of education of Clarkston. County school board.

Sec. XVII. Be it further enacted, That the county school commissioner of Dekalb county shall pay over to the board of education of Clarkston the pro rata share of the State and county school fund to which said town is entitled according to the number of school children of school age residing within the corporate limits of said town, increased by the number of children in said county between the ages of six and eighteen attending said school. Said town is hereby declared to be entitled
to the same proportion of said school fund as the total number of children of public school age residing within the corporate limits of the town, increased by the number of children of said county of public school age attending said public school, bears to the total number of children of school age residing within the limits of said county of Dekalb, as shown by the last school census. The amounts so to be paid shall be paid at such times as the teachers of the county are paid, and when paid shall be expended by said board for the support and maintenance of the public schools of Clarkston. State and county school fund, pro rata share.

Sec. XVIII. Be it further enacted, That before this Act shall become operative and go into effect, it shall be submitted to the qualified voters of said town of Clarkston to determine whether or not said public schools shall be established and maintained, and to this end, the mayor and town council shall within thirty days from the passage of this Act, or as soon thereafter as practicable, order an election in conformity with the provisions of article 8 section 4, paragraph 1 of the constitution of this State on the question of local taxation to establish and support said system of public schools, of which election four weeks' notice shall be given signed by the mayor and clerk of council and published in the Dekalb New Era, or in the newspaper designated the official organ of the town of Clarkston, and also posted in three or more public places in said town in addition to this newspaper advertisement. Said election shall be held at the council chamber of said town under the same rules and regulations as do apply to the election of mayor and town councilmen for said town. Those in favor of public schools and local taxation therefor shall have written or printed on their tickets for public schools, and those opposed shall have written or printed on their tickets against public schools. The managers of said election shall make returns of the result of said election by ten o'clock forenoon on the day succeeding the election to the mayor and council of said town, who shall at 12 o'clock of the same day succeeding said election, or as soon thereafter as practicable, meet and open said returns and declare the results thereof, and which result shall be entered on the minutes of said council. If two-thirds of the qualified voters of said town, measured by the number of votes cast at the last general election for mayor and councilmen of the town, shall be for public schools, then this Act shall take effect immediately, and the mayor and town council shall immediately proceed to carry it into effect by assessing, levying and collecting the tax, electing the board of education, and doing all those things herein required of
them for the establishment of said schools. Should this Act fail of adoption at said election the mayor and council may submit the same to another election under the same rules, regulations and qualifications after the expiration of six months and so continue to submit it until the same is favorable to the adoption of the Act; provided, elections shall not be had therefor oftener than once in six months, and it shall be the duty of the mayor and town council to order an [Illegible Text] on the written request of twenty-five freeholders of said town until the result is for public schools. Election for public schools.

Sec. XIX. Be it further enacted, That in case of the breaking out of any epidemic or contagious disease, the board shall have the right and power to stop and prevent any child that has been exposed to it or liable to contract it, for such time as said board shall deem prudent and safe. Contagious diseases.

Sec. XX. Be it further enacted, That all moneys raised by the corporation of said town of Clarkston by taxation or otherwise, shall be used only in paying the tuition of children between those ages, and in those branches or studies to which the public school laws of this State would entitle them in the public schools of the several counties, and pupils having studies not provided for by the school laws of this State are liable to pay such tuition and fees as the board may prescribe. Curriculum.

Sec. XXI. Be it further enacted, That the child of no person shall have the benefit of said public schools who fails or refuses to pay all taxes assessed against him or her by the corporation of the town of Clarkston, and which he or she is liable for. Defaulting taxpayers.

Sec. XXII. Be it further enacted, That all assessments of taxes, and all funds arising from or collected under this Act, shall be by the corporate authorities of the town of Clarkston kept separate and distinct from other assessments and collections of said town, and are to be used solely for the purpose herein designated; and the mayor and council shall have kept a separate, full, and distinct itemized account, showing all moneys raised and received, when and how, and from whom and what, and the disposition of the same, to whom, when and for what paid. School fund.
Sec. XXIII. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: LOGANVILLE, BONDS FOR PUBLIC SCHOOLS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend the charter of the town of Loganville in Walton county, Georgia, so as to provide in said charter, and thereby confer municipal authority, for the issuing of school bonds for said town, in accordance with the laws of said State, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That the charter of the town of Loganville in said State, as embodied in the Acts of 1887, page 508, and the Acts amendatory thereof, be, and the same is, hereby amended, as hereinafter set forth. Loganville. Charter amended.

Sec. II. The mayor and council of said town are hereby empowered to order an election by the qualified voters of said town on the question of Bonds or No bonds. Notice of said election shall be given as now prescribed by the code and constitution of said State. Election for bonds.

Sec. III. A two-thirds majority of all the qualified voters residing in said town shall be necessary to an election in favor of said bonds, as prescribed by lawthose voting in favor of bonds shall have printed or written on their tickets For school bonds, and those voting against bonds shall have printed or written on their tickets Against school bonds. Ballots.

Sec. IV. The qualifications of voters at said election shall be the same as those prescribed for those voting for mayor and council of said town. And the elections herein prescribed shall be held and returns thereof made as prescribed in said Acts of 1887, page 508, or the Acts amendatory thereof. Qualifications of voters. Election, how held, returns of.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That in the event the required number of votes shall be cast For school bonds, said mayor and council shall elect five suitable persons, to be known as The board of education of the Town of Loganville, who shall hold their office for two years, and until their successors shall be elected. Any vacancy that may exist on said board shall be filled by the mayor and the council. The proceeds arising from the sale of the bonds as herein prescribed, shall be used by said board of education in the purchase of a lot, or lots, and the purchase or erection of school buildings in said town, and for the equipment and maintenance
of the same in such manner as may be deemed best by said board. Board of education. Proceeds of bonds.

Sec. VI. If at said election that may be held under this Act the said bonds shall fail to secure the required number of votes, then the mayor and council shall be authorized to order another election to be held not less than six months after the preceding election. Second election.

Sec. VII. For the purpose of enabling said board of education to buy suitable real estate, and to purchase, build, equip or repair school houses, and to provide the same with suitable furniture and apparatus (if deemed advisable), the said mayor and council of said town are authorized to issue bonds of said town not to exceed five thousand dollars, to run not exceeding twenty years, bearing interest at eight per cent. per annum, payable annually, at such time and place as the said mayor and council may determine. Said bonds shall be issued in the sum of one hundred dollars each, shall be signed by the mayor and countersigned by council of said town, and shall have coupons attached to them for each installment of interest, signed by the treasurer of said town, and the bonds and interest coupons shall be payable by the treasurer on presentation at their maturity. Bonds, how issued.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted, That said mayor and council are hereby authorized, and they are hereby required, in the event the requisite number of votes should be cast for school bonds, to buy and collect such tax upon the taxable property of said town as will be necessary to carry out the provisions of this Act.. Tax.

Sec. IX. Be it further anacted, That the title to all property purchased or acquired under this Act with money arising from the sale of said bonds, shall vest in said board of education for the benefit of the schools they represent. School property.
Sec. X. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: TIFTON, PUBLIC SCHOOLS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to establish a public school system for the city of Tifton, Georgia; to provide for a board of education for said city; to provide for raising revenue to maintain said schools; to authorize and require the county school commissioner of Berrien county to pay over to the treasurer of said city such part of the State school funds as may be the pro rata share for all the children attending said schools, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act there shall be established in the city of Tifton in said State (the corporate authorities of said city having so recommended) a system of public schools, the same to be established, conducted, maintained and supported in the manner hereinafter set forth. Tifton. Public schools.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That the mayor and council of said city shall have charge of said schools, and that for the better carrying of this Act into effect, they shall elect annually on their first meeting night in January not less than three nor more than five trustees, who shall have immediate charge of said schools under the direction of said mayor and council, or the said mayor and council may by ordinance provide for the election of said trustees by the qualified voters of said city at the annual election for city officers. That whether elected by the voters or themselves, the said mayor and council shall by election fill all vacancies that shall occur in said board of trustees when all the members of said board of trustees within the city at the time have had notice of meeting; a majority shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any business. Trustees, Election of.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That no member of said board shall reside without the city of Tifton; that the officers of said board shall be a president and secretary, the former of whom shall be ex officio the superintendent of schools; the duties of the president shall be prescribed by the board, and he and the secretary shall hold their offices at the pleasure of the board. Trustees. Officers of board of trustees.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, That the duties of said trustees shall be to establish two schools in said city of Tifton, one for white children and one for colored children, which shall be entirely
distinct and separate; to provide schoolhouses by building, rent, purchase, or otherwise; to repair the same, to employ teachers, to provide the curriculum of said schools; to provide all necessary school furniture and educational appliances; to fix the salaries of teachers; to make all such by-laws, rules and regulations for the government of the board, and for the government of the said schools, and for the paying out of sehool funds, as they may deem necessary, and are not in conflict with the laws of this State or the ordinances of the city of Tifton; provided, that the title to all school property shall be vested in the mayor and council of said city of Tifton, and that the said board of trustees shall make no contracts nor incur any expenses without first having submitted an estimate of same to the city council, and having received an appropriation therefore. Duties of trustees. School property.
Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That the necessary funds for establishing, conducting and maintaining said public schools shall be derived as follows, to wit:

1st. The city council of Tifton is hereby empowered, authorized and required to levy each year, after the passage of this Act, a special ad valorem tax as the board of trustees shall recommend, not to exceed one-half of one per cent. on all property in said city subject to taxation by said city, to collect said tax and pay the same out on the order or contract of the said board of trustees. School tax.

2d. The county school commissioner of Berrien county is hereby authorized, empowered and required to pay over to the treasurer of the said city of Tifton the pro rata share of the State school fund for Berrien county for each child attending the schools established by said trustees upon the presentation by the said treasurer of Tifton of a list of pupils, with the number of days each has attended school, certified to by the principal of said schools. State school fund, pro rata share.

3d. The board of trustees of said school are hereby authorized, empowered and required to employ for said schools those teachers only who have a license to teach in the common schools of the State. Teachers.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted, That all sums paid as above required to the treasurer of the said city shall constitute the public school fund of said city, and shall be used and paid out for the following purposes, to wit: Payment of the salaries of teachers; building, purchasing, leasing or renting schoolhouses and repairing and insuring the same, purchasing school furniture and educational appliances and repairing the same, and for other purposes connected with and for the good of said schools. School fund, how applied.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted, That said schools shall be open
for not less than six nor longer than ten months in each year, and shall be free to all children between the ages of six and eighteen years, whose parents, guardians or natural protectors reside within the corporate limits of the city of Tifton, and the children of nonresidents and those over eighteen years of age may be admitted on such terms as the board of trustees may prescribe. School year. Pupils.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted, That any member of said board of education shall, for malfeasance or non-feasance, neglect of duty or other sufficient cause, be removed by a majority vote of the council of said city, and the vacancy shall be filled in the same manner by election. Trustees removable.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted, That the authorities of Berrien county shall not establish or open any school within the corporate limits of said city of Tifton, nor have any voice or authority in the management of the said schools therein established by the authorities of the said city of Tifton. County school.

Sec. X. Be it further enacted, That this Act shall be submitted to an election for the approval or disapproval by the qualified voters of the city of Tifton within ninety days after the passage of this Act. That notice of said election shall be by the mayor of the city of Tifton, published at least once previous to the day of said election. Those voters favoring this Act shall have written or printed on their ballots, For public schools, and those opposing shall have printed on their ballots Against public schools. That said election shall be held at the same time and in the same manner as elections for mayor and councilmen for the city of Tifton and the managers of said election shall certify the number of votes cast For public schools and Against public schools to the mayor and council of the city of Tifton, and if two-thirds of the qualified voters of said city shall vote For public schools, the mayor of said city shall so declare in writing and publish his said declaration once in a newspaper published in the said city, and upon said publication this Act shall take effect and be of force, and the public schools herein provided for shall be put in operation as soon as the mayor and council shall deem practicable, but should there not be a two-thirds majority in favor of public schools at the said election on the first Monday in December, 1898, then the question may again be submitted at the next annual city election, and so on each year until the same is adopted by the said two-thirds majority as above provided. Election for public schools. When and how held Returns. Other elections.
Sec. XI. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with the foregoing be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: WASHINGTON, PUBLIC SCHOOLS, LAW OF AMENDED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act approved September 14th, 1891, establishing a system of public schools in Washington, Georgia.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That from and after the passage of this Act, the above recited Act, approved September 14th, 1891, be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows: By inserting in the twelfth line of the seventh section of said Act, after the word tuition, the words and such incidental fee, and by striking from line fourteen of said section the following words in no case to exceed one dollar per month for each scholar, so that said seventh section, when thus amended, shall read as follows: Be it further enacted, That said board of education shall provide separate schools for the white children and for the colored teachers and children of the town. All children in the town between the ages of six and eighteen years of age, whose parents or guardians are bona fide residents of the town, shall be entitled to the benefits of said school. Said school shall be kept opened during not less than nine scholastic months in each year. The board of education shall provide for free tuition in said schools during a sufficient number of months to enable each scholar attending to get the full benefit of the school fund paid to said board by the State, but each scholar, after having thus received the benefit of the school fund derived from the State, shall pay such tuition and such incidental fee for the remainder of the scholastic year, or any part thereof, as the board may fix. Washington. School laws amended.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: BALDWIN COUNTY, COMMISSIONERS FOR, ELECTION OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the county of Baldwin, to prescribe the powers and duties thereof, and for other purposes, approved Dec. 26, 1888, so as to provide for the election of said board by the people instead of by the grand jury, as provided in section first of said Act.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That the Act creating the board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the county of Baldwin, to prescribe the powers and duties thereof, approved Dec. 26, 1888, be amended by striking out the first section of said Act and substituting in lieu thereof the following: Section 1. That from and after the passage of this Act, the election of said commissioners of roads and revenues of Baldwin county shall be by direct vote of the people, as follows: The successors of the two commiseioners whose terms expire in January, 1899, and January, 1900, respectively, shall be selected at an election by the duly qualified voters of Baldwin county, to be held on the 7th day of January, 1899; the length of the terms of the two commissioners thus selected to be determined by lot, and shall be for one and two years, respectively, commencing at the expiration of the terms of the present commissioners whom they succeed, and expire on January 1, 1901, or when their successors are elected and qualified. That the successors of the two commissioners elected as herein provided for, and the successor of the commissioner whose term expires in January, 1901, shall be elected by the duly qualified voters of Baldwin county, said election to be held on the first Wednesday in October, 1900, on the day of holding elections for the members of the Lesgislature, and subject to the same rules and regulations prescribed for the election of members of the Legislature. The three commissioners thus elected shall hold office for a term of two years, beginning January 1, 1901, and their successors shall be elected biennially thereafter, on the day of the regular election for members of the General Assembly, immediately preceding the expiration of their terms of office. Baldwin county, commissioners for. Election of, when held. Terms of.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That the elections provided for by this Act shall be conducted as to manner, place, qualifications
of voters, superintendence and qualifications of managers, in accordance with the law prescribed for holding elections for members of the General Assembly, and in case of contest by either candidate, the same shall be in accordance with the law now prescribed for contests for city offices. Elections, how held.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That the registration for the election of members of the General Assembly, held on the first Wednesday in October, 1898, shall be sufficient for the special election provided for in this Act, except that the board of registrars shall add to the said registration list the names of all qualified voters who may have registered after said October election, and prior to January 1, 1899. Voters.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, That section ten of said Act be amended by striking from the last line thereof the words meeting of the grand jury, and inserting in lieu thereof the following: regular election, so that said section, when amended, shall read as follows: Section 10. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That all vacancies in said board shall be filled by the remaining commissioners until the next regular election. Vacancies.
Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: BROOKS COUNTY, COMMISSIONERS FOR, ELECTION OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to change the manner of selecting the members of the board of county commissioners of Brooks county, by providing for the election of said board by the legal voters of said county, and fixing the time and place of holding said election, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act the members of the board of county commissioners of Brooks county shall be elected by the legal voters of said county at the same time and place and under such regulations as now provided for the election of members of
the General Assembly; provided, that the first election under this Act shall be held at the time of the election of the members of the General Assembly next preceding the expiration of the term of the member or members of the present board. Brooks county, commissioners for. Election of.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That the board so elected, and their successors in office, shall have and exercise all the powers and duties provided by the Act creating the board of commissioners of said county of Brooks. Powers of.
Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: BURKE COUNTY, COMMISSIONERS FOR, COMPENSATION OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to compensate the members of the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of Burke county, Georgia, for their services.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by authority of the General Assembly of the State of Geogia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, each member of the board of county commissioners of roads and revenues of Burke county shall be paid the sum of $3.00 per day out of the county treasury of said county for each day that they actually serve in their capacity as a court of commissioners. Burke county commissioners. Compensation of.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws or parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: BUTTS COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR, ESTABLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues in and for the county of Butts; to define the number of commissioners on said board and to fix their duties according to the law regulating the authority and supervision of such commissioners over county matters as now provided.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, there shall be created and established a board of commissioners of roads and revenues in and for the county of Butts in said State. Butts county. Board of commissioners for.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said board shall consist of three members, who shall be elected by the qualified voters of said county. The first election under this Act shall be called by the ordinary of said county after giving thirty days' notice by publication as soon after the first day of January, 1899, as the ordinary of said county may deem practicable. The terms of office of the three first commissioners under this Act shall expire the first day of January, 1901. Said commissioners under this Act shall hold their offices for two years, except as above set out for the first term. They shall be elected after said first election at the regular time provided for holding elections for ordinary and other county officers, and shall qualify and be commissioned as other county officers, and all vacancies occurring at any time shall be filled as vacancies in county offices are now filled. Election of. Terms of office.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said board of county commissioners shall be vested with all the power now exercised by law by the ordinary of said county over county matters so far as relates to roads, bridges, public buildings, property, managements of the county jail and its fees, the control and maintenance of paupers, assessing and collecting taxes, disbursing public money for county purposes, and execution of all laws in reference thereto and so far as the same relates to all other county matters over which the court of ordinary now has jurisdiction, simply as to the management of county matters for county purposes. Powers of.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said commissioners shall at their first meeting of each year choose
one of their number chairman, whose duty it shall be to preside at all meetings, to approve and sign the minutes of each meeting, and to sign, as chairman, all orders and processes of said commissioners. Chairman.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said commissioners shall meet in regular session at the county site once in each month for the transaction of county business, but may meet in special session whenever, in their judgment, public necessity may require; and they may in their discretion, at their first meeting after their organization under this Act, appoint some suitable person to serve as clerk, whose term of office shall be the same as the terms of the commissioners unless removed by them, they having the power to do so in their discretion. Said commissioners shall fix the compensation of said clerk at their first meeting in each year, the compensation of said clerk not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars per year. At the same time said commissioners shall fix their own compensation, not to exceed two dollars for each day's attendance upon their meeting; the compensation of said commissioners in no event to exceed the sum of one hundred dollars each per year; the compensation for commissioners and clerk to be paid out of the treasury of said county on orders signed by the chairman. Meetings. Clerk. Compensation of commissioners.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall be the duty of the clerk to attend on all the meetings of the commissioners, and to keep in well bound books, to be provided at the expense of the county, full and accurate records and minutes of all their transactions; to file in the order of their date all original orders and other papers, to arrange and keep in the order of their filing all petitions, applications and other papers addressed to said commissioners, and to record in separate book all orders made or approved by said commissioners for the payment of money by the county treasurer, and all books, files and records to be used or kept shall always be open at the county site for the inspection of any tax payer of the county on demand. If no clerk is appointed by said commissioners, then the books and records specified in this Act shall be kept by the chairman or secretary of said board. Duties of clerk.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said commissioners shall at least once in each year prepare and submit to the grand jury of said county a complete statement in writing of the condition of the county property, paupers and finances and shall, whenever called on by the grand jury, furnish
full and distinct information concerning the public business of the county. Reports of commissioners.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said commissioners shall be commissioned in the same manner as the justice of the peace, and before entering on the duties of their office shall take and subscribe to an oath to faithfully discharge the duties of said office. Commissioners. Oath.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the said board of commissioners shall require said clerk before entering upon his duties to take the same oath taken by them, and to enter into a bond with good security payable to said commissioners and their successors in office, conditioned to well and truly do and perform the duties of said office. Said bond to be in the sum of one thousand dollars. Clerk, oath and bond of

Sec. X. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That it shall be the duty of the ordinary of said county to deliver to said commissioners all books and papers relating to the jurisdiction and powers herein conferred, and said ordinary shall have no power to exercise any of the powers herein conferred upon said commissioners after their election and qualification. Transfers of books by ordinary.

Sec. XI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said commissioners and said clerk shall be exempt from jury duties, street or road duties, and shall be subject to prosecution for malpractice in office and removal from office in the same manner as justices of the peace. Commissioners removable.

Sec. XII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said commissioners shall be citizens of said county, not less than twenty-five years of age, and shall have resided in said county not less than two years prior to their election. Qualifications of commissioners.

Sec. XIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the qualification of voters at the election of said commissioners shall be the same as prescribed by the laws of this State for election for other county officers and the regulation for making returns of said election shall be the same. Qualifications of voters.
Sec. XIV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: CHATHAM COUNTY, OFFICERS OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act entitled an Act to prohibit in Chatham county the holding of more than one office by one person at any one time, and for other purposes, approved December 15, 1894, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That the Act prohibiting in Chatham county the holding of more than one office by one person at any one time, and for other purposes, approved December 15, 1894, be, and the same is, hereby repealed. Chatham county. Officers of
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: COLUMBIA COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR, ESTABLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues in the county of Columbia, to define their powers and duties, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That a board of commissioners of roads and revenues shall be established for the county of Columbia composed of three persons. Said board shall, when sitting for county purposes, have exclusive jurisdiction over the following subject-matters: 1st. In governing and controlling all county property as they may deem best according to law, letting, hiring out, or farming out the county convicts of said county. 2d. In levying taxes for county purposes as prescribed by law. 3d. In examining, auditing, allowing and settling all claims against the county. 4th. In examining and auditing the accounts of all officers or persons having
the care, keeping, management, collecting or disbursing of money belonging to the county or appropriated to its use and bring them to a settlement. 5th. In making such rules and regulations for the support of the paupers and the promotion of their health as are not inconsistent with the laws of this State. 6th. In establishing, altering, abolishing or opening roads or bridges in accordance with law and in the general management of the roads and revenues and exercise all authority over the same, and do all other things for county purposes as are now done by the ordinary, and not inconsistent with the laws of this State. Columbia county. Board of commissioners for established Jurisdiction of.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That no person shall be competent to serve on said board until he shall have taken the following oath of office, which shall be administered by the judge of the superior court, the clerk of said court or the ordinary, which oath shall be recorded in the book of records of the proceedings of said board: You and each of you do solemnly swear that you will faithfully discharge the duties of commissioners of roads and revenues, and in all matters which require your official action you will so act as in your judgment will be most conducive to the welfare and prosperity of the entire county. Oath of commissioners.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That two of said board shall be a quorum and two must concur to pass an order or let any contract, pledge the county credit, or grant or allow any claim against the county credit, or grant or allow any claim against the county. Quorum.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, That John Q. Spires and Sheldon E. Kelly, for term of two years, and George L. Reville, for a term of four years, shall constitute and be the first board of county commissioners for roads and revenues under this act, and shall be duly commissioned by the governor of said State for a term of two and four years as above stated, commencing from the first day of January, 1899, the terms of John Q. Spires and Sheldon E. Kelly expiring on the first day of January, 1900, and one thereafter, and that of George L. Reville to expire on January 1st, 1903, and three thereafter. A board shall be elected at the same time prescribed by law for the election of county officers, commencing on the first Wednesday in October, 1900, one for two and one for four years thereafter, who shall be commissioned for two and four years by the governor of this State, said terms commencing on the same day as other county officers. All vacancies shall be filled by appointment by the judge of the superior court for any unexpired term. Appointment of. Election of.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That the said board shall have
authority to appoint a clerk who shall take an oath to faithfully perform the duties of his office as required of him by said board. Clerk.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted, That the said commissioners shall hold their regular meetings on the second Monday in each month, and hold special meetings in addition to general meeting when the interest of the county demands; provided, that both regular and special meetings shall not exceed fifty days in each year, and not so often unless concurred in by a majority of the board. Said commissioners shall keep a record of all their proceedings in a well bound book to be purchased by them for that purpose and paid for out of the county treasury on their order, and shall cause their clerk to keep said record under their supervision, and signed by them at the close of each meeting. Meetings. Records of.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted, That the treasurer of said county shall not disburse or pay out any money from the county treasury unless authorized by said county board of commissioners by written order, except as is provided for under existing general laws. County funds, disbursement of

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted, That the members of said board shall be paid the sum of two dollars per day each for the time they are actually sitting for county purposes, and their clerk two dollars per day for the time employed by them. Compensation of commissioners.
Sec. IX. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: COLUMBIA COUNTY, OFFICES OF CLERK SUPERIOR COURT AND TREASURER SEPARATED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act consolidating the offices of clerk and treasurer in Columbia county.
law.p: Section I. Be it entacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That after the passage of this Act the law allowing the offices of clerk of the superior court and treasurer of the county of Columbia to be held by one person be repealed, and the general law be of operation in said county; provided, said Act shall not take effect until October 1st, 1900. Columbia county. Offices of clerk superior court and treasurer separated.
Sec. II. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: DADE COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR, ESTABLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the county of Dade and to define its powers and duties, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act there shall be established in the county of Dade a board of commissioners of roads and revenues to consist of three persons, to wit: W. S. Taylor, J. A. Bennett and A. M. Tatum, who shall hold their office two years, but if a vacancy should occur from any cause said vacancy shall be filled by said board from the same section of said county from which said vacancy occurred. Dade county. Board of commissioners for established

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said commissioners shall hold their meetings at the court-house in said county on the first Monday of each month; provided, that the regular time of meeting may be changed to some other day of the month, by order on their minutes, which order shall remain of force until rescinded; provided further, that said commissioners may hold special sessions at any time the business of the county demands immediate attention; provided, that not more than two days be consumed in any one month at the expense of the county. A majority of said board shall constitute a quorum to transact business and exercise any power herein delegated pertaining to their duties. Meetings. Quorum.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said commissioners shall have power to exercise exclusive and original jurisdiction over the following subject-matter, to wit: Jurisdiction of.
1st. In contracting for and letting out all bridges and all other public work.

2d. In examining and auditing all claims against the county
except the pay of jurors and the payment of officers of the superior court, and the treasurer of the county shall not disburse or pay out any funds from the county treasury on any order unless the same shall have been approved by said board of commissioners and countersigned by the chairman.

3d. that said board of commissioners shall have the same power in appointing the road commissioners and enforcing the road law as were vested in the ordinary of said county prior to the passage of this Act.
4th. In holding and controlling all property belonging to the county.
5th. In purchasing all supplies of any kind for the county or use of the county officials.
6th. In levying all general and special tax for countyparposes according to law.
Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said board shall receive one dollar and fifty cents per day for actual service, and be exempted from road and jury duty.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any of the commissioners named in this Act shall refuse to qualify or act the vacancy so caused shall be filled as is provided in section one of this Act, and at the expiration of the first two years vacancies shall be filled by recommendation of the grand jury to the county court judge, and if no county court judge, then the judge of the superior court, who shall fill said vacancies by appointment for a term of two years; provided, that each section of the county shall be represented as near as practicable. Vacancies.
Sec. VI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said board shall have the same right to punish for contempt as the judge of the superior court of this State. Contempt.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That if any person furnishes any pauper of the county any goods or supplies of any kind by contract with the county authorities, they must present an itemized bill, showing the date and the article and price of said articles furnished before the board of commissioners shall have authority to pass upon or approve the order given for the same. Supplies, how paid for.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That before entering upon the discharge of the duties of said board of commissioners they shall each take an oath to faithfully and impartially discharge the duties of commissioners of roads and revenues of said county, to be administered by any judicial officers of said county authorized to administer oaths. Oath of commissioners.
Sec. IX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said board of commissioners shall each hold their office until their successors are elected and qualified. Terms of office.
Sec. X. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said board shall organize by electing one of their number chairman of said board, and one of their number clerk of said board. Chairman.
Sec. XI. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: DOUGHERTY COUNTY, SHERIFF'S BOND.
law.fulltitle: An Act to reduce the sheriff's bond of the county of Dougherty and State of Georgia, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, the persons elected or appointed, or now holding the office of sheriff of the county of Dougherty and State of Georgia, shall be required to give bond and security in the sum of ten thousand dollars only, for the faithful performance of the duties of the sheriff's office of said county of Dougherty. Dougherty county. Sheriff's bond.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted by authority of the same, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: FANNIN COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR, ABOLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act entitled an Act to create a board of county commissioners for the county of Fannin, to define their powers and duties, and for other purposes, approved December 16, 1895.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assemby of the State
of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, the above recited Act, approved December 16, 1895, creating a board of county commissioners of roads and revenues in and for the county of Fannin, be and the same is, hereby repealed. Fannin county. Board of commissioners for abolished.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: GLYNN COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR, ELECTION OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues in the county of Glynn, so as to provide for the election of such commissioners by the people, and to increase the number of such commissioners so that each militia district in the county shall have representation on said board, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That section one of an Act to create a board of commissioners and revenue in Glynn county, enacted by the General Assembly in 1870, be amended by striking therefrom the words three persons to be appointed by the grand jury of the county, and also by striking therefrom the words: and all succeeding boards shall hold their office for the term of one year, unless sooner removed by the judge of the superior court, upon the request of two-thirds of any grand jury impaneled at any term of the superior court of said county. Glynn county.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That section two of said Act of 1870 be stricken and the following be inserted in its place and stead: Said board of commissioners of roads and revenue shall be composed of seven members, four of whom shall reside within the corporate limits of the city of Brunswick and three of whom shall reside without the corporate limits of said city. From and after the passage of this Act, C. D. Ogg, Tobias Newman, J. J. Lott and M. Isaac, of the city of Brunswick, J. L. Foster of the 25th militia district of said county, W. R. Townsend of the 1499th
militia district of said county, and Davis Dubberly of the 1356th militia district of said county, shall constitute the board of commissioners of roads and revenue of Glynn county. The term of office of said named commissioners shall expire on the first day of January, 1901. On the first Wednesday in October, 1900, on the day of holding elections for county officers of said county, and subject to the same rules and regulations prescribed by law for the election of members of the Legislature, the successors to the above named commissioners shall be elected. The commissioners elected on the first Wednesday in October, 1900, shall hold office for a term of two years, beginning January the first, 1901, and their successors shall likewise thereafter be elected on the same day for holding elections for county officers of said county, and for like terms. The commissioners so elected shall be commissioned by the governor. Appointment of. Election of.

Sec. III Be it further enacted, That any vacancy in said board shall be filled for the unexpired term by the remaining members of the board. The person appointed to fill such vacancy must be a resident of the militia district in which the member whom he is to succeed resided at the time of his election or appointment. Should any member of said board remove from the militia district in which he resided at the time of his election or appointment, his office shall immediately become vacant and his successor appointed by the remaining members of said board. Vacancies.
Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, That sections three and six of said Act of 1870, creating said board of commissioners of roads and revenue be, and the same are, hereby repealed and stricken.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That the word two in section five of said Act of 1870 be, and the same is, hereby stricken, and the word four inserted in lieu thereof, so that said section as amended shall read: That it shall require four of said commissioners to form a quorum for the transaction of business, and a majority must concur to pass any order or decree. Quorum.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted, That the compensation of said commissioners shall be two dollars each per day for each day they shall hold meetings for the transaction of the county business, such compensation to be paid out of the county treasury; provided, that no member shall be paid such per diem for any session of the board from which he was absent; and provided further, that such compensation shall not be paid for more than twenty sessions of the board per annum. Compensation.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted, That section ten of said Act of
1870 be amended by striking out the word three therein and inserting in its place and stead the words one hundred and fifty, so that when amended said section shall read as follows: That said board may elect a clerk, whose duties shall be defined by said board, with such compensation, to be paid out of the county treasury, as they may see proper to give him; said compensation, however, shall not exceed one hundred and fifty dollars per annum. Clerk.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted, That in addition to the statement required by section twelve of said act of 1870 to be rendered to the grand jury at each regular session of the superior court, it shall be the duty of said board to have published quarterly, in a newspaper of general circulation in said county, a statement of the financial affairs of said county, showing all receipts and disbursements, and also to publish monthly in such paper a synopsis of the proceedings of each meeting of the board showing plainly the business transacted at such meeting. Reports.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted. That all contracts for public improvements and the purchase of supplies, including the contract for the printing of the statements and proceedings provided for in this Act, shall be let to the lowest responsible bidder, and due advertisement shall be made of the letting of all such contracts and inviting bids therefor. Contracts, how let.

Sec. X. Be it further enacted, That the members of said board of commissioners shall be disqualified from holding any other county office, or State office, and shall not be eligible to serve as grand jurors, so long as they hold their commissions as such commissioners, and are exempt from militia and jury duty. Commissioners can hold no other office.

Sec. XI. Be it further enacted, That said board shall have the entire control and management of the convicts of said county sentenced to work on the public works of said county, and shall employ them on the public roads and works of said county, and on the streets of the city of Brunswick, and to improve the sanitation of said county, under the laws regulating the working of such convicts. The said board shall have authority to employ a superintendent and guards for said convicts, and to prescribe their duties and fix their compensation. In the event such convicts are employed in agricultural pursuits on a county farm, the products of their labor shall not be marketed in said county in competition with the products of free-labor. Convicts, control of.

Sec. XII. Be it further enacted, That all disbursements made by said board shall be on warrants drawn on the county treasurer, signed by the president and countersigned by the clerk of the board and on the authority of said board. Warrants on treasurer.
Sec. XIII. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: HANCOCK COUNTY, INSOLVENT COSTS OF JUSTICES OF THE PEACE AND OTHER OFFICERS.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act entitled an Act to provide for the payment of the insolvent costs of the justices of the peace, notaries public, and constables of Hancock county, approved November 13th, 1889.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That section three of an Act entitled an Act to provide for the payment of the insolvent costs of the justices of the peace, notaries public and constables of Hancock county, approved November 13th, 1889, be, and the same is, hereby repealed. Hancock county. Insolvent costs.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: HOUSTON COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS, MEETINGS OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act entitled an Act to create a board of roads and revenues for the county of Houston, and for other purposes, approved February 28th, 1874, by striking out the words four regular sessions annually, between the words hold and at, in the sixth section of said Act, and inserting in lieu of said words the words a session on the first Tuesday in each month, so that said Act, when so amended, shall provide for monthly sessions of said board, and to amend further by striking out all of section nine of said Act, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act an Act entitled an Act to create a board of roads and revenues for the county of Houston and for other purposes, approved February 28th, 1874, be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking out the words four regular sessions annually between the words hold and at in the sixth section of said Act, and inserting in lieu thereof the words a session on the first Tuesday in each month, so that the same, when so amended, shall read as follows: Section VI. That said board shall hold a session on the first Tuesday in each month at the court-house; provided, nevertheless, that a majority of said board may convene the same in extraordinary session whenever, in their judgment, the interest of the county of Houston may demand it. Houston county, Board of commissioners. Meetings of
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That said Act be, and is here-by further amended by striking out all of section nine from the body of said Act.
Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: MARION COUNTY, JUDGE OF COUNTY COURT, SALARY OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to fix the salary of the judge of the county court of Marion county, to provide for the payment of the same, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, that from and after the passage of this Act, the salary of the judge of the county court of Marion county in criminal matters shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00) per annum, to be paid by the county treasurer of said county in quarterly installments at the end of each quarter of the calendar year. Marion county. Judge of county court. Salary of.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: MONROE COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS ENLARGED.
law.fulltitle: An Act amending an Act approved August 27, 1872, creating a board of commissioners of roads, public buildings and public property and finances for the county of Monroe, and for other purposes, so as to increase the number of commissioners from three to five and make their terms four years instead of three years, and provide for their election by the people, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from the passage of this Act an Act approved August 27th, 1872, entitled an Act to create a board of commissioners of roads, public buildings and public property and finances for the county of Monroe, and for other purposes, be, and the same is, hereby amended by changing the number of commissioners for said county from three to five, and the length of term of said commissioners from three to four years, subject to the provisions hereinafter made. Monroe county. Five commissioners. Terms of.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That within thirty days after the passage of this Act the commissioners of said county shall order an election to determine whether the provisions of this Act shall become operative in said county and for the purpose of electing five commissioners, at which election all qualified voters may be entitled to vote. Those favoring the provisions of this Act shall have written or printed on their ballots For the new law, and those opposing shall have written or printed on their ballots Against the new law, and the managers of said election shall meet and consolidate the vote as in cases of the elections of members of the General Assembly, and certify the result to the board of commissioners of said county, at the same time delivering to them the ballots and tally sheets of said election. Said board of commissioners shall declare the result of said election, and if a majority of those voting on said question shall be in favor of the new law, then the same shall become immediately operative in said county, and the commissioners elected shall immediately qualify and assume the duties of their office as now provided by law, and if a majority of the votes on said question are against the new law, then the provisions of this Act shall be inoperative in said county. Election, to increase number of commissioners.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That the terms of all commissioners elected under this Act shall be four years or until their successors are elected and qualified; provided, however, that the terms of the first commissioners elected under this Act shall expire as follows: The term of the two receiving the lowest number of votes shall expire January 1st, 1901, and the remaining three January 1st, 1903, and their successors shall be elected at the general election preceding the expiration of their term; provided, however, if a vacancy occurs as much as six months preceding a general election the board may in their discretion order an election to fill such vacancy. And in all special elections under the provisions of this Act the said commissioners shall have the right to order a new registration list for said election or adopt the one of the last preceding general election, but the adoption of any registration list previously made up shall not be construed so as to prevent any one from voting who may have become of age since the said list was made up and prior to the election at which he offers to vote if he is otherwise qualified to vote. Terms of commissioners.
Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: OCONEE COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS ABOLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act entitled an Act to provide for the creation of a board of commissioners of roads and revenue for the county of Oconee, and to define the powers and duties thereof, approved February 28, 1875, which said Act clothed the governor with the power of appointing the original members of said boardfive in number; and provides for the appointment of their successors by the judge of the superior court of the circuit to which said county belongs, etc., and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority aforesaid, That an Act entitled an Act to provide for the creation of a board of commissioners of roads and revenue for the county of Oconee, and to define the powers and duties thereof, approved February 28, 1875, which said Act clothed the Governor with the power of appointing the original members of said board, five in number; and provided for the appointment of their successors by the judge of the superior court of the circuit to which said county belongs, etc., be, and the same is, hereby repealed. Oconee county. Board of commissioners abolished.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: PULASKI COUNTY, SOLICITOR OF, HOW APPOINTED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to fix the terms of office of county solicitors of Pulaski county.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That the term of office of the county solicitor of Pulaski county, Georgia, shall terminate on the 31st day of December, 1898. Pulaski county, Solicitor of.

Sec. II. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the terms of office of county solicitors in and for the county of Pulaski shall
be two years, beginning from the 31st day of December, 1898, at which time, or as soon thereafter as practicable, the Governor shall appoint a county solicitor for said county, and shall every two years thereafter, dating from December 31st, 1898, make appointments to said office. How appointed.
Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: RICHMOND COUNTY, SHERIFF'S COSTS IN CITY COURT.
law.fulltitle: An Act to limit and regulate the payment of insolvent costs of the sheriff of Richmond county for services in the city court of said county out of the treasury of Richmond county, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, the treasurer of Richmond county shall pay to the sheriff of Richmond county for insolvent costs in criminal cases in the city court of said county, upon presentation of itemized bills, when audited and approved by the presiding judge; provided, the sum so paid shall not exceed in any one year twelve hundred dollars. Richmond county. Sheriff's costs.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: RICHMOND COUNTY, CLERK'S COSTS IN CITY COURT.
law.fulltitle: An Act to limit and regulate the payment of insolvent costs of the clerk of the city court of Richmond county for services in said court out of the treasury of Richmond county, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, the treasurer of Richmond county shall pay to the clerk of the city court of the county of Richmond, upon presentation of itemized bills for insolvent costs in criminal cases in such court when audited and approved by the presiding judge; provided the sum shall not exceed in any one year the sum of twelve hundred dollars. Richmond county. Clerk's costs in city court.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: SPALDING COUNTY, COMMISSIONERS OF, COMPENSATION CLERK.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the counties of Spalding and Butts, assented to February 5th, 1873, so as to repeal sections two and three of said Act so far as it applies to the county of Spalding, and to fix the compensation of the commissioners of Spalding county, and to give them authority to elect a clerk and fix his compensation, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and immediately after the passage of this Act, that the second and third sections of the Act creating a board of commissioners
of roads and revenues for the county of Spalding and Butts, approved February 5th, 1873, so far as they are applicable to the county of Spalding, they be, and are, hereby repealed, and in lieu of said sections the following sections shall be adopted. Spalding county. Commissioners of.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That each commissioner of roads and revenues of the county of Spalding receive one hundred dollars per annum in full for his services, to be paid out of the treasury of the county of Spalding. Salary of.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That the said board shall have authority to elect a clerk and define his duties, and to fix his compensation, which shall not exceed three hundred dollars per annum, to be paid out of the treasury of the county of Spalding, and to require a bond of said clerk in the sum of five thousand dollars, with good security payable to the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of the county of Spalding and their successors in office, conditioned to faithfully perform the duties of said office. Clerk.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed, and the said Act when amended shall read as follows:

Sec. I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That from and immediately after the passage of this Act, all the provisions of an Act to create a board of commissioners of roads and revenues in the county of Harris assented to March 17th, 1869, be made applicable to the counties of Spalding and Butts except the 10th section of said Act. Law as amended.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That each commissioner of roads and revenues of the county of Spalding receive one hundred dollars per annum in full for his services to be paid out of the treasury of the county of Spalding.

Sec. III.
