Be it further enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That the said board of Spalding county shall have authority to elect a clerk and define his duties, and to fix his compensation, which shall not exceed three hundred dollars per annum, to be paid out of the treasury of the county of Spalding, and to require a bond of the said clerk in the sum of five thousand dollars, with good security payable to the board of commissioners of roads and revenues of the county of Spalding and their successors in office, conditioned to faithfully perform the duties of said office.
Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act are hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: THOMAS COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS ABOLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act entitled an Act to provide for a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for counties of Camden, Thomas, and Echols, approved February 20th, 1873, so far as relates to the county of Thomas, and an Act amendatory thereof approved February 13th, 1877, and all Acts amendatory of either of these Acts, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, an Act entitled an Act to provide for a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the counties of Camden, Thomas and Echols, approved February 20th, 1873, so far as relates to Thomas county, and an Act amendatory thereof approved February 13th, 1877, and all Acts amendatory of either of these Acts, be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Thomas county. Board of commissioners abolished.
Sec. II. Be it enacted by authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: THOMAS COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR ESTABLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to provide for a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the county of Thomas; to provide for their election by the people; to prescribe their powers and duties; to fix their compensation, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of same, That there shall be a board of commissioners of roads and revenues for the county of Thomas to consist of five members and to be known as the county commissioners of Thomas county; that J. T. Pittman, J. B. Carroll and E. R. Whaley be, and they are, hereby appointed members of said board of commissioners to hold their offices until the first day of January 1901, and until their successors are elected and qualified; that at the next general election to be held in October, 1900, three men shall be elected by the voters of Thomas county, as other county officers are elected, to hold their office for a term of four years beginning January 1, 1901; that S. L. Hayes and Casper Walker are hereby appointed members of said board of commissioners to hold office until January 1, 1903, and until their successors are elected and qualified; that at the general election in 1902 two commissioners shall be elected at the same time and in the same way as other county officers are elected, for a term of four years from January 1, 1903; that as the terms of the several commissioners expire, their successors shall be elected, commissioned and qualified as other county officers; that all vacancies shall be filled by the remaining commissioners, and such person or persons so chosen shall be commissioned by the Governor of the state of Georgia to hold office until the first of January next, succeeding a general election for county officers, at which general election a member or members shall be elected for the unexpired term or terms, if any. Thomas county. Commissioners of. E'ection of. Vacancies

Sec. II. Be it enacted by authority of same, That the board of commissioners so organized shall have exclusive jurisdiction, care and control over bridges, public roads, ferries, public buildings and other property of the county, and shall have and exercise the jurisdiction formerly vested in the superior court, and afterwards by the
Constitution of 1868, vested in the ordinary over the following subject-matters, to wit: In assessing general and special taxes for county purposes; in examining and settling the accounts of all officers charged with the collection, keeping or disbursement of public moneys; in auditing and settling all claims against the county; in establishing and changing militia districts and election precincts; and in changing the places for holding justice's courts; in establishing and discontinuing public roads; in the appointment of road commissioners and the enforcement of road laws; in the establishment and control of public bridges and ferries; in providing for the care, maintenance and burial of paupers; and in fixing the fees for dieting prisoners confined in the county jail. Jurisdiction of

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the board of commissioners shall have exclusive authority to lease or hire out to such persons and on such terms as they may deem proper, all persons convicted of misdemeanor in the superior or county courts of the county and sentenced to labor on the chain gang or on the public works, taking from such lessees such bond and security for the safe keeping and comfort of the convicts, so leased or hired, as they may deem sufficient, or they may, in their discretion, employ such convicts on the public roads of the county, and shall have authority to make suitable provision for guarding and feeding them while so employed. Convicts.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the board herein provided for shall have exclusive authority to take and approve the official bonds of all county officers; and to provide, either by appointment or by ordering elections, as the ordinary was heretofore authorized to do, for filling all vacancies in the offices of the county. Official bonds, etc.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the board of commissioners shall meet at the county site for the transaction of county business, at least once in each month, but may meet in extraordinary session as often as the affairs of the county may require, and at all such meetings three of its members shall constitute a quorum. The members of the board shall, at the first regular meeting after their election, select one of their number to act as chairman during the term for which they were elected, who shall preside at all meetings of the board and shall have authority to summon witnesses and compel their attendance; to administer oaths and take testimony in all matters relating to the business of the county. At the same meeting there shall also be chosen a suitable person to serve as clerk, whose duty it shall
be to attend all meetings of the board and to keep a full record of its proceedings, and who shall receive for such services such compensation as the board may prescribe, and shall be removable at the pleasure of the board. It shall be the duty of the sheriff of the county, when required by the chairman, to attend all meetings of the board, to preserve order and to carry out the instructions of the board. In the absence of the chairman, the other members of the board may appoint a temporary chairman to discharge the duties and exercise the functions of the chairman. Meetings. Clerk. Sheriff.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That the treasurer of the county shall make such reports, and submit his books and accounts to such inspection as the board may require, nor shall that officer disburse any funds of the county except upon orders signed by the chairman of the board or the judge of the superior court, but the concurrence of a majority of the members of the board shall be necessary to authorize the making of such orders by the chairman. Treasurer. Disbursements.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That the members of the board of commissioners shall each receive five dollars for actual attendance upon each regular monthly meeting of the board, and shall also be exempt during their term of office from road, militia and jury duty. They shall submit through their chairman, to the grand jury of the county, at the spring term of the superior court in each year a statement in writing, of all matters relating to the financial condition of the county, its roads, bridges, public buildings and paupers, with such suggestions in regard to county affairs as they may deem proper to make. The records of the proceedings of the board shall be open at all times to inspection by any citizen of the county. Each outgoing board shall turn over, at the expiration of their term of office, all records, books, papers and other property of the county to their successors in office. Compensation of. Reports of.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That said commissioners shall each subscribe an oath to faithfully discharge the duties imposed by the provisions of this Act. Said oath shall be taken and subscribed before the ordinary of the county before entering upon their duties. Oath of.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted by authority aforesaid, That nothing contained in the foregoing sections shall be construed as giving to the board herein provided for any jurisdiction or control over the county board of education or the county school commissioner. Board of education.
Sec. X. Be it enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: TWIGGS COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR ESTABLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to create a Board of Commissioners of Roads and Revenues for the county of Twiggs and to define its powers, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act there shall be established in and for the county of Twiggs a board of commissioners of roads and revenues to consist of five persons as follows: Jas. W. Jones, W. A. Joyner, I. N. Maxwell, George W. Waters and E. F. Pettis, citizens of said county. Twiggs county. Board of commissioners.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That the first two commissioners named shall hold their offices until their successors are elected and qualified, which said election shall be held with and in the same manner as the regular election for county officers on the first Wednesday in October, 1900, and every two years thereafter. The last three commissioners named shall hold their offices until their successors are elected and qualified, the election for which shall be held with and in the same manner as the regular election for county officers on the first Wednesday in October, 1902, and every two years thereafter. Any vacancy occurring in the board hereby created, or any subsequent board, shall be filled by the remaining commissioners, and the person thus chosen shall hold his office for the unexpired term of the commissioner whose vacancy he fills, and no person shall be eligible for office under this Act who has not been a resident citizen of said county at least one year next preceding his election. Election of. Vacancies. Qualifications.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That said board shall have exclusive jurisdiction over all matters concerning county property, county taxes, general and special; in establishing and changing militia districts and election precincts; in examining, auditing and allowing all claims against the county; in examining, auditing
and settling the accounts of all officers having the care, management, collection, keeping and disbursement of money belonging to the county or due to the county; in establishing, altering and abolishing roads, bridges and ferries; in the appointment of road commissioners and enforcement of the road laws, and to exercise-exclusively the authority conferred by the general law upon county commissioners and ordinaries when sitting for county purposes where no board of commissioners of roads and revenues exists. Jurisdiction of.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted, The regular meetings of said board shall be held on the first Tuesday in each month. Three of its members shall constitute a quorum, and the concurrence of three shall be necessary to pass any order or decree. Meetings.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted, That the county treasurer shall not pay out or disburse any funds in the county treasury, except upon the written order of said board of commissioners, signed by at least three of its members upon a regular court day. County funds.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted, That said commissioners, before entering upon the duties of their office, in addition to the oath usually administered to all county officers, shall take and subscribe an oath, truly, faithfully and impartially to discharge their duties during their term of office as county commissioners, which said oath shall be administered by and subscribed before the ordinary as in case of other county officers. Oath of commissioners.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted, That said commissioners shall be authorized to elect a clerk, who shall keep a minute of all the proceedings at each meeting of said board, legibly written, in a substantially bound book provided at the expense of the county, which shall be submitted to the inspection of the grand jury at its regular sittings. Clerk.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted, That as compensation each of the said commissioners shall receive two dollars for each day he is actually engaged in his duties as commissioner, and the clerk, who may be one of the commissioners, or any other suitable person, shall receive such reasonable compensation as shall be fixed by said commissioners. Compensation of commissioners and clerk.
Sec. IX. Be it further enacted, That all laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: WASHINGTON COUNTY, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS FOR REDUCED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to amend an Act to create a board of commissioners for roads, public property and finance for the county of Washington, and to define the duties and powers of the same, and for other purposes, approved December 15th, 1897, by providing that the number of commissioners shall be reduced from seven to three, and by providing the manner in which the reduction in number of said commissioners is to be effected, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act section one of the Act creating a board of commissioners for roads, public property and finance for the county of Washington, and defining the powers and duties of the same, approved December 15th, 1897 (Acts of 1897, pages 405 to 407), be, and the same is, hereby amended by striking out the word seven in the third line of said section, immediately following the word of, and immediately preceding the word persons, and substituting therefor the word three; also by striking out the names R. R. Smith, J. C. Harman, Joseph R. Daniel and R. C. Harrison, in the third and fourth lines of said section, so that said section, when amended, shall read as follows: Section I. Be it enacted, that there shall be established in the county of Washington a board of commissioners of roads and revenue to consist of three persons, to wit: S. J. Taylor, B. C. Harris, and Wiley Harris. Washington county. Board of commissione s.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section two of the above recited Act be, and the same is, hereby repealed and the following section is adopted in lieu thereof, to wit: Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That the term of office of S. J. Taylor shall be one year from January 1st, 1899, expiring January 1st, 1900; the term of B. C. Harris shall be two years, from January 1st, 1899, expiring January 1st, 1901, and the term of Wiley Harris shall be three years, from January 1st, 1899, expiring January 1st, 1902. Said board shall be a board of county commissioners for said county of Washington, exercising control
over all county matters generally, as well as over the matters specially mentioned in the Act of December 15th, 1897. Terms of.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section three of the above recited Act be, and the same is, hereby amended, as follows, to wit: by striking out the figures 1898 in the second line of said section immediately following the word term and immediately preceding the word shall, and substituting therefor the figures 1899; also, by striking out the figures 1899 in the third line of said section, immediately following the word year and immediately preceding the word to, and substituting therefor the figures 1900; also, by striking the name of R. R. Smith, at the last of the fourth and beginning of the fifth lines of said section, and substituting therefor the name of S. J. Taylor; also, by striking out the figures 1898 in the eighth line of said section, immediately following the word term and immediately preceding the word all, and substituting therefor the figures 1899; also, by striking out the word seven in the last line of said section, immediately following the word of and immediately preceding the word years, and substituting therefor the word three, so that said section, when amended, shall read as follows, to wit: Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That the grand jury, at the fall term, 1899, shall elect a member to said board, who shall qualify as a member of said board at the first meeting in the year 1900, to fill the vacancy caused by the expiration of the term of S. J. Taylor and that succeeding grand juries, at the fall terms of the court, each year, shall elect one member to fill the vacancy that will occur the succeeding January, and that, commencing with the election of the member at the fall term, 1899, all members so elected shall hold their office on said board for a term of three years. Elections.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That section 5 of the recited Act be, and the same is, hereby amended as follows, to wit: By striking out the word four in the first line of said section, immediately following the word require and immediately preceding the word of, and substituting therefor the word two; also by striking out the word four, in the third line in said section, the same being the first word in said line, and substituting the word two, so that said section, when amended, shall read as follows, to wit: Sec. 4. Be it further enacted, That it shall require two of said commissioners to constitute a quorum to transact any business and two of said commissioners must concur to pay any order or decree, or to transact any business pertaining to the duties of said commissioners. Quorum.
Sec. V. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: ALPHARETTA, SALE OF WINE PROHIBITED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to prohibit the sale of wine within two miles of the Court-house in the town of Alpharetta in the county of Milton, and to prescribe a penalty for the same, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act, it shall be unlawful for any person or persons to sell wine of any kind whatever, in any quantities, within two miles of the court-house in the town of Alpharetta in the county of Milton. Alpharetta. Sale of wine prohibited.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That any person or persons violating the provisions of this Act shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as provided in section 1039 of volume 3 of the Code of 1895. Penalty.
Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: BUTTS COUNTY, MANUFACTURE OF LIQUOR IN PROHIBITED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to prohibit the manufacture of spirituous liquors within the county of Butts, in this State, prescribe a penalty for any violation of the provisions of this Act, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by the authority of the same, That it shall
not be lawful for any person or corporation to manufacture spirituous liquors in the county of Butts, in this State. Any person or corporation violating the provisions of this Act shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and, on conviction thereof, shall be punished as prescribed in section 1039, volume III. of the code of 1895; provided, that the Act shall not apply to the manufacture of domestic wine. Butts county. Manufacture of liquor in prohibited.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: COMER, TOWN OF, DISPENSARY FOR, ESTABLISHED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to establish, maintain and regulate a dispensary in the town of Comer, Madison county, Georgia, for the sale of ardent spirits, malt liquors, wine, cider and other intoxicants; and to establish and perpetuate a board of commissioners for the management of said dispensary, and for other purposes.
law.p:
Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That from and after the passage of this Act, W. C. Burchmore, J. J. Moore, J. L. Turner, G. M. Carithers and P. S. Rice be, and the same are, hereby constituted a body corporate under the name and style of dispensary commissioners of Comer, Georgia, for the purpose of establishing and maintaining a dispensary in said town of Comer, for the sale of ardent spirits, malt liquors, wines, cider and other intoxicants. Said commissioners shall have power to perpetuate the board by filling all vacancies that may occur, by a majority vote of the remaining commissioners; to elect from their number a chairman, a secretary and a treasurer, requiring good and sufficient bonds from the secretary and treasurer, to be approved by the board. Said board of commissioners shall have power to sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, in all courts of this state. The dispensary commissioners provided for in this Act, before entering upon the discharge of their duties as such, shall take and subscribe, before some qualified officer, an oath that they
will faithfully and honestly discharge all the duties imposed upon them by this Act. Comer, town of. Dispensary Commissioners for incorporated. Powers of. Oath of commissioners.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the dispensary commissioners provided for in this Act may establish and maintain at some convenient point in the town of Comer, Georgia, a dispensary for the sale of ardent spirits, malt liquors, wines, ciders and other intoxicants. They shall on the day after their qualification and organization, and annually thereafter, elect a man who shall be of good moral character and sober habits, to be known as the dispensary manager, who shall have charge and control of said dispensary, under their supervision. Said manager shall be chosen for the term of one year, but shall be removable at any time by said commissioners for neglect of duty or for violation of any law, and said commissioners shall fill his place at once. Said dispensary manager shall be required to take and subscribe an oath that he will faithfully and honestly discharge the duties required of him by this Act. Said dispensary managers shall also be required to give bond, with good security, to be approved by the board of commissioners, in such sum as the board may determine, conditioned to faithfully account for all goods and moneys that may come into his hands as such manager, and for the faithful performance of all duties required of him by this Act; and by such rules and regulations as the board of commissioners may enact. He shall receive such salary as the board of commissioners may fix, and his compensation shall not be dependent upon the amount of his sales. Dispensary Manager.

Sec. III. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said manager shall under the direction of said dispensary commissioners at all times keep under the supervision of said commissioners a stock of ardent spirits, malt liquors, wine, cider and other intoxicants in such quantities as said commissioners may direct. All bills incurred for the establishment, maintenance and operation of said dispensary, from time to time, shall be paid by the treasurer upon presentation when approved by a majority of said commissioners. Said manager shall sell only for cash and shall turn over all moneys received by him to the secretary of the board each day; who shall keep an account of the same and who shall turn same over to the treasurer of the board of commissioners at the expiration of each week, taking said treasurer's receipt for the same. Stock. Sales.

Sec. IV. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said dispensary commissioners shall make from time to time rules and regulations for the operation of said dispensary, not in conflict
with the provisions of this Act. The quantity of liquor to be sold to any one purchaser at one time shall not exceed four gallons, and in no event shall liquors be furnished in quantities less than half pints, and none shall be drunk in the building or on the premises where said dispensary is located. Said dispensary shall not be opened before sunrise and shall be closed each day before sunset, and shall remain closed on Sundays, election days and such other days as the commissioners may direct. Said manager shall be bound by all the laws of this State regulating the sale of liquors and all the regulations of said board of commissioners not in conflict with the laws of this State. Regulations.

Sec. V. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the manager of said dispensary shall sell to no person or persons any of said ardent spirits, malt liquors, wines, cider or other intoxicants except in sealed packages, and he shall not keep any broken packages in said dispensary, and whenever an original package is broken it shall be at once bottled and sealed. Said manager shall make a monthly report to said commissioners showing the amount of sales for the preceding month, and stock on hand on the last day of said month. Said commissioners may cause an inspection and an analysis of the stock on hand from time to time, by a competent chemist, the expense of which may be paid out of any funds in the hands of the treasurer. Sealed packages. Reports.

Sec. VI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said manager shall not allow any person or persons to loiter in or about said dispensary, or the premises on which it is situated, and for failure to enforce this section said manager shall be removed from office; and any person or persons refusing to leave said dispensary or the premises on which it is situated, or to comply with any other provision of this Act or the ordinances passed by the of the said town of Comer, shall, upon conviction thereof before the said town authorities, be punished as prescribed by the ordinances of said town. Loitering.

Sec. VII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the council of said town shall have power and authority to pass all ordinances to carry out the purposes of this Act, and provide suitable penalties for violation of any provisions. Mayor and council.

Sec. VIII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said dispensary shall be maintained and operated from the profits arising from the sale of said ardent spirits, malt liquors, wines, ciders and other intoxicants; provided, that to inaugurate said dispensary and purchase the first stock, said board of commissioners
are hereby authorized to borrow money or pledge the credit of the board, said obligation to be paid out of the first profits realized from said dispensary. Profits of dispensary.

Sec. IX. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said board of commissioners shall appropriate a sufficiency of the net profit of said dispensary, not to exceed fifty per cent. thereof, together with the public school fund, to maintain the Comer High School in said town for nine months in each year; the said full terms of said school shall be free to any student of said school resident in said Madison county within school age. The remainder of said profits may be used and expended in the interest of said town in building and repairing bridges, working streets, lighting the town, in repairing, enlarging and furnishing said school building or erecting new school building for said school when necessary, or in such manner for the interest and welfare of said town as said board of commissioners may from time to time direct. Comer high school

Sec. X. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the dispensary commissioners provided for in this Act shall receive as such commissioners a salary of twenty-five dollars each per annum, and the secretary and treasurer shall be paid twenty-five dollars each per annum additional, said salaries to be paid out of the net proceeds of the dispensary. Salary of commissioners, secretary and treasurer.

Sec. XI. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That said board of commissioners shall have full power and authority, at any time they deem it for the best interest of said town of Comer, to suspend, or discontinue said dispensary, and to close out all stock on hand. It is further provided, that the provisions of the foregoing Act shall not go into effect until adopted by a majority of the qualified voters residing within the corporate limits of the town of Comer at the regular election for councilmen of said town, to be held on the first Saturday in January, 1899; that the town council of said town of Comer shall advertise said election for the adoption or rejection of said Act, by posting notices at three public places within the corporate limits of said town, not less than five days prior to the time for holding said election; that those voting in favor of the adoption of said Act shall have written or printed upon their ballots the words For dispensary, and that those voting against the adoption of said Act shall have written or printed upon their ballots the words Against dispensary; that said election shall be held and the result declared under and by the same rules and regulations that control the election for councilmen of said town of Comer. Suspension Election.
Sec. XII. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: MITCHELL COUNTY, DISPENSARIES IN TOWNS OF.
law.fulltitle: An Act to establish, maintain and regulate dispensaries for the sale of ardent spirits, malt liquors, wines, ciders and other intoxicants in each of the several incorporated towns of the county of Mitchell on recommendation of the municipal authorities of said towns, to establish and perpetuate a board of commissioners for the management of said dispensaries, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the first day of January, 1899, it shall be unlawful for any person to sell any spirituous, vinous, or malt, or fermented liquors, or other intoxicants, in the county of Mitchell, except in the dispensaries provided for in this Act, and no municipal authorities in said county shall license the sale of such liquors by any person, firm or corporation. Mitchell county, sale of liquor in.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That the persons who now hold the offices of commissioners of roads and revenues of Mitchell county, and their successors in office, shall be known as the dispensary commissioners of Mitchell county, and they are hereby constituted a body corporate under the name of dispensary commissioners of Mitchell county, with all the powers that are usual and incident to corporations of this State, besides the powers hereinafter conferred. Dispensary. Com'ers incorporated.

Sec. III. Be it likewise enacted, That whenever the municipal authorities of any incorporated town or city in said county shall desire the establishment of a dispensary in said town or said city, it shall be the duty of sad municipal authorities to pass a resolution declaring such desire, and to furnish a copy of such resolution to said dispensary commissioners of said Mitchell county. There-upon a board of three supervisors for the dispensary to be located in such town or city shall be chosen from the citizens of said
county as follows: They shall be nominated by the minicipal authorities of such town or city and confirmed by the dispensary commissioners of Mitchell county. The supervisors thus chosen shall hold their offices until January 1st, succeeding their confirmation, and one of them shall hold for one year after said January 1st, one of them for two years after said January 1st, and one of them for three years after said January 1st; and their successors shall be nominated and confirmed in like manner, during the month of November in each year for a term of three years, each to begin January 1st next after such confirmation, so that there shall be one supervisor chosen each year for a term of three years. Any vacancy occurring on such board of supervisors from death, resignation, removal or any other cause, shall be filled as soon as practicable by nomination and confirmation as aforesaid, for the unexpired term. Any of said supervisors may be removed from office by the dispensary commissioners of Mitchell county at any time, upon ten days' written notice, for any malpractice in office, any wilful or negligent failure on his part to perform any of the duties imposed upon him or for any violation of any of the provisions of this Act, or of the laws of said State, regulating the sale of liquor. Said supervisiors shall elect one of their number chairman. Dispensaries, how established Supervisors of.

Sec. IV. Be it likewise enacted, That such board of supervisors shall elect a man of good moral character and sober habits as dispensary manager for such dispensary. Said dispensary manager first chosen shall hold his office until January 1st next succeeding his election, and after that the term of office of such dispensary manager shall be for one year, beginning January 1st of each year, and shall he be elected during the month of December preceding such January 1st. In case of a vacancy in the office of such dispensary manager from death, resignation, removal or other cause, such board of supervisors shall elect a successor for the unexpired term. Such dispensary manager shall be at all times subject to the orders, rules and regulations of such board of supervisors, and shall before entering upon the discharge of the duties of his office give such bond and security as said board of supervisors may require, conditioned to faithfully account for all goods and money that may come into his hands as such dispensary manager, and for the faithful performance of all duties required of him; and he shall also take and subscribe an oath that he will faithfully and honestly discharge the duties of dispensary manager. He shall receive such compensation as may be fixed by said board of supervisors, not to exceed the sum of $50 a month, and his compensation shall not be
in any way dependent upon the amount of his sales. He shall receive no gifts, rebates, commissions or other gain of any kind besides his salary. Manager.

Sec. V. Be it likewise enacted, That such dispensary manager shall, for and in the name of the dispensary commissioners of Mitchell county, establish and maintain, under the direction and control of the board of supervisors who elected him, and in the town whose authorities nominated said board of said supervisors, a dispensary for the sale of such liquors before mentioned, purchasing the stock therefor and keeping the same and selling the same in the manner prescribed by said supervisors, selling said liquors for cash only. All funds arising from the sale of said liquors, or from the sale of empty barrels or from any other source connected with said dispensary, shall be deposited daily with the treasurer of the town or city in which such dispensary is located, and such treasury is hereby made the depository of such dispensary. All debts incurred in the establishment and maintenance of such dispensary shall be paid out of said funds so deposited with said treasury, upon the order of dispensary manager after the same has been indorsed by at least one of the supervisors of said dispensary. Such dispensary shall be maintained and operated from the profits arising from the sale of said liquors, provided that to inaugurate said dispensary, and to purchase the first stock therefor, said dispensary commissioners of Mitchell county shall be authorized to borrow money or to pledge the credit of said dispensary commissioners of Mitchell county, but they cannot bind the county of Mitchell for any such debts in any way. Each dispensary operated under this Act shall be separate from the others, and in no event shall the profits of one dispensary be used to maintain another, but each must be self-sustaining, and any unproductive dispensary shall be discontinued by order of the dispensary commissioners of Mitchell county as soon as it appears that said dispensary is unproductive. Said board of supervisors shall, from time to time, make rules and regulations for the operation of such disponsary, not in conflict with this Act or the laws of this State. The quantity of such liquors sold to any one person at any one time shall not exceed four gallons, and in no event shall such liquors be furnished in quantities less than one-half pint, and none shall be drunk in the building or on the premises where said dispensary is located. Said dispensary shall not be open before sunrise and must be closed each day before sunset, except that during the winter season it may be opened at six o'clock a. m., and kept open at six o'clock p. m. Said manager shall be
bound by all the laws of this State regulating the sale of liquors and all of the regulations of the board of supervisors not in conflict with the laws of this State. Dispensary, how established and operated.

Sec. VI. Be it likewise enacted, That said dispensary manager shall sell to no person any of said liquors except in sealed packages, and whenever any original package is broken it shall be at once bottled and sealed. Said manager shall under oath make a monthly report to the supervisors of his dispensary, showing the financial condition of said dispensary, its liabilities, if any, cash on hand, and the amount of sales for the preceding month, and the stock on hand at the end of said month. Whenever any such authorities of any such town or city shall desire the discontinuance of any such dispensary located in said town or city, they shall pass a resolution showing such desire, and furnish a copy thereof to the dispensary commissioners of Mitchell county. Thereupon the supervisors of such dispensary shall sell its stock and close the same as soon as practicable. Sealed packages. Reports. Discontinuance.

Sec. VII. Be it likewise enacted, That the books of accounts and all other papers connected with the said dispensary shall be at all times open to inspection by the public. Said chairman of said board of supervisors shall be under the special duty of specially supervising the management of said dispensary, but shall have no more power than the other supervisors. Said chairman shall receive a salary of twenty-five dollars per annum, to be paid out of the profits of the dispensary. No other officer connected with any of said dispensary shall receive any salary. And neither said chairman nor any other officer connected with said dispensaries shall receive any gifts, rebates, commissions, or other gain from any source connected with such dispensary, either directly or indirectly. Books, etc Salaries.

Sec. VIII. Be it likewise enacted, That said board of supervisors shall as often as once in each quarter set aside as a dividend or profits all money belonging to said dispensary that can be taken from it without embarrassing the continuance of its business, with a stock of such size as said supervisors may deem proper for such dispensary; provided, said supervisor shall at all times retain a sufficient amount of funds to enable all bills incurred in the management of said dispensary to be paid cash, and they are required to avail themselves of all discounts for cash allowed on such bills. The money thus set aside as dividends or profits shall be at once divided equally between the town or city in which such dispensary is located, and the public school fund of Mitchell county, and the part thus going to the public school fund shall be paid directly to
the county school commissioner of Mitchell county, and he is hereby required to give an additional bond for the faithful accounting for said fund. Public schools.
Sec. IX. Be it likewise enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: NEWTON COUNTY, MANUFACTURE OF LIQUOR IN, PROHIBITED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to prohibit the manufacture of any spirituous, malt, or intoxicating liquors, except domestic wines, made from grapes or berries, within the limits of Newton county; to provide a penalty for violation of same, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the first day of January, 1899, it shall not be lawful for any person or persons, firm or corporation, to manufacture within the limits of the county of Newton, any spirituous, malt or intoxicating liquors, except domestic wines made from grapes or berries. Newton county. Manufacture of liquor in prohibited.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That any person or persons violating the provisions of this Act shall be guilty of a misdemeanor for each violation thereof, and shall be punished as prescribed in section 1039, volume III., Code of 1895, of the State of Georgia. Penalty.
Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: NEWTON COUNTY DISPENSARY, AUTHORITY TO ESTABLISH WITHDRAWN.
law.fulltitle: An Act to repeal an Act entitled an Act to authorize the commissioners of roads and revenues in the county of Newton to establish a dispensary where pure liquors can be obtained for medical, scientific, mechanical and sacramental purposes, whenever the citizens of said county shall, by a majority vote, prohibit the sale of spirituous and malt liquors in accordance with the present general local option law, approved October 6, 1891.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That each and all of the sections of the aforesaid mentioned Act, approved October 6, 1891, be, and the same are, hereby repealed. Newton county Dispensary
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: TALBOT COUNTY, MANUFACTURE OF LIQUOR IN, PROHIBITED.
law.fulltitle: An Act to make it unlawful to manufacture any alcoholic, spirituous, malt or intoxicating liquors, except domestic wines, in the county of Talbot, and to prescribe a penalty for violating same, and for other purposes.
law.p: Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia, That from and after the first day of April, 1899, it shall be unlawful to manufacture any alcoholic, spirituous, malt or intoxicating liquors, except domestic wine, in the county of Talbot. Talbot county, manufacture of liquor prohibited.

Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That any person or persons violating the provisions of this Act shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction, shall be punished as prescribed in section 1039, in volume 3 of the Code of 1895. Penalty.
Sec. III. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: FOR RELIEF OF O. W. LINDER, TAX-COLLECTOR OF LAURENS COUNTY, AND HIS SECURITIES.
law.fulltitle: An Act to relieve O. W. Linder, late tax-collector of Laurens county, Georgia, and B. B. Linder, W. J. Hightower, C. W. Holmes, W. T. Haskins, H. M. Burch, T. J. Haskins, J. R. Shepard, E. M. Lake and A. G. Odum, securities on said Linder's bond.
law.p: Whereas, The clerk of the superior court of Laurens county, did issue execution against O. W. Linder, late tax-collector of Laurens county, and his securities on his bond as tax-collector, for the sum of two thousand and twenty-two dollars and forty-nine cents ($2,022.49), for taxes still claimed to be due Laurens county by said Linder for the years 1891 and 1892, together with the penalty of twenty per cent. per annum on said principal, amounting in the sum total to two thousand four hundred and eleven dollars and eighty-one cents ($2,411.81), and Preamble.

Whereas, The said principal sum was not paid because said Linder verily and truly believed that said sum nor any part thereof
was not due the county aforesaid and the contrary was not made to appear to him until after a protracted investigation between said Linder and the County Commissioners of said county of Laurens, and

Whereas, The said O. W. Linder during the year of said investigation, and before the same was ever concluded, became in very ill health and totally blind, and is still blind, and therefore was unable to fully protect himself in contest with said county commissioners, and

Whereas, That since said investigation and settlement the said O. W. Linder has paid off and discharged nearly all of the principal sum found to be due by him as tax-collector, to wit: the sum of sixteen hundred and twenty-five dollars ($1,625.00), even to the sacrifice of his entire property to said payment, leaving himself penniless and absolutely blind for life;

Section I. Be it therefore enacted by the General Assembly of the State of Geeorgia, That said O. W. Linder and the securities on his bond, to wit: B. B. Linder, W. T. Haskins, J. R. Shepard, W. J. Hightower, H. M. Burch, E. M. Lake, C. K. Holmes, T. J. Haskins and A. G. Odum, are hereby relieved of the penalty for said default or any part thereof now remining unpaid. For relief of O. W. Linder, tax collector of Laurens county, and his sureties.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted, That all laws and parts of laws in conflict with this Act be, and the same are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: ST. LUKE'S METHODIST EPISCOPAL CHURCH, OF COLUMBUS, MORTGAGE.
law.fulltitle: An Act to authorize the St. Luke Methodist Episcopal Church South, of the city of Columbus, Georgia, to create a lien by mortgage deed, deed of trust, or otherwise, for the purpose of borrowing money to complete the church building and improvements on lot B in said city of Columbus, Georgia, for religious purposes, etc.
law.p:
Whereas, Lot B in the city of Columbus, Georgia, was set apart for religous purposes by the commissioners of the town of Columbus, and donated to members of the Methodist church, and as his Excellency, the Governor of the State of Georgia, was authorized
and directed by the General Assembly to issue a grant to the trustees of said Methodist church in said town, free of charge, to be held in trust by them and their successors in office, for the use of said society for religious purposes, by an Act approved December 22, 1828, and Preamble.

Whereas, Under said grant the St. Luke Methodist Episcopal Church, South, of the city of Columbus, Georgia, have used and occupied said lot and improvements thereon for religious purposes agreeably to said Act, and

Whereas, It now becomes necessary and expedient for said church to create a lien by mortgage deed, deed of trust, or otherwise, to borrow a sufficient sum of money to complete the improvements on said lot B, and

Whereas, Under an Act of the General Assembly of Georgia, approved December 19, 1859, certain persons therein named and their associates and successors in office were incorporated and made a body corporate, under the name and style of St. Luke Methodist Episcopal Church, South, of the city of Columbus, therefore

Section I. Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Georgia and it is hereby enacted by authority of the same, That from and after the passage of this Act the St. Luke Methodist Episcopal Church, South, of the city of Columbus, Georgia, is authorized and empowered to create a lien on its lot of land in said city of Columbus, Georgia, known as lot B, by mortgage deed, trust deed, or otherwise, for the purpose of borrowing a sum of money to complete the improvements on said lot, to be used for religious purposes, whenever said church may so direct by resolution of its board of trustees. St. Luke's Methodist Episcopal Church of Columbus. Mortgage.
Sec. II. Be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid, That all laws and parts of law in conflict with this Act be, and are, hereby repealed.

law.shorttitle: AUTHORIZING THE GOVERNOR TO BORROW MONEY.
law.p: Resolved by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That if it should become necessary at any time previous to the meeting of the General Assembly in October next to supply casual deficiencies, the Governor shall be, and he is, hereby authorized to borrow on the best terms he can a sum of money sufficient to supply said deficiencies, within the terms of the constitution; and the money so borrowed shall be used for the purpose specified, and for no other. Casual deficiencies.

law.shorttitle: NORTHERN BOUNDARY OF THE STATE.
law.fulltitle: A resolution authorizing the Governor to appoint a commission to consider, determine and declare the true northern boundary of this State, and for other purposes.
law.p: Whereas, The true and ancient northern boundary of this State is still unsettled and undetermined, Preamble.

Be it therefore resolved by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That the Governor be, and he is, hereby authorized to appoint three citizens of this State of high character and ability to act as commissioners in behalf of the State, to meet similar commissioners who may be appointed in behalf of the States of Tennessee and North Carolina, or either of them, for the purpose of considering and determining the true and ancient northern boundary of this State dividing the States of Georgia and Tennessee, and the States of Georgia and North Carolina. Commissioners to determine northern boundary of State.

Be it further resolved, That the General Assemblies of the States of Tennessee and North Carolina, and each of them be, and they are, hereby requested to adopt legislation reciprocal to this resolution, providing for the appointment of commissioners, to meet with the commissioners so to be appointed in behalf of this State, for the purpose of ascertaining, determining and proclaiming the true northern boundary line between the several States. Commissioners of Tennessee and North Carolina.

Be it further resolved, That so soon as the States of Tennessee and North Carolina, or either of them, shall have adopted reciprocal legislation, and have provided for the appointment of commissioners, the Governor of this State is requested to name the commissioners in behalf of this State as provided in the first section hereof, and to employ special counsel to represent the State of Georgia in the hearing before the joint commissioners. The Governor is hereby authorized to fix the compensation of the commismissioners appointed by him in behalf of this State, and also to agree with the special counsel upon the terms of his employment. Commissioners for Georgia, how appointed. Special counsel. Compensation.

Be it further resolved, That the commissioners so appointed in behalf of the several States, or on the part of the State of Georgia, and of the States of Tennessee and North Carolina shall constitute a joint tribunal which shall be vested with all the rights, powers and authority of a court of superior original jurisdiction,
and as such shall have authority to compel the attendance of witnesses and the production of papers, to hear evidence, and consider and determine questions of law, and to proceed to an adjudication of the questions at issue. The findings of such commissioners, however, shall not be final and binding upon either State unless concurred in by a majority of the commissioners acting in behalf of each State. The said commissioners shall report the evidence, together with their findings and conclusions, to the General Assembly of this State for approval and confirmation; provided, however, that any finding concurred in by a majority of the commissioners of each of the States participating in the consideration and determination of the question shall be binding upon each of such States, and shall not require legislative approval. Authority of commissioners. Report of

Be it further resolved, That should neither of the States of Tennessee nor North Carolina adopt legislation reciprocal to this resolution and appoint commissioners for the purpose and with the authority herein defined, the Governor is requested to take no action hereunder other than to report the fact to the General Assembly at its next session. Governor, authority of.

law.shorttitle: AUTHORIZING PURCHASE OF FLAG FOR THIRD GEORGIA REGIMENT.
law.p: Resolved by the Senate, the House concurring, That the Governor be, and he is, requested to purchase a State flag for the Third Georgia Regiment, volunteers, at a cost of not exceeding one hundred dollars, and present the same to said regiment, and that he be authorized to pay for the same out of the military appropriation. Flag for Third Georgia.

law.shorttitle: PER DIEM AND MILEAGE OF HOW. W. T. JONES.
law.p: Resolved by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That the widow of the Honorable W. T. Jones, late a representative from the county of Dougherty, be paid in full any unpaid balance of his per diem and mileage for the full term of fifty days, and that his Excellency the Governor be, and he is, hereby authorized to draw his warrant for the same. Authorizing payment of per diem of Hon. W. T. Jones.

law.shorttitle: AUTHORIZING PAYMENT OF DOORKEEPERS AND OTHER EMPLOYEES.
law.fulltitle: A resolution to provide for the payment of certain additional doorkeepers, pages, and porters of the Senate and House of Representatives for the session of 1898, and to provide for indexing the Journals of the Senate and House.
law.p: Whereas, By the several resolutions of the Senate and House of Representatives, respectively, there have been appointed, and are now serving, the following attachs, in addition to those provided for by the general appropriation Act for the support of the government for the years 1897 and 1898, to wit: Preamble

One assistant doorkeeper, two pages and one proter for the Senate for the session of 1898, two extra assistant doorkeepers of the House of Representatives for the session of 1898, and one additional porter for the postoffice of the House for the last half of said session;

Therefore, be it resolved by the General Assembly of Georgia, That the sum of four dollars per diem for each of said doorkeepers, and two dollars per diem for each of said pages and porters be, and the same is, hereby appropriated for their compensation for the time they serve during the present session of 1898, and the sum of one hundred and fifty ($150.00) dollars be appropriated to pay
for the indexing of the Journals of the Senate and House of Representatives for the year 1898, the same to be drawn by L. G. Brannon and O. L. Gresham, the Journal clerks of the Senate and House. The elevator boy shall be paid three dollars per diem for the session. Per diem of extra doorkeepers and pages. For indexing journals Elevator boy.

law.shorttitle: AUTHORIZING PAYMENT OF PENSION OF O. F. JOHNSON.
law.p: Whereas, O. F. Johnson, of Oconee county, was an applicant for a pension, under the indigent law, for the year 1898, and said application was passed upon and allowed by the pension commissioner, and, whereas, said O. F. Johnson departed this life a few days before his pension check reached him, and said check was returned to the treasury of the State; therefore be it resolved by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring: First, that the sum of sixty dollars allowed O. F. Johnson, as above stated, be paid to his widow, Mrs. Belle Johnson; second, that the Governor is hereby authorized to draw his warrant upon the treasury of the State for said sum of sixty dollars, in favor of the widow of said O. F. Johnson, in payment of said claim. Preamble. Pension of O. F. Johnson. How paid.

law.shorttitle: DECORATION OF CAPITOL AND EXECUTIVE MANSION.
law.p:
Resolved by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That the Governor of the State of Georgia be, and is, hereby requested to decorate the Capitol and the Executive Mansion with the National colors on Thursday, the 15th day of December, 1898, instant, the same being the date of a reception to be
held by the President of the United States in the Capitol of the State of Georgia, such decoration to be in honor of the President of the United States and of the country. In honor of the President.

law.shorttitle: AUTHORIZING PAYMENT OF PENSION OF J. W. WILLOBY.
law.p: Whereas, J. W. Willoby, of Fayette county, had been duly enrolled and paid as a pensioner from Fayette county for the year 1897, and died on the day of January, 1898, when his pension for said year was due, and after he had made his claim for 1898, as provided by law, and which pension was not paid; Preamble.

Therefore, be it resolved by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That the sum of sixty dollars ($60.00) be paid to Mrs. Charlotte Willoby, widow of said J. W. Willoby, for the use of herself and her minor children, being the pension so due her said husband for the year 1898, and that the Governor be empowered to draw his warrant for said sum in favor of the said Charlotte Willoby. Pension of J. W. Willoby, how paid.

law.shorttitle: FOR RELIEF OF CHARLES J. DOUGHERTY.
law.p: A resolution to refund Charles J. Dougherty, of Greene county, Georgia, the sum of one hundred dollars, paid by him to the tax-collector of Greene county on January 1, 1892, as a license from the State of Georgia as a retailer for the said year, on account of sickness, and other causes. Preamble.

Whereas, Charles J. Dougherty, of the county of Greene, did, on the first day of January, 1892, pay to the tax-collector of Greene
county, Georgia, the sum of one hundred dollars to the State of Georgia for a license to retail liquors in the city of Greensboro, Georgia, for said year 1892; and
Whereas, the said Charles J. Dougherty was taken sick on the first day of January, 1892, and remained sick for a long time; and

Whereas, he did not exercise any of the rights granted to him under said license, and did not retail any spirituous liquors in said city for said year 1892, either by himself or agents or clerks, therefore be it

Resolved by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That the treasurer of said State is hereby authorized and directed to refund to the said Charles J. Dougherty the said sum of one hundred dollars out of the treasury of said State. License tax refunded.

law.shorttitle: FOR RELIEF OF GEO. A. HALL AND JOEL F. THORNTON.
law.fulltitle: A resolution for the relief of George A. Hall and Joel F. Thornton, of Greene county, Georgia, as sureties on the bond of Gene Williams.
law.p: Whereas, at the February term, 1897, of the county court of Greene county, final judgment was rendered by said court against George A. Hall and Joel F. Thornton, securities for the appearance of Gene Williams, to answer to the offense of a misdemeanor in said court; and Preamble.
Whereas, since the rendition of said judgment the securities have caused the said Gene Williams to be apprehended and delivered to the sheriff; and
Whereas, the said Gene Williams was convicted in said court for said offense, and was, by said court, sentenced to work on the public roads of said county for the period of twelve months; and
Whereas, the said Gene Williams has fully served out said sentence on said public roads under the supervision of the county commissioners of said county; therefore be it

Resolved by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That the said sureties, George A. Hall and Joel F. Thornton, be, and
they are, hereby relieved from all liability on said bond, and the judgment entered on the forfeiture of the same upon the payment of costs, if any be due. Forfeited bond.

law.shorttitle: FOR RELIEF OF A. M. HILL.
law.p: Whereas, A. M. Hill, of Walton county, became security on the bond of one Tom Neal, indicted in Walton Superior Court for the offense of larceny from the house, in the sum of fifty dollars, and said case was transferred to the county court of said county, and at the January term, 1897, of said county court, the said Tom Neal failed to appear according to the terms of said bond, and the said bond was duly forfeited, and whereas the said Tom Neal was recaptured at great expense to the said A. M. Hill; and whereas, at the July term, 1897, of said county court, the said Tom Neal was tried and acquitted of offense; and whereas, the said A. M. Hill has paid all the cost of said forfeiture; therefore, be it Preamble.

Resolved by authority aforesaid, that the said A. M. Hill be, and he is, hereby relieved of any and all further liability on said bond, and the judgment and executions based on said forfeiture is hereby declared null and void, except as to costs, and of no effect as to the said A. M. Hill. Relieved as surety on bond.

law.shorttitle: APPOINTING COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE STATE TREASURY.
law.p: Whereas, the General Assembly of Georgia has upon it the responsible duty of adjusting the expenditures of the State to a level with the receipts and income thereof, without increasing the present tax rate, which is already oppressive; and Preamble.

Whereas, the General Assembly, in the performance of this duty should have all information that can be obtained, upon each and every item of expense to the State Government, before the appropriations for next year are made; and
Whereas, it appears that retrenchments are greatly needed; it is therefore
Resolved, by the Senate of Georgia, the House concurring therein,

Resolved 1st, that a committee of five from the Senate and ten from the House be appointed as a joint committee, to thoroughly investigate the condition of the State Treasury, ascertaining its condition as to the present year, and the needs and requirements of said treasury for the year 1899. Said committee shall make their report as early as practicable to the present session of the legislature. Investigation of treasury.

Resolved 2d, That the utility and necessity of each and every item of appropriations be investigated and considered separately, and the conclusion reached by said committee be reported in the order considered by said committee to each branch of the General Assembly as early as can be done consistently with the thorough performance of the duties imposed upon said committee. How made.

Resolved 3d, That said committee, in making the investigation required of them by this resolution, shall also be required to investigate the accounts of any other department of the State which has either the collection or disbursement of the State funds not covered in the treasury of the State, or of any department to which the State makes yearly appropriations. Other departments.

Resolved 4th, Said committee shall carefully ascertain the amounts necessary to be appropriated, if any, to the various purposes for which appropriations were made the present year, and report such sums.

Resolved 5th, Such committee shall be appointed by the President of the Senate and Speaker of the House from the Finance and Appropriation Committees of each House respectively. Committee, how appointed.
Resolved 6th, Said committee shall report as early as they can the result of their work.
The treasury shall first be investigated and reported upon; provided, that the investigation shall be without expense to the State.

law.shorttitle: IN REFERENCE TO NICARAGUAN CANAL.
law.p: Whereas, recent events have demonstrated the necessity for the construction of the Nicaraguan canal, under the control of the Government of the United States, whereby the effective strength of the American Navy will be doubled; and Preamble.

Whereas, the opening of this inter-oceanic water-way, between the Atlantic and the Pacific Oceans, will not only reduce the distance by water between the eastern and the western coasts of our country about ten thousand (10,000) miles, but will place our Atlantic and gulf States in touch with the great populations of Japan, Corea, Northern China, Australia, Polynesia and the western coast of South America, giving us a very superior advantage in the matter of distance, and opening to American traffic a very large area of the earth's surface, whereby new and ever-expanding markets will be opened to the cotton, coal and tobacco of the South, and to American manufacturers generally; therefore,

Be it resolved by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That our Senators in Congress be instructed, and our representatives be requested to use their best efforts in furtherance of the speedy construction of the Nicaraguan canal, under the control of the United States Government, and to this end give their zealous support to such legislation as will insure the completion of this great work at the earliest practicable date. Senators and representatives in Congress

Resolved further, That his Excellency, the Governor, be requested to have each of our Senators and Representatives in Congress supplied with a certified copy of the foregoing preamble and resolution. Governor.

law.shorttitle: WELCOME TO LEGISLATURE OF ALABAMA.
law.p:
Whereas, we learn with pleasure that the General Assembly of Alabama has decided to honor our State, by attending in a body
the Peace Jubilee to be held next week in the city of Atlanta; therefore, be it Preamble.

Resolved by the Senate, the House concurring, That a committee of five from the Senate and ten from the House be appointed to met the General Assembly of Alabama on their arrival in the city and extend to them a Georgia welcome and other proper courtesies. Legislature of Alabama

law.shorttitle: INVESTIGATION OF GEOLOGICAL DEPARTMENT.
law.p: Be it resolved by the General Assembly of Georgia, That a committee of two from the Senate and three from the House be appointed to investigate the Geological Department and report their findings as soon as possible after the adjournment of the General Assembly to the Governor of Georgia, with power to summon witnesses, to compel the production of all necessary books, papers or documents. Geological department
Resolved further, That said committee shall serve without further compensation than their actual and necessary expenses.

law.shorttitle: INVESTIGATION OF STATE SANITARIUM.
law.p: Whereas, the committee appointed to visit the sanitarium has made and filed its report, relating to said institution; and
Whereas, it is shown thereby that said committee's examination was not full and complete, on account of the limited time allowed to prosecute said investigation; and Preamble.

Whereas, said committee in its said report to the Senate of Georgia, recommends that a joint committee of two from the Senate and three from the House be appointed to make a thorough and
complete investigation of all the departments of said institution and make report to the next session of the General Assembly; now therefore, be it

Resolved by the Senate, the House concurring, that a committee of two from the Senate and three from the House be appointed to thoroughly investigate each and every department connected with said institution, and at as early a day as possible, and report its findings to the Governor of this State, and at the next session of the General Assembly, and make such recommendations as they may see proper, with power to subp[oelig]na witnesses, send for books and papers, and to do such other lawful acts as may be necessary to the full discharge of the duties herein imposed, and that said committee be instructed to make its report to the next session of the General Assembly. Investigation of Sanitarium

law.shorttitle: RETURNING WILLIAM SCHWARZ FROM SANITARIUM TO SHERIFF OF CHATHAM COUNTY.
law.p: Whereas, at the June term, 1895, of Chatham Superior Court, William Schwarz was indicted for the offense of murder, and on the call of the case, he, through his attorneys at law, F. G. duBignon and W. E. Morris, filed his plea, alleging that at the time of the commission of the alleged crime, the said William Schwarz was not of sound mind, memory and discretion, and was in fact afflicted with insanity. Further, that the accused William Schwarz, since that time, and now at the time of his trial, is not of sound mind and memory, and is in fact afflicted with insanity, as such should not be put upon trial for any of the things or matters charged in said bill of indictment. Preamble.

Upon motion of the solicitor-general, it was ordered that said portion of said plea, which alleges insanity of the defendant at the time of the commission of the crime be, and the same is, hereby stricken from said plea.
Upon the issue formed upon said plea the jury returned the following verdict: We, the jury, find for the plea. On July 27th the presiding judge passed the following judgment:

It is ordered under section 4299 of the Code of Georgia, that the said defendant, William Schwarz, be delivered by the sheriff of said county to the superintendent of the asylum of said State, there to remain until discharged by authority of law; and

Whereas, It is made known by the report of the trustees of said asylum, and by the report of the joint committee, appointed by the House of Representatives and the Senate, that said William Schwarz is now of sound mind, memory and discretion, and is not now afflicted with insanity; now, therefore, be it

Resolved, by the Senate, the House concurring, That the superintendent of the asylum aforesaid be, and he is, hereby authorized and directed to deliver the said William Schwarz to the sheriff of said Chatham county, to be by him carried back to the county of Chatham, there to be dealt with as the law directs. Wm. Schwarz.

law.shorttitle: RETURNING ROXIE ANN LONG FROM SANITARIUM TO SHERIFF OF BRYAN COUNTY.
law.p: Whereas, At the May term, 1897, of Bryan Superior Court, Roxie Ann Long was indicted for the offense of murder, and on the call of the case, she, through her attorneys at law, Seabrook and Morgan, filed her pleas, alleging that at the time of the trial she was insane, and that she ought not to be placed on trial for said charge. Preamble.

Upon the issue formed upon said plea, the jury returned the following verdict: We, the jury, find in favor of the special plea of insanity. On May 3rd, 1897, the presiding judge passed the following judgment: The plea of insanity in the above case having been tried by a special jury, and having found to be true, it is ordered that the said Roxie Ann Long be delivered to the superintendent of the State Insane Asylum, there to remain until discharged in the manner prescribed by law.
In open court, this May 3d, 1897.
R. Falligant,
Judge of Superior Court E. J. C. of Georgia.

And whereas, it is made known by the report of the trustees of said asylum, and by the report of the joint committee, appointed by the House of Representatives and the Senate, that said Roxie Ann Long is now of sound mind and memory and discretion, and is not now afflicted with insanity; now, therefore be it

Resolved by the House of Representatives, the Senate concurring, That the superintendent of the asylum aforesaid be, and he is, hereby authorized and directed to deliver the said Roxie Ann Long to the sheriff of the said county of Bryan, to be by said sheriff carried back to the county of Bryan, there to be dealt with as the law directs. Roxie Ann Long.

law.shorttitle: AUTHORIZING PUBLICATION OF PUBLIC ACTS.
law.p: Resolved by the General Assembly of the State of Georgia, That W. H. Harrison, of the county of Fulton, be, and he is, hereby authorized to publish the public Acts of this General Assembly, and for this purpose, the Secretary of State be, and he is, hereby authorized to furnish him the manuscripts of said Acts, to be properly kept and safely returned to his office. Also, that the said W. H. Harrison be authorized to include in said publication the public laws of 1896 and 1897. Public laws.

law.shorttitle: CONGRATULATIONS TO LIEUT. THOS. M. BRUMBY.
law.p: Whereas, Flag lieutenant Thomas M. Brumby, of the Asiatic Squadron, U. S. Navy, under command of Admiral Dewey, especially distinguished himself in the battle of Manila, and in the complete rout of the Spanish Navy in the further operation in and around Manila harbor; therefore, be it Preamble.

Resolved by the Senate, the House concurring, That we view with pride the splendid record of this now distinguished Georgian who raised the first American flag over Manila, and whose conduct, under the eyes of the glorious Dewey, elicited the prompt recommendation of that gallant commander, for his promotion. Lieutenant Brumby.

The General Assembly of Georgia extends cordial congratulations to Lieutenant Brumby, feels honored that Georgia is the State of his nativity, and instructs that the engrossed copy of this resolution be forwarded to him.

law.shorttitle: RECESS OF LEGISLATURE.
law.p: A resolution providing that the General Assembly adjourn on Saturday, November the 5th, and take a recess until Wednesday, November 9th, and to reconvene on Wednesday, November 9th, at twelve o'clock m. Preamble.
Whereas, The election for Congressmen of this State in the United States Congress occurs on Tuesday, November 8th; therefore, be it

Resolved, by the Senate, the House concurring, That when this General Assembly adjourns on Saturday, November 5th, that it takes a recess until Wednesday, November 9th, at 12 o'clock m. and that the time that intervenes during said recess be not counted in the fifty days allowed by law for the General Assembly to remain in session. Recess.
